Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Early in April, 1948, you advised me that the following funds are provided in your estimates, 1948-49, for the above-named school:

- New roothouse and painting and repairs to staff rooms and residence $3,000.00
- Refrigeration equipment $850.00

I have just received word from this school that they are worried about the roothouse as your local Agent informs them that he has not yet received any authority for this work. I can assure you, from personal inspection, that the present structure is not only useless but is unsafe for anyone to enter. As the school has 1½ acres of potatoes planted, in addition to other vegetables, it is of great importance that the roothouse be rebuilt before the crops are harvested and it is requested, therefore, that your Agent be given authority to proceed with the work of rebuilding as early as possible.

The report from the school also contains the following:

"There are several small repair jobs around the school which really should be attended to while the children are away; for example, some tables in the children's dining room need bracing and a few extra tacks and a coat of paint. Some places in the lower part of the dining room walls need patching with plaster and the whole lower half painting. The washrooms require repairing, the kitchen also should have a coat of paint on the lower part and the floors of the halls and stairs around the battleship linoleum need stain varnishing, etc., etc."

p.t.o.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6370, file 763-5, part 8)
It is requested that your Agent be authorized to have these minor repairs and painting carried out during the holiday period this summer. It is not very desirable to have wet paint around while small children are in residence if this can be avoided by carrying out the work when they are away.

May I be advised as early as convenient as to what you can do in regard to the above services.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

St. Cyprian's Indian Residential School.

Included in our 1948-49 Main Estimates is a sum for the repairs required to the root house at this school. As you are aware, these residential schools on the Prairie usually have good farms and store the larger portion of their produce for use in the winter. Mr. Indian Superintendent McMillan has been trying all summer to interest a contractor in carry out these repairs but he has had no success. Today we received a telegram from Mr. Gooderham, our Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies reading as follows:

"Re root house St. Cyprian School Peigan Stop McMillan got one bid only stop Playford contractor who built barn quotes $600. Stop He is reliable please wire instructions".

The contractor referred to in this telegram is Mr. Orrin Playford of Pincher Creek, Alberta, who carried out the labour required to erect a barn at this school last year. His work in this connection was quite satisfactory and it is felt that he will renovate the root house in a satisfactory manner. In view of the necessity for providing this outbuilding, it is recommended that approval be given to Mr. Playford's tender.

Director.

Re: St. Cyprian's Indian Residential School, Peigan Indian Reserve.

Mr. McMillan, Superintendent of the Peigan Reserve, informs me that as yet the Anglican Church has not sent a Principal for this school, and that he finds it very difficult to deal with the Farming Instructor who was apparently temporarily in charge. Could you please advise if and when a new Principal may be expected at this school.

Painting of Barn - St. Cyprian Indian Residential School.

Originally it was not our intention to paint this barn this year as funds were not available. However, we have closed a residential school in Northern Ontario operated by the M.S.C.O. and we are thus able to transfer funds which can be used for this project.

Could you please advise me as soon as possible as to

(a) The amount and colours of paint required for this barn,

(b) The cost of the labour involved in its painting.

The paint can then be obtained through the Departmental Purchasing Agent and an accountable advance can be forwarded to you for the payment of the Indians or those whom you employ for this work.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Colonel Neary:

It will be appreciated if you will make provision in your Departmental Estimates, 1949-50, for the following services at St. Cyprian's Anglican Indian Residential School, Brocket, Alta.:

(a) Re-flooring of Boys' Dormitory $500.00
   A good part of this floor is in very bad condition

(b) Painting exterior of Main School Building $1,200.00
   Painting is badly needed for preservation reasons

(c) Painting of all windows, including storm sash, of main building $300.00

(d) Painting of barn $600.00
   The new barn should be painted in order to preserve the woodwork

(e) New chicken house $500.00

(f) Provision of two kitchen ranges ??

(g) Provision of Farmer's Cottage $4,000.00
   The provision of a cottage to permit the school farmer to live outside the main school building is highly desirable.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent

(a) Reflooring of Boys' Dormitory $500.00
A good part of this floor is in very bad condition.

(b) Painting exterior of Main School Building $1,200.00
Painting is badly needed for preservation reasons.

(c) Painting of all windows, including storm sash, of main building $300.00

(d) Painting of Barn $600.00
The new barn should be painted in order to preserve the woodwork.

(e) New chicken house $500.00

(f) Provision of two kitchen ranges ??
(g) Provision of Farmer's Cottage. $4,000.00

The provision of a cottage to permit the school farm to live outside the main school building is highly desirable.

Please let us have your comments regarding each of the above at the earliest possible date.

Superintendent of Education.

Indian Affairs Branch Dept of Mines & Resources Ottawa.

I am in receipt of your letter of the August authorizing the sending of $300.00 on the Engine at St Cyrian's School for necessary repairs.

Mr Wilson expert of the Bruce Robinson Electric, arrived at this Agency yesterday and pulled the Lister Bruston Engine apart. I visited the school this morning and checked over the engine, which calls for two new heads, with one new block, also the Fly Wheel is very shaky and needs fixing.

I checked over the engine this A.M. with Mr Wilson, and he advises that it would be impossible to give a guarantee for the engine if the work was not completed, with the engine taken down and dismantled, and the extra work available cheaper, I authorized the placing of this engine in first class shape and found it would cost more than I originally estimated.

I would be glad if the Branch will concur in my decision, as I am led to believe, that neither the change of the Range to two small stoves, or the Walk in Refrigerator is being considered by the new Provincial.

When completed I will show the amount authorized, and any extras as an emergency.

Anthony M. Miller
Supt.

"Mr. Wilson expert of the Bruce Robinson Electric, arrived at this Agency yesterday and pulled the Lister Bruston Engine apart. I visited the school this morning and checked over the engine, which calls for two new heads, with one new block, also the fly wheel is very shaky and needs fixing.

Memorandum re Water Supply, St. Cyprian Indian Residential School

Examiners March 21, 1949

This residential school for Indian children mainly from the Peigan Indian Reservation is located two miles south of the hamlet of Brockle. At present there is a staff of ten and an enrollment of fifty-eight students. It is operated by the United Church of Canada with financial aid from the Dominion Government.

A steel-cased artesian well 60 feet deep supplies water to the school. A Robins and Myers' 1000 gallons-per-hour pump supplies water to two large pressure tanks of approximately 1200 gallons each. The well appears to be suitably protected against contamination from the top.

Two samples of water taken for bacteriological analysis (see attached) indicated the water to be of good bacteriological quality. The chemical analysis indicated the water to be of good chemical quality although the water is fairly hard. The iron content (0.60 p.p.m.) is quite high but does not appear to create a problem apart from staining of fixtures.

Conclusions and Recommendations

The water supply at this school appears to be of good bacteriological and chemical quality.

Stanley S. Copp
Sanitary Engineer, District No.8.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: St. Cyprian Indian Residential School,
Sacred Heart Indian Residential School,
Pelican Indian Agency, Electoral
District of Macleod

The first named school is conducted under the auspices of the church of England and the second school is conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. The main buildings at both schools are the same size, namely length 99', width 33' and height 40'.

The Superintendent of Indian Education visited this Agency last summer accompanied by Regional Supervisor Gooderham. The district in which these schools are located is subject to very high winds and as a result it has been necessary to have the exteriors painted every 2 or 3 years. At the time of the visit of the two officials just mentioned, it was decided that it would be advisable to cover both buildings with insul brick. Provision was made for this expenditure in the current fiscal year's appropriation, and the insul brick is being purchased by the Departmental Purchasing Agent.

Indian Superintendent McMillan has obtained the following quotations:

W.H. Leidlaw, Pincher Creek, Alberta.
(Scaffolding to be supplied by the Department)
For each building........................................$1,680.00
Gunnar Nelson, Pincher Creek, Alberta.
(Will supply his own scaffolding.)
For each building..........................$1,800.00.

Three other firms were requested to quote,
but did not give a firm tender on the labour.

In view of the size of these buildings,
considerable scaffolding will be necessary and
Indian Superintendent McMillan recommends that we
accept the tender of Gunnar Nelson, as he will
supply his own scaffolding.

We would like to have this work carried
out before September 1st, and it would be
appreciated if the Minister would approve acceptance
of the tender of Gunnar Nelson for labour at a
total cost of $3,600.00, namely $1,800.00 for each
building.

Attention Mr. Phelan

Re: Pressure Boiler, St. Cyprian's Residential School, Pelican Reserve

I made a hurried inspection on the Pelican Reserve last week. It was brought to my attention that a large pressure tank which was purchased in 1948 had not yet been put up in this school. Mr. McMillan had a tender from S. Pearson, Plumber, Pincher Creek, to do so at a cost of $440.00. I feared that this was excessive and inquired as to what Mr. Pearson was going to do when he installed this.

He stated that it was necessary to remove two old boilers that were leaking very badly and cannot be used and then replace them with the new boiler. This required the cutting of a portion of the cement and woodwork wall to take out the old boilers and put in the new one. He proposed to fill this space with a window, which, when removed would allow the passage of boilers in or out of the building.

To convince myself that this was necessary, I visited the school and inspected the basement. I then concluded that the amount asked to do this work was not excessive, but I asked Mr. McMillan to obtain a breakdown and herewith is a copy for your information.

I met Mr. Pearson at Pincher Creek and he stated that the new boiler should be put in before the school opens as the water will be cut off.

If Mr. McMillan has not already submitted the tender he will do so on instructions from this office. When it is received, I hope that it is acceptable and that you will wire the Superintendent authority to proceed with the installation.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of Department No. 116-1-14 dated the 31st ultimo with reference to stock, agricultural machinery, and tools required at the St. Cyprian Indian Residential Day School. Inspector Christianson informs me that all that the school has now in the form of outside equipment is a team of horses, an old wagon, and a democrat. I think, therefore, that it would be well to provide them with some of the articles mentioned in your letter referred to, such as:

1 wagon with box,
1 gang plow,
1 drill,
1 disc harrow,
1 drag harrow,
1 cultivator,
1 hay mower,
1 hay rake,
2 teams of horses with harness.

I do not recommend a tooth harrow and the purchase of a binder can be provided for but left over until nearly harvest time when we ascertain what has been the result of their farming operations. In regard to the poultry, this is a matter for the Department to decide but the request to be supplied with geese is unusual. If the Department desires, we could buy two brood sows.

The Secretary,

Sir,

I have received a letter from the Rev. J.R.A. Westrate at Winnipeg, asking if the Department would consider granting assistance to the St. Cyprian School at Crochet, Alberta, by providing ten cows of good milking strain. He points out that the new school has a capacity of fifty pupils, but is about fifteen short of the capacity enrollment and that as a consequence the cost of maintenance is resting heavily on the Church.

You will recall that we have granted similar assistance to schools on the Blood and Morley reserves, and to the Church of England School at Union Lake. If the Department will sanction the purchase of the animals required at the St. Cyprian School, I will take the necessary steps to arrange for their purchase to the best possible advantage.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that during my recent trip to Alberta and while at the Pelican agency I called at the two residential schools on the reserve.

At the Anglican school everything seemed to be in fair shape also. The school was clean and tidy and matters in general seemed to be running along smoothly. When I was at Hobema I received a wire from you instructing me to purchase five cows for the school, which I did. I may say that at the present time it is a very difficult matter to buy milch cows. I was in touch with most of the stockmen in Alberta and the only place I could find any cows was at the C.F.A. farm at Strathmore. The cows which I bought are Holstein. They are not pedigreed; two of them are pure bred but have no papers and the other three are practically pure bred. All have passed the tuberculin test and two of them had just freshened, while the other three are due to freshen around the end of this month. The price paid for these cows was $125.00 each, which I consider very reasonable. They are from three to six years of age and if properly looked after will produce a lot of milk.

H. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian agencies.

Dear Sir:

During a visit to our St. Cyprian School yesterday, I noted the very urgent need of a pair of bob-sleighs and undertook to ascertain if your Department would provide these. I regret that I was unable to confer with Mr. Indian Agent Arthur on this matter, as he was seriously ill with three Doctors in consultation and a surgical operation appeared to be imperative, but I feel certain he would confirm my opinion of the necessity of the sleighs. The snow lies deep on all the country side of Southern Alberta, and as a carload of coal is now on order for this School and must be off-loaded at once, and the coal drawn to the School, the urgent necessity of the sleighs is apparent. As the wagon-box will fit the sleighs, the cost should not be much for the bobs alone, and I shall be obliged if you will either undertake to provide these or authorize me to do so. A grain-cleaner or fanning mill will also be required before Spring seeding begins, but I will address a separate communication to you at a later date in this connection.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Louis Bastien, Pupil No. 126, of the St. Ignatius Indian Residential School at Brocket, who died at Piigan Indian Hospital (place) on May 15th, 1937.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Sir:

I have the honour to inform you that Thunder Chief, one of the Minor Chiefs on the Blood Reserve is very anxious to have a school opened in his village under the Church Missionary Society.

Thunder Chief's village is situated four miles up the River from the Agency, and the nearest school to it is the one established by the Methodist Church about ½ mile below the Agency, and it is in consequence too far to be of any good to the children of that village.

There are in all some 24 families with 45 children of an age to attend school in the said village. The estimated cost according to the plan adopted for day schools would be about $600.00, on account of the higher cost of labour and materials in that part of the country.

Under the circumstances I think the request is deserving of consideration, and would recommend that provision be made for the purpose, and authority be given me for the expenditure.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 13th instant re fire protection for the Church of England Boarding School on the Blood reserve. It is but just to the Principal of the School to say that he did consult me about the kind of plant that should be purchased to secure the said protection. He submitted a proposal from the Waterous Engine Company to supply a 5 H.P. gasoline engine, rotary pump, rubber hose and a certain length of hose as the plant best adapted to supply the fire protection required. When I enquired of the Company's Agent here what such plant would cost delivered at Macleod, he replied $676.00. As a building would require to be erected for the plant, and the latter placed in position for operation, bringing the whole cost probably up to nearly $1000.00, I declined to entertain the proposal.

As the school buildings are not high I suggested to the Agent that an elevated tank to be kept filled by the windmill pump, with a hose to reach the several buildings, might supply sufficient water to extinguish at once any fire that would be likely to start in the buildings, but they appear to have considered the suggestion impracticable, and no other proposal has been submitted to me.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the concluding paragraph of Rev. Mr Owen's letter of the 27th ultimo, on the subject of the grant for the Church of England boarding school on the Blood Reserve, I beg to say that although a grant was at one time allowed for 80 pupils, it was reduced after due consideration to 50, as up to the time of the reduction, which was made in the estimates for 1900-01, the average attendance had never exceeded 47. The Annual Report for 1902 shows that with an enrollment of 56 the average attendance was only 48.

Mr Owen is correct in stating that the Agent and Commissioner have recommended that he be allowed the grant for 60 pupils, but the number has been reduced here by direction of the Minister, who has, I am informed by Mr Scott, made the same provision in the estimates for next year, although 60 pupils were again asked for.

This school was started by the Church Missionary Society in 1892, when the pupils were given rations and clothing. In 1894 20 pupils were provided for at $72; in 1895 the number was raised to 40; in 1896 to 80 and reduced to 50 in 1900.

Out of the 23 boarding schools in the North West Territories, Duck Lake Emmanuel College and St Albert are the only ones with a larger provision. Duck Lake has 100 pupils at $100 per capita, and is considered...
considered to be quite on a par with any of the industrial schools. Emmanuel College has provision for 52, of whom 20 are paid for at $100 each with the view of fitting them for Indian teachers. St Albert is allowed a grant of $72 for each of 80 pupils, which it has had for the last eight years.

The Roman Catholics have a boarding school on the Blood reserve with a grant for only 25 pupils and I fail to see that Mr Owen has any just cause of complaint. He receives liberal support from the Church Missionary Society and if he wishes to keep expenses down he should confine himself to the number of pupils authorized.

In addition to the grant allowed this school, the Department has paid over $2000 as a contribution to the buildings, which are not on the reserve and are not its property.

Report on attempted burning of Girls' Home.

On the evening of Thursday the 20th day of October an attempt was made by the girls to burn their home, but the fire was happily discouraged before any serious damage was done.

The cause which led to the fire—There seems to have been some dissatisfaction among the bigger girls because it had been found imperative to make certain changes which tended to improve the discipline and thus place the general tone of the school on a sounder footing; hence the girls were allowed less freedom than formerly and they retaliated in the manner mentioned above.

How the plan originated—At first the matter was treated as a joke, and tho' often spoken of many of the girls never dreamed that it would be really put into effect.

How the plan was effected—On the Monday preceding the Thursday—the night of the fire—one of the girls, Lucy Welch, dared the other girls to say that she wouldn't light the fire. The girls laughed at her and taunted her, till she resolved that nothing would stop her from carrying out her intention viz.: to set fire to the building. When her companions found that she had really made up her mind, they assisted her. Lucy Welch proposed to fit the house on Monday evening, but on ordinary circumstances they could not do it, however the girls decided to make preparations on Wednesday and Thursday would find everything ready. Accordingly rags were saturated with coal oil and secreted. On Thursday morning some of the better disposed were inclined to waver and confess, but the stronger willed persuaded and prevailed. On the afternoon of this day the rags which had been prepared, together with matches, were laid under the sill of the west window ready to be fired as soon as it was dark enough to escape possible detection, but as no opportunity was afforded before prayers it was decided to see what could be done after.

The usual hour for prayers is at 7 p.m., but as Mr. Gale did not return to the school till 7.15 p.m., prayers were delayed in consequence and the prayer bell did not ring before 7.45. The girls paraded to end from school. When they arrived back it must have been 8 p.m.

The lighting—Two girls—Lucy Gladstone and Norah Eagle Speaker—asked permission to go outside and leave was given them, the matron waiting at the door for their return. In the meanwhile Lucy Welch got hold of the kitchen window fastened by Essie Macaslin, the girl who laid the fire! lit the fire and returned without detection. The two girls who were out saw the fire but made no effort to extinguish it, nor did they give the alarm.

How the fire progressed—Mrs. Gale who was living in the girls' home at that time was putting her two children to bed in the east wing and her husband remarked when he went into his room that there was much smoke in the house. He went down to the kitchen to find it full of smoke altho' 4 girls were working there. He remarked about the smoke but thinking that the stoves were smoking thought little more about it and went back to his wife's room. About 15 minutes after the little girls who were in their dormitory between the two wings found it impossible to stay in their room. The girls downstairs began to speak of the thick smoke and Mr. Gale went down to find the whole house filled.
He unlocked the kitchen door and walked outside—what was his surprise to see a sheet of flame shooting up the outer wall. Procuring water he quenched the flames and calling for assistance the fire was soon extinguished.

It was extremely fortunate that there was no wind, for nothing could have saved the building from being partly destroyed at least.

The fire was discovered—the fire was discovered at 8.30 p.m. so that it must have been smouldering for some twenty minutes or more before it flamed.

Pupils professed ignorance of the origin of fire—A close watch was kept all night as it was feared that the building might again be set on fire. In the morning when all the pupils were assembled they were questioned with regard to the fire, but they professed ignorance of the whole affair.

Corpl. Armer informed—The principal wrote to Corpl. Armer of Stand Off about the matter, but before he arrived the girls confessed their diabolical act. When Mr. Armer came he was informed of the case and he referred it to his superior officers at Macleod. A commission of enquiry was held at the school by Inspector Walke and evidence taken.

Present situation—There the matter rests & presumably for the present.

(signed) G. Edward Gale

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 11th ultimo, I have the honor to say that I am informed by the Principal of the C. E. Boarding School, to which the Medical Officer referred, that they have a good garden this year.

While the lack of garden supplies last winter was undoubtedly bad for the children it might be as well to note that other existing conditions contribute to the ill health of these pupils.

The admission of tuberculous children as pupils to the boarding schools should be discontinued. To this end the Medical Officer should be instructed to make a real examination of each entering pupil instead of founding Certificates of Health upon superficial observation.

The pupils should get more open air or outdoor recreation than at present and instead of being kept out of bed until late at night by night school and band practice they should retire at 8 p.m. during winter and 9 o'clock in summertime with nothing but recreation between evening prayers at 6.30 and bedtime.

Last winter the authorities controlling the finances of this school, who I understand live at Calgary, did not provide nearly enough fuel for the normal ordinary and necessary heating of the buildings, the result being a scandalous amount of suffering from cold by pupils and staff.

Dear Mr. Scott,

For some time past I have been considering the possibility of writing you on the following subject, but have been waiting to see if the prevailing conditions on the Reserve were in any wise better, but at the present there is no brighter outlook, hence my letter.

In view of the fact that the Blood Reserve is the largest in the Provinces I regret to say that the school attendance is far from being in proportion, approximately there are 150 children on the Reserve who are receiving no kind of education, and no effort on the part of the parents is being made to take advantage of the present educational facilities, no matter what pleas are put forward or what encouragement is given, the same refusal is met with at all points, that the parents either flatly refuse to put their children in school, or they wish to keep them out in order to gain for themselves pecuniary assistance, the girls for the marriage market, and the boys to work on the surrounding farms and ranches. At the present time I have 39 pupils enrolled and have the best of accommodation for 50, I have several more signed in, but it is a difficult thing to get them even though they are signed in. When we returned in the afternoon we visited the C.E. School and hospital. The little hospital, the school house and the dormitory for the boys which I understand was constructed by your order are the only things which I can praise in the whole institution. They are all that could be desired but that old building which is used for a kitchen, dining-room and girl's quarters are most unfit for habitation. The place is dirty, the children are healthy enough looking but they don't look tidy or well clad; though there is a good deal of excuse for the officials, having to live in such a poor building. The only way in which I can see to remedy the condition is to have a new school and when the two years of this church management is over I hope it can be accomplished and that it be built by the Government on the Reserve and run under some supervision of the Government. I believe this school is also in great danger from the spring flood.

I cannot see how it is but the R.C. people have the C.E. people beaten forty ways in the management of their institutions. The Principal of the C.E. school seems all right, active and energetic and they tell me the young lady who is teacher is a good instructor, but there seems to be something wrong about the housekeeping. Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd inst., dealing with the report of Dr. Grain, and hereby beg to tender a most emphatic protest against same.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

You will see from the letter hereunder from the Rev. Mr. Middleton, Principal of the Blood (C.E.) Boarding School, that he takes exception to Dr. Grain's report on this institution. He expresses himself in rather strong language as regards the conditions Dr. Grain found at the school at the time of his visit. That the Blood Indians may get the most advantage of an English education, that the separate boarding schools be filled to their full capacity; I must request that parents having children of school age shall enroll them in whichever of the three schools recruiting from the Blood Indians, the parents to make their own choice of school.

Sir,— Since both Boarding Schools are having their annual vacation during the past and the present month up to the 15th inst., there is not much to report re school matters.

I am enclosing you copies of circulars sent out from this office re Indian education. The two schools on the reserve have now the largest attendance in their history, one has an enrollment of 55 one 52. I have now 5 applications taken by myself which will be sent the respective principals upon their return to the schools from vacation. I will experience no difficulty in getting recruits for the schools the only difficulty will be that the schools will not accommodate all of the children that can be placed in them. I am going to do my part at least in making this year coming the banner year for the Indian schools here. Our difficulty from this time on will be to receive accommodation for the children. But I do hope that the standard of efficiency can be generally raised thru the introduction of increased numbers.

I have experience some difficulty here thru the truancy of children from the schools. I had exhausted patience in talking to the parents, finally finding a parent who deliberately took his child from school without leave. I sent him to jail for ten days. This stopped the truancy instantly. Also some difficulty has been experienced thru the elaborated promises made some years ago by principals to parents. The Principal and agent having changed the Indian may now be right, but as there is no record at this
office in reference to it, I am unable to do anything.

Also it has been a practice since ever there was a boarding school on this reserve to literally buy children into school. One principal here no longer than last spring told me that he is always asked by the parent to give him $5.00 for the child. He said that he would loan the parent $5.00 expecting never to have it returned and it never is. Also it has been a practice to hold children in many cases after the age of 16 years.

The general conception of the Indian is that he is doing the Government and the Principal a favor by placing a child in school.

I wish to altogether change these ideas and make the schools take a different standing, that of being here for the benefit of the Indians alone.

I am firm in the opinion that the schools will do more than any other institution will work out the problems that are to be solved, on the Blood reserve.

I would be pleased to have you inform me if any change in my proposed program is desired by the Department, if it is the pleasure of the Department that I add anything to the above mentioned program.

I have the Honor to be

Sir

SMART WORK IS DONE BY INDIAN CORPS OF CADETS

Blood and Peigan Boys Rank Among First Six in Military Arts

(Special Dispatch To The Herald)

MACLEOD, July 15—The annual field day and sports meet of the Blood Indians and Peigans from their cadet corps were held Wednesday at Macleod. The inspection of the cadets was held in the morning before the field day. Major Miller who complimented the officers and cadets of both corps for their achievements. The Indian cadets, under the command of Capt. McMillan went through all their drills and manoeuvres in perfect order and smartness which brought forth favorable comments from the large number of people who were witnessing the inspection.

Major Miller addressed the cadets and said he was more than surprised to him, and he was very pleased with them and the brothers of the fine inspection which he had made that day. He told them to carry on with the good work. Very often there were things that were not pleasant to perform, but they were only obstructions to be overcome, an introduction to duty and also help to train them for their future life.

Sergeants Complimented

He complimented Sergeants Middleton and Sergeants Herron and Penner on the manner in which they gave their instruction, and he also told the boys that to be successful in life they could not help but get on and that their work would be well received by their officers for the many hours spent on their instruction.

Major Miller informed the corps that he was so pleased with the performance of the cadets that he had presented a silver medal to be given every year to the cadet corps who won the most prizes in the sports. After the inspection the games were held and then the very keen military show was given by both of the Blood Indians and the boys of the Peigans. The Blood Indians showed their prowess over the Peigans. Nelson Rabbitt, of the Blood school won not only Major Miller's medal, but also a handsome cup presented by the parents of the pupil of either school who won the inspection competition.

Arthur Healy, another Blood boy, was awarded the Meritorious Prize, which is given annually for the boy who shows the greatest amount of merit marks during the year. The prizes were graciously presented by Mr. J. Herron, who made a very nice address, commending his boys staff for their excellent work.

Special attention should be drawn to the Indian cadet corps of the Peigan school, which has been instructed by Capt. McMillan and Capt. J. Herron, and great credit is due to these officers for the splendid manner in which the signalling was done. The signalmen's work was shown in the school and great interest was taken by the very large number of people who were present.

Deserves Commendation

Rev. Mr. H. J. Smith, principal of both schools, deserves the highest commendation for the way in which he has brought the pupils of the two schools to such a high state of efficiency. He has given them a great number of years in Indian service and, being of the Peigan type, has been able to introduce into the school the best traditions, one of which is his cadet corps. It will be remembered that Lieut. Albert Mountain Horse who enlisted in the army in 1914 and was killed about 12 months after, received his training from Capt. Middleton. He has been instructor for years and the Indians have responded during which time they won several cups at various fairs both for sports and for races. More than seven Blood Indians who were overseas in the war and whose supreme sacrifice was also attested by the Blood Indians' cadet corps, which speaks very highly for the work done by Capt. Middleton during the time he has been principal of the school.

LOCAL INDIANS AWARDED HIGH MILITARY HONOR

The R. B. Bennett Shield presented to the Champion Cadet Corps of Alberta has been awarded to St. Paul's Indian Cadet Corps of the Blood Reserve. This champion cadet corps was organized by Capt. (Rev.) S. Middleton in 1912 and has on many occasions won distinction, especially so at the Calgary Camps in 1912 and 1913, where they brought back to Macleod several trophies. The Shield was won by R. B. Bennett, Esq., Mayor of Calgary, is awarded to the Cadet Corps in Alberta gaining the highest honors, and as there were over seventy-five cadet corps in the province competing for this shield, the St. Paul's Boys are to be congratulated on their wonderful success.

The inspection of the Cadets was held June 7th of this year, when Maj.-Gen. Miller, the inspecting Officer commented the Indians on their drill and military maneuvers in the highest terms. The late Lieut. Albert Mountain Horse who died on his return from overseas, was a former cadet of the St. Paul's Corps, and several other Indians who enlisted from the Blood Reserve received their first taste of military training from the St. Paul's Indian Cadet Corps. Every member of the Corps is a full blooded Indian and speaks highly of the training he received from Capt. Middleton and Lieutenants Pearce and Herron, who have worked so hard with the boys to bring them up to present a corps of perfection in military tactics. Special mention should be made to the signalling corps of the Indian Boys, who under the able instruction of Lieut. Herron, gained first class honors in this work.

"WHEREAS, we the assembled members of St. Paul's Old Boys Association, have read with interest the reply from Mr. D.C. Scott, Dep. Sup. General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, to the Resolution passed at our last Re-Union—Jan. 27-28th 1920—that certain steps are being taken to re-organise the Indian educational system of Southern Alberta; and

"WHEREAS we humbly beg for more information as to whether definite action has been taken, and if so, in what manner;

THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED that we beg to recommend the erection of a new industrial school, of an advanced type, be proceeded with at the earliest possible date; that a site for same be procured in or near the City of Lethbridge; that no Day Schools be erected on the Blood Reserve; and be it further—

"RESOLVED that a copy of this Resolution be forwarded to the Executive Committee of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, Toronto, beseeching their recommendation of same to the Indian Department, Ottawa, and also a copy be forwarded to the Deputy-Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa."

Dear Mr. Scott,-

I beg to advise you that I visited the Blood Reserve on the 8th, 9th, 10th and 11th of this month, and while there I made an inspection of both Boarding Schools, with a view of ascertaining the immediate requirements in the way of repairs to the buildings. I have made a separate report on the requirements and expect that you will have it before you by this time, and will be able to authorize the necessary expenditure.

I was greatly pleased with the manner in which the children at both institutions were looked after. They were well clothed and well fed and comparing these institutions with other schools which I visited, I would say that they were quite up to standard.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing a copy of a communication from Rev. Mr. Middleton, relative to a continued grant for graduate pupils taking advanced work at public schools or colleges.

In reply I beg to state that this Department makes such arrangements only when the pupil continues in residence at the Indian boarding school and attends a high school or college in the immediate vicinity. Certain funds are provided, however, for assistance to promising Indian boys or girls who have been in attendance at Indian schools. Before arranging for the tuition of an Indian boy or girl, we must be satisfied that the pupil in question is of the proper type and will make a bona fide effort, and that careful supervision will be offered by the Department or Church representatives.

If there is a promising boy, who has graduated from the Blood C. of E. Boarding School, in attendance at the Agricultural College at Claresholm, Alta., Rev. Mr. Middleton should make a request to your office, giving the facts of the case. A proper home must be provided for the boy, and his activities must be supervised by some responsible party. The Agricultural College Registrar should make a report regarding the boy's progress and his ability to satisfactorily complete the course.

Extract from Inspector's Report on the Blood C. E.
Boarding School, October 6, 1922.

Basing my opinion on what was seen here, I would grade Mrs. Robertson as a teacher among the lowest of the low. "She is without question the most unobservant teacher I have ever seen in a classroom. Most teachers will make some attempt at least to keep the pupils who are left at their seats employed at work of some kind. But when Mrs. Robertson dismisses a class she is done with it. The pupils take their seats and with nothing in the world to do they sit there gazing around the room and waiting for long minutes to drag by; when recess or noon will bring a welcome break in the dull, dead monotony of the classroom. Fully ninety per cent of the time of the pupils is spent in this empty, listless, soul-paralyzing sort of existence."

Nor is her instruction much better. For example, in a spelling lesson taught to Grade II, several words were written on the board and the pupils were asked to spell. The pupils spelled each word a number of times in concert, some looking at the word in the list, and others looking in all directions, were merely keeping company with the rest. Then they were required to spell the words individually and orally without looking at the board. One pupil spelled "birds" brides. The teacher repeated the error "b-r-i-d-s" somewhat sarcastically and then said, "You spell it." The pupil spelled "b-r-i-d-s". Then to another she said "You spell it." The pupil spelled "b-r-i-d-s". Then the teacher went to the board and wrote down, spelling as she did so "brides" and said is that the way to spell birds. Look at it.

Comment is needless. Suffice it to say that this is typical of her teaching.

J. H. Hutchison,
Insp.
Ottawa, March 26th, 1923.

Rev. Sir:

The report of the Public School Inspector, who visited the Blind C. of E. Boarding School in October last, has just been received. The Inspector has drawn particular attention to the teaching methods employed by Mrs. Jean Robertson, and has graded her work as being of a very low order. He states as follows:

"She is without question the most unobservant teacher I have ever seen in a classroom. Most teachers will make some attempt at least to keep the pupils who are left at their desks employed at work of some kind. But when Mrs. Robertson dismisses a class she is done with it. The pupils take their seats and with nothing in the world to do they sit there gazing around the room and waiting for long minutes to drag by, when recess or noon will bring a welcome break in the dull, despondency of the classroom. Fully ninety per cent of the time of the pupils is spent in this empty, listless, soul-paralyzing sort of existence."

He further states that her method of instruction is very inferior, some examples of which he has given.

This matter is being drawn to your attention with a view to Mrs. Robertson still employed as teacher, to a change being made. You will observe from the Inspector's remarks as mentioned above that the pupils are only wasting their time in the classroom. Under the charge of a properly qualified and competent teacher there is no reason why the children of this school should not make good progress in their studies.

We hope that this matter will receive your earnest attention and that a change in the teaching conditions at this school will result.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

NEW INDIAN SCHOOL NEAR CARDSTON COST $160,000

EIGHT NEW BUILDINGS ACCOMMODATE AGENCY ON THE BLOOD RESERVE

(By D. O. WIGHT)

Seven months ago, the Clayton Company of Winnipeg, contractors, began work on the New St. Paul's Industrial School, just four miles from Cardston. Today the school stands completed ready to receive by name 125 Indian boys and girls of the Blood Reserve. This splendid building is to take the place of the old school at the Lower Agency, and has been built as a part of the plan to make the Indians self-supporting, not only in their agency and their farming interests near Cardston. There is also a school at Stand-Off, which is being controlled by the Catholic Church. The plans are now ready for the construction of a new school at the mission to the Anglicans near Cardston. When this second school is completed, opportunity will be furnished for every Indian child of the Reserve to receive an education.

The St. Paul's school near Cardston is the best one of its kind in Canada. It is made of brick, faced with stone. The cost of the building alone runs over $135,000, while the furnishings and equipment will mount up to $25,000 more. It has four class rooms, a gymnasium, a library, the regular curriculum of the schools of Alberta, and in addition, rooms are provided for instruction in Carpentry and Blacksmithing for the boys, and Domestic Science and Art for the girls. Instruction will all be given in English and farming. Husbandry. In fact the school is an industrial school of the very latest type. Rev. S. Middleton will be in charge, the other members of the staff have not been appointed as yet.

A Modern Building

The building itself is thoroughly modern in every respect. Hot and cold water is provided throughout. It is supplied with an electric plant which gives light and power. There is a full size gymnasium, a shower bath. The waterworks is a gravity system, supplied by a deep, drilled well, the water from which is pumped to a 20,000 gallon tank, which stands 90 feet high from the ground, and is located on the highest point of the school. In addition to all these modern features, the dormitories, of which there are four, are finished in the best style of the day and provided with hot water. The staff are also kindly provided for, while the principal has a separate wing of the building for his residence. In fact every accommodation is provided for both pupils and staff. The building, without question, a superior one of its kind in the whole Dominion.

New Agency Building

In addition to this excellent industrial school, the Indian department has constructed eight new buildings to accommodate the Indian Agency of the Blood Reserve. These buildings are also placed near Cardston, about five miles from the school and the new agency. They have cost in the neighborhood of $40,000. They are constructed of lumber, and finished with hardwood floor and perfect in every detail of their appointments, being fully equipped buildings. The central square contains the agency offices. His residence stands just to the north of the office, and it is the largest building there. Mr. J. F. Faunt is the agent, the man upon whom the task of educating the Indians is chiefly reposed. Visit him in his home and find him cordial, resourceful, and thoughtful in his office, and ever enthusiastic for the welfare of the Indians. He has grouped the other officials, who in his own residence, where Mr. A. Macdonald, the clerk, and many more, by the farm instructor's home, Mr. Thaddess Gregson, while the interpreter's house is situated just to the west and north. The other buildings are machine shop, blacksmith shop, stable and barns, etc., all planned so that when the tree planting plans are been warned not to indulge in luxuries." The other residents individual patents to their land. This will come later. At present, they do have, however, full ownership of their cattle, horses, machinery and the produce from their farms.

One Indian's Big Crop

That they are taking advantage of this is shown by the one case of Joe Butten, who this year harvested on his own farm 640 bushels of wheat and 1,500 bushels of oats. But he is only one of 130 other Indians who are operating farms on their own account. Every year more Indians are applying for this privilege, and Mr. Faunt now has waiting list of 40 Indians anxious to get the necessary equipment to start farming. This equipment will be charged against their account, and a he reaps his harvests the returns will be applied to paying for it. Thus it is seen that the first one in which the Indians are wholly out of debt.

Individual Initiative

In the system thus evolved, everything depends upon the attitude and individual industry of the Indian as to the progress he makes and the returns he reaps. If he wishes to go ahead, he will go ahead. If he does not, he cannot. But every head of a family is now looking forward to the possession of a half section of land that he can operate for his own profit. The 130 who are doing so have already demonstrated that they can do it, and the whole tribe will be a little nation of expert farmers and ranchers. The schools are helping them materially with their knowledge, but the real secret lies in the care and judicious handling of the Indians by the agent and his staff of farm instructors. For instance, the Indians usually incline toward use of high powered machinery, the big tractor and plow outfits for the breaking of their land, but the wisdom of Mr. Faunt in insisting that each man buy his own broken land has helped the industry of the Indians and their attitude toward their work. Also, if allowed they would all have automobiles, but here again wisdom and experience teaches that barns must be built in order to keep rain, wind, rain, etc., that cars usually unfit the owner to go quietly on with his farming operations. The Indians, however, after the first impulse for these novelties pass away, are ready enough to buy them and are buying them now. With the erection of "their own homes, they being given almost complete freedom in the choice of plans, and location. Of course a more or less common or unfamiliar style may be adopted by the Indians, but the individuality of the Indian can exert itself in the style and design of the building and the furnishings that go in it. Several of such buildings have been completed and the future will see them rapidly increasing in numbers.

Thus the construction of the new St. Paul's Industrial school, near Cardston marks but the beginning of a rapid advance in the welfare of the Indians.
It has four class-rooms for general instruction in the regular subjects of the old Albermarle school, and the industrial rooms are provided for instruction in Carpentry and Blacksmithing for the boys, and Domestic Science and Art for the girls.

Instruction will also be given in Agriculture and Animal Husbandry. In fact the school is an Industrial school of the very latest type. Rev. G. Middleton will be in charge; the other members of the staff have not been appointed as yet.

A Modern Building

The building itself is thoroughly modern in every respect. Hot and cold water is provided throughout. It is supplied with an electric plant which furnishes light and power. There is a fully equipped gymnasium and shower baths. The waterworks is a gravity system, supplied by a deep, drilled well, the water from which is pumped into the galvanized tanks located 90 feet from the building and is 10 feet higher than the roof of the school. In addition to all these modern features, the dormitories, of which there are four, are finished in the best hardwood and fitted with every comfort. The staff are also similarly provided for, while the principal has a separate wing of the building for his residence. In fact every accommodation is provided for both pupils and staff, making the building, without question, a superior one of its kind in the whole Dominion.

Indian Agency Building

In addition to the excellent Industrial school, the Indian department has constructed eight new buildings to accommodate the Indian Agency of the Blood Reserve. These buildings are also placed near Cardston, about five miles from the school and some seven miles from the town. They have been built at a cost of $40,000. They are constructed of lumber, and finished with hardwood floor and perfect in every detail of their appointments, being fully modern buildings. The central square building is the agent's office. His residence stands just to the north of the office, and it is the largest building on the reserve. Mr. A. Faunt is the agent, who is in charge of the task of educating the Indians in citizenship, rests, etc. Visit him at any time and you find him courteous, considerate, and thoughtful in his office, and ever enthusiastic for the welfare of the Indians. Arranged around him are the other officials, each in his own residence. There is Mr. A. McMillan, the clerk, just east, and nearby is the farm instructor's house, Mr. Thaddeus Gregson, while the interpreter's house is situated just to the west and north. The other buildings are modern, splendidly built, and when stable are barns. These buildings are all well placed so that, when the tree planting plans are completed, they will present a most attractive appearance, and be one of the beauty spots of the whole Reserve.

But why all this expense and attention to the Blood Indians? What are they doing to merit the Government expenditures in this lavish fashion? In answer, let us enumerate some of the actual performances of these Indians during the last five years, since the new policy was inaugurated.

Take On Modern Ways

Five years ago, there was little or no land under cultivation on the big Reserve, the Indians, living a camp life, herding their cattle and horses, and depending on the government for food to supply the deficiencies of their labor. They were still draped in their old robes, and appeared as a most shiftless population. To-day they appear, at least the majority of the younger ones and the number is constantly increasing, as well dressed as any whites, wearing the latest fashions in blankets and shawls, and except some of the older Indians, whose ways are set, they speak English fluently, and are keen buyers at the stores of Cardston. To this last point, every merchant in Cardston can testify. They buy the best and newest fashions, too, to satisfy, and that merchant who tries to fool them in their goods has a slim chance for a repetition of the trick.

To illustrate their modern aspect, two Indian women were observed in Laidlaw's Ltd., the other day, and one was heard to say: "Don't buy that, you know you have..."

Dear Mr. Scott:

Your letter, dated April 2nd, serial number 103-1-1, in reply to our request for an increase in the rate of the per capita grant for the new St. Paul's Indian Residential School, was submitted to our Executive Committee at its meeting yesterday. The Committee instructed me to emphasize the following points:

(1) That the M.S.C.C., under its current sanctioned estimates for Indian Residential Schools, without provision for the increased cost of the New St. Paul's School, is under an obligation to provide, in cash, or in the form of cash values of clothing and supplies, a total sum for the year of £8,570.00. It follows, therefore, that any re-classification of the schools which may be made cannot result, if the Church of England is to carry on, in any lessening of the amounts now payable, in the form of per capita grants, to the various schools administered by this Society. The revision, if made on general lines, must, of necessity, be in an upward rather than in a downward direction.

(2) The new St. Paul's School and the new Methodist School near Edmonton are, as far as our information goes, similar in all respects connected with the cost of administration. There exists, therefore, in our opinion, no possible ground on which these schools could be placed, under any re-classification, in different groups. We feel, further, that we have, in consequence, a very strong claim in repeating our request that the new St. Paul's School should be placed at once on the same scale of per capita grants as that being allowed for the new Methodist School at Edmonton; the scale in question being, we understand, the same as that now being paid to the Elkhorn Institution.

I am very pleased to know that the enrollment of the School has been increased to 125; it will, however, be probably some time before this total is reached, and in any case the additional pupils mean a decided increase under all the headings of the estimates adopted.

May I express the hope, therefore, that this important matter will receive your early and favourable re-consideration.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

General Secretary

EDITORIAL

"In the old days the Indian centered everything upon his religion. He thirsted for a knowledge of God, though at times he but faintly apprehended Him. His religion entered into every phase of his life—his planting, harvesting, feasting, recreation, hunting, warfare—in short, all his interests were intimately bound up with religion. Therefore the Indian of the old trail was strong and steadfast in his adherence to old ways and in his loyalty to his ancient gods. The very perils and hardships of the trail and warpath called in him a longing for close relationship with the unseen world of mystery round about him. So he established such relationships as he could, through fastings and visions, sacrifices and immolations.

But the Indian of the old trail has passed on, leaving behind chiefly such vestiges of the old regime as war paint and feathers, bow and arrow, blanket and mocassin. The Indian youth of today is on a new trail. As with every new trail he is facing this dim and uncertain at times. The transition from the old to the new is often fraught with difficulties and perils. He has cast upon the higher plane of knowledge and does not turn back to the old trails. The road of the old is being retained in the new. It is recognised that in the Indian's tribal lore, his art, handicraft, and some of his ceremonies were cultural elements of value which should be retained and encouraged; accordingly, musical and religious organisations, athletic clubs, physical culture and art classes are promoted, to which the Indian temperament naturally inclines. It is also the aim of those who are that is best in the Indian folk tales and their stories as a race heritage to be handed down as an inspiration for racial progress and development.

St. Paul's, as a School with ideals, endeavours to furnish avenues of expression for all these activities, especially where the appeal is from a religious and instructive motive. The residential school system has demonstrated very effectively its value and adaptation to the needs of the Blood Indian boys and girls. Its results are unmistakable. It has enabled the Indian to make..."
greater progress than any other primitive race in a like period of which there is any written record. Most of its body of workers put into their labours a lifting spirit of altruism above value.

Under the service of this educational system the Indian is casting away the things which typify his old barbarous life. He has gone from the mocassin to the shoe, from the blanket to the coat, from feathers to the hat. He has exchanged the bow for the plough, and turned from the buffalo to the white man's herd and flock. He is forsaking a weird and uncertain conception of divinity for the Church and organised Christian benevolence of his white brother. He is lifting drudgery and burdens from the women of his race and granting them lighter ideals of home-keeping and womanhood. Generally speaking, the graduates of the School are the transforming influences of the Reserve life today.

If we give the unenlightened Indian property, he may or may not wisely use of it. If we give him education, he has a working capital, of which he cannot be deprived, that should make him and keep him both progressive and solvent. The oft-repeated saying "in the Indian youth lies the hope of his race" should here find its fulfillment. Indeed, one may have faith to believe that here, if anywhere, the Indian youth will respond by "outward and visible signs" to the "inward and spiritual grace" bestowed upon him through increasing knowledge to the word of the Great Spirit.

At the parting of the ways, the young Indian says with Tennyson:

"Come my friends,
'Tis not too late to seek a newer world,
Push off, and sitting well in order sail
The samplings furrows; for my purpose holds
To sail beyond the sunset, and the baths
Of all the Western stars until I die."

Official Opening of St. Paul's School

July 21-22, 1925

(Reprint from Calgary Herald, June 26, 1925)

An interesting ceremony took place at the Blood Reserve on Monday, June 22, when the new St. Paul's Indian residential school was formally opened by Right Reverend the Bishop of Calgary.

More than 400 visitors were present, both Indians and whites, including many who had motored from Edmonton and Macleod, showing their keen public interest in this flourishing and progressive institution.

Some of the old-time Indians were present, the men with blankets, and hats decked with feathers; the women in brightly-colored shawls and kerchiefs, in marked contrast to the serge or tweed suits and stylish hats and dresses of the younger generation. The bright sunlight accentuated chatter of the assembled crowd added to the impressiveness of a memorable scene.

The proceedings, which took place in front of the main building shortly after 2:30 p.m., started with the performance of exercises by the pupils, the girls marching to one side and the boys to the other side of the steps, to the accompaniment of music provided by the school brass band.

The singing and physical exercises were excellent, and showed a great deal of care and thorough training. A piano solo by Josephine Davies, piano first by two boys, and concertina by two members of the band were novel features of the entertainment, as it is believed to be the first time in Alberta that an Indian child has played the piano at a public performance.

The band presented a smart appearance in their navy and red uniforms, and although they have had only a few months' instruction, accomplished several of their exercises very well, and with excellent time.

Olive Davies as the Indian queen, with her two modern slaves, made an attractive picture.

Prizes Presented

Following the programme given by the children, His Lordship, Bishop Pinkham, presented the prizes, consisting of five awards to each of the recipients. Josephine Davies, Miss Montana Horse received the prizes offered by the L. O. D. E. for the best essays on the Blood Indians.

Bishop Speaks

At the conclusion of the prize-giving, the aged Bishop, whose voice was full of emotion, addressed the assembly. He recalled the early days of his episcopate, when he made his first visit to the reserve, when there were but one day schools for Indians, and the Indians were practically all heathen. He eulogized the work of the men and women who had so patiently labored for the betterment of the Indians, and acknowledged with deep admiration the manner in which the Indian department of the government had met the present educational requirements by the creation of "this splendid building."

He then briefly congratulated Rev. Canon Middleton on the progress the school had made during the fifteen years it had been under his charge, and hoped to be spared a few years longer to administer the work of the district, and to see the new school fully justify its erection.

Address by Archdeacon

The Ven. Archdeacon Timms then followed with a short address, taking the letter "P" of "St. Paul's" as his text, and speaking briefly on the three points of patience, progress and possibilities.

Dedication Ceremony

He reminded the Indians of the patience required to overcome the difficulties and the almost insuperable difficulties against which they struggled. There were no fences, farms nor railways. The Indians had no idea what education meant, and thought that the reading, writing and arithmetic taught to their children were different forms of prayer.

Next, he spoke of the progress they had made, with special reference to the prizes won by the pupils at the Calgary exhibition, and the efficiency shown by the cadet corps.

Lastly, he spoke of the possibilities of the future. He looked forward to the time when the wards of the government would be free citizens. A great deal depended on the parents in the example they set their children. They must therefore be educated, but they must remember that civilization without Christianity must be a failure, he said.

Judge Jackson Speaks

Then in a short speech, Judge Jackson, of Lethbridge, contrasted the Indians of long ago with those of today, commenting on the pro...
gives that had been made, and saying that education was to be the salvation of the Indian. Mayor Macleod, of Macleod, opened the high school board, and in the old and in the present schools. He congratulated the staff and pupils on their new and commodious quarters, and the change from the ramshackle buildings, where astronomy could be studied through the roof and the sunlight through the floor.

The last speaker was Mayor Caldwell of Carleton. He was proud of having the new school in the vicinity. He had watched the Indians grow and prosper for many years, and considered the school was a fine educational institution.

Dedication Ceremony

As the conclusion of the speeches, the clergy present retired in order for the ceremony of dedication, and during the interval the visitors were entertained with selections by the band. Then the procession of clergy issued from the south door, preceded by the Bishop and Mrs. Thomas, Rev. G. Johnson, rural dean of Lethbridge; Rev. W. J. Merrick, rural dean of Macleod; Rev. Canon Middleton, Very Rev. deacon Thomas, and Rt. Rev. Bishop Fulton. They took their places on the steps of the main entrance, and after "O God Our Help in Ages Past" had been sung, His Lordship delivered the dedicatory address. After the school opened its doors, nothing that was said by his pastoral staff upon the doors, he demanded admittance. At once the doors were flung open by an Indian boy and girl, and the Bishop, followed by the clergy, entered.

The building was then thrown open to the visitors, and they were received by the Bishop, Mrs. Middleton and Miss Thomas. Groups of visitors were shown over the school, and many expressions of surprise and approbation were heard as the parties progressed through the institution. Later refreshments were served in the dining-room.

Location of School

The new St. Paul's school is situated four miles north-west of Macleod, west of Edmonton. It has large sections of splendid farming land, which are to be worked by the pupils. The school grounds include the magnificent view of the mountains, with Chief Mountain very prominent. The building itself is a magnificent structure of red brick, and is splendidly fitted out throughout.

The chapel, placed opposite the front door, at once acquaints the visitor with the fundamental object of the institution, namely, the illumination and elevation of the children of the prairies under the influence of the Christian religion.

The whole atmosphere and tone of the place bear eloquent witness to this fact, and the prayers at the morning and evening prayers held daily in the chapel, lead to love and reverence the services of the church. The Bishop dedicated the chapel in a short service on Sunday afternoon, just previous to a con-

dition.

Capacity, 125 Pupils

St. Paul's is now capable of accommodating 125 pupils, of whom 92 are in residence. It is expected that after the summer holidays the school will be filled to capacity.

Credit Due Canon Middleton

To Rev. Canon Middleton, for fifteen years principal of the school, St. Paul's owes much for his tireless energy, his optimism and ambition. It is very greatly owing to him and the dedication with which he developed the school opening its doors, nothing that times with his pastoral staff upon the doors, he demanded admittance. At once the doors were flung open and spiritually has taken place. The loyalty of ex-pupils to the old school, and their well- ingess to give their best understandings. Their power, is a striking witness to the lasting influence of St. Paul's upon those who pass through it.

There is a splendid school cadet corps organized in 1911, which has a most creditable record. They formed the guard of honour for his excellency the Duke of Connaught when governor-general in 1912. They presented the king's colors to the school. The corps has been the winner of four silver cups, three championship cups and three silver medals.

Inspected by Prince

It was inspected by His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, in 1910 and again in the following year won the R. B. Bennett shield in open competition with the white cadet corps of Alberta. The latest addition to the list of honors is the winning of the Army Cadet Corps medal to the best school training corps of 16 members in the province, outside of Lethbridge, Calgary and Edmonton. There has also been for the last year, a cadet corps of 30 pupils, who meet each week for drill, games, and other forms of guide training, and who will no doubt make for themselves a record as excellent as that of their brothers in the cadet corps.

St. Paul's has a very full curriculum, the pupils being given instruction in all kinds of practical work, besides the regular lessons in the classrooms.

Now St. Paul's starts on a new stage in its history. In the words of the principal: "It is the aim of St. Paul's to train the Blood Indian boys and girls to take upon themselves the duties and responsibilities of Christian citizenship." And there is no doubt that, continuing the work along the lines which have been formerly maintained, and which have shown such excellent results, that this aim will be fulfilled.

The Origin of the Sun Dance

Or, The Story of Scar Face

By S.H.M.

The chief dance among the Blood Indians was the Sun Dance, and its beginning is described in this way.

The great festival of the year was the ceremony of the Medicine Lodge. It was a time of happy meetings, feasting, and giving presents. Besides this, the men who wished to make a vow took many of their undertakings tried to prove their prayers sincere by sacrificing their bodies, by some form of torture, etc. This was a most painful suffering, but vows for the Medicine Lodge must always be taken by a good woman if she has a son or husband or even a child that is sick; she will offer prayer to the sun, and in case of recovery she will build a Medicine Lodge. The pledge or vow must be made in a solemn manner, so that all might hear the promise had been made.

About the time the berries ripen the tribe would come together and pitch their lodges in a great circle, and in the centre the Medicine Lodge would be built, but not until the minor ceremonies had taken place. The ceremony usually lasted four days and four nights, during which time the person who had taken the vow would neither eat nor drink, excepting in a sacrifice.

There are quite a few ideas as to the origin of the Medicine Lodge. Some say that it was designated by the Creator to an ever-lasting friend of His. Others tell you that it was caused by an Indian named Scarface taking a journey to the Sun, and whilst staying near the lodge of the Sun and Moon he was initiated into the following rites:

A long, long time ago there was a very pretty girl, the daughter of a chief. Many of the young braves wished to marry her, but she always refused. At last her father asked her the reason she did not marry, but she replied that she did not desire to marry anyone until the young braves became so persistent in their admiration for her and the constant repetition of her father's request, she at last told her father that the Sun had...
