spoken to his mother nor to me for she belonged to the Master Person. Immodestly her father acquiesced, and nothing more was spoken about it.

There also existed at this special time a very poor young man who had no parents. He was much smaller than his fellow and for that reason he was called by the Indians "Scareface," or "Ciski." Owing to the young man's extreme poverty he was always in need for every occasion and was often taunted by the fact that if he had enough courage the Sun girl might marry him. In order to make up for the trifles he daily received, one day he met the Sun girl down by the river and asked her if she would marry him. She replied in the affirmative and he told her the secret she had made him very happy. "But," she replied, "I have one stipulation to make, and that is that you must go into the woods and get something and also ask him to remove that scare from your face—for that will be his sign. If you can find your way back to the Sun, then I shall marry you on your return." Scareface was very sad and asked her how far the Sun was from the earth; but she told him to take courage, and then left him.

Scareface lay down and tried to think, and at last he arose and went to an old woman who had been kind to him, and asked her to make seven pairs of moccasins, and to give him some advice for his journey on a long and dangerous trail. He then went out a little and looked over the camp. He turned and looked at the Sun and wondered if he would ever return home again. He offered a prayer to the Sun and then set out on his journey. He traveled many days and many weeks, crossing prairies, rivers, mountains, and many difficulties. Gradually the road became more severe, and he had to resort to the berries, etc., he found on the way. He met a Wolf on the trail and the Wolf replied that it was a long way to the Sun's camp. The Wolf replied that it was a long way and no one had ever been able to find the trail, but he advised him to go and see the Bear, who knew all the trails.

To the Bear he went and was treated with the same courtesy. Again he was directed elsewhere, this time to the Badger, who told him to go and see Kit-Face. Kit-Face was the very best guide, and to the edge of the great water which had to be crossed ere getting to the Sun's camp.

Early next morning he went down to the edge of the big water and then he fell down and cried aloud, for he had never seen such a large expanse of water before; for he could not see the other side. His mother answered him by his name, and he was almost at the point of exhaustion, and just as he was offering another prayer to the Sun, asking for his guidance, two young men came running to him and asked him why he was crying.

"I have come here today," said Scareface, "for Scareaway in my country is a very petty place. I want to marry her but she belongs to the Sun, and I set out to find him and to ask him for her. But I have been here a long time, and I have no clothing and food and game. I cannot turn for I do not know the trail, so I must die here." The Swans replied that they would take him across the great water. There was then that the Sun and Moon lived.

This gave Scareface great courage; he now knew that he was almost at the end of his journey, so he jumped on the Swans' backs and they swam away. It was a most awful journey, for there were a lot of creatures and people living in the deep water that he had never seen before, and he was very much afraid. But the Swans took him safely to the other side. There he saw the trail and the Swans told him to follow it. He had not gone far when he heard lots of very fine things lying all over the trail, bows and arrows, war instruments and very fine beads to work. He saw them all but he did not take any of them. He ran on the trail until he met a very handsome young man. His clothing was made of strange skins and his moccasins were sewn with bones.

The young man greeted him and asked him if he had touched any of the things he had seen lying on the trail. Scareface said that he had not. He was then directed where he was to go and what to do. Scareface coldly. Then the other replied that his name was "Morning Star," and said:

"The Sun is my father and the Moon my mother. My son is not at home now but I will take you to our lodge." After a time they came to the lodge and there was a very pretty scene with the bright colors. Scareface had never seen such a fine lodge before, so he was afraid to go towards the lodge, until Morning Star's mother, the Moon, who was standing outside, spoke kindly to him and gave him food and asked why he had left his people.

Scareface then told the Moon his story and when she was satisfied she sent him back to his mother. So the Moon hid him under some buffalo robes. But the Sun knew that a stranger person was in the lodge for he asked, "Who is this?" the stranger was not from whence had he come? . . .

After coming from under the robes, the Sun came to Scareface and was pleased that he had returned and asked him to stay a long time as his son was very lonely.

Next morning the two young men went hunting, but were joined by the Moon no to go near the big water, and they went together together for a long time. Morning Star was sometimes very unruly and disobeyed the Moon, so she told Scareface to be careful not to wander too far that he should go near the big water. But on this occasion Morning Star was persistent and went out into the water and was almost drowned, when Scareface went to his rescue. Scareface carried her back to the lodge and told the Moon what had happened and she was very cross with Morning Star. And when the Sun came home that night she told him what had happened. The Sun said he would not forget what he had done and promised to give Scareface a promise sacred to ask for. So Morning Star told the Sun that she was pleased to hear that his girl had been true to his commands by not making use of the things he had assured her that he could make him nine men are returning to his people.

Some time after the Sun took Scareface to the edge of the sky and told him to look down upon the earth. The Sun then said to Scareface: "Everything you see is mine, the mountains, trees, prairie plants and animals all belong to me. I am the only chief. I am never die. The winter makes me old and weak but I grow young again every summer. And when I am old I give you the sign by which my people are known. If any person is sick or in danger, promise me to build a lodge if the person recovers."

DRESSED FOR THE SUN DANCE
and the lodge is to be built like the world, round, with arched sticks, one half to be painted red for me and the other half to be painted black for the Moon.” The Sun then told Scar Face and his wife different kinds of belongings which he wished some medicine on the young man’s face and the scar disappeared. He then gave Scar Face two ermine feathers to stick in his hair as a sign, the sign for the girl that he has given him, and they were to be worn by the husband of the woman who took the vow for the Sun Dance.

Scar Face went away to pray to the Sun after the Sun and Moon and Morning Star had given him lots of presents the Sun took him to the edge of the sky and showed him the short way back to earth, and then they along the Milky Way through the heavens. He followed this “Wolf Trail,” as the Indians call it, and soon arrived back to this camp.

Instead of going direct to the camp, he sat on one of the surrounding buttes and watched all the people as they were in the midst of having a feast. As he sat there one of the chiefs saw him, and thinking him to be a stranger sent a messenger to inform him of the visit. Scar Face came down to the camp and the old Chief recognized him, and immediately sent for the Sun girl, who came very quickly by his message. All the Indians saw that the scar on his face had disappeared and that he was very handsome, and all his clothing was of strange manufacture. He then spoke to the two crow feather and told them of his visit to the Sun and of the mysteries into which he had been initiated. The chief proclaimed that he should be their chief, and he married the Sun girl the next day. They lived to a ripe old age, but they were never sick, their bodies being free from blemish, and after giving to his tribe the mysteries taught him by the Sun, both heard his wife passed away to the Sandhills, where their spirits were in safe-keeping as they had gone to the place thus ordered by the Sun.

Indian Games (By S.H.M.)

The Indian boy is much like his white brothers and loves to play games whenever he has the opportunity. In the "long ago" he played at mimic warfare, hunted around in the brushwood, or performed some of the feats of animals; and in summer spent about half his time in the water. In winter he spent his top on the ice, slid down hills on an annoyance made of buffalo ribs and hunted rabbits.

"Top" was always a favorite game with the boys. The wooden top was usually made of birch. The bark was removed entire or in sections. The top heads are marked with studs or painted partly for ornamentation and partly for decoration. The whips have four or six strands. When the game is played in soft snow, the object being to determine who can drive his top over the greatest distance without interrupting the spindle.

Another "Top" game is played upon smooth ice. The tops are water-worn egg-shaped pebbles. In the game the reels are set spinning by whipping them about at high speed and then together, the one that stops spinning first loses.

Another game commonly played during spring time is the "whipping" of flying arrows. No bow is used and the so-called arrows being but straight slender sticks. The players take an equal number of sticks. They are thrown by hand, striking them against the ground or earth. In some cases a large stone is used for elevation. The player throwing the greatest distance takes the prize.

The game of wooded darts or arrows is another boys' game, of the same general type. The darts are willow sticks of medium length. Each is sharpened at one end and split into three parts toward the other. These darts are usually decorated and some are attached tufts of hair. In the game the darts are thrown toward a target. First one is cast into a clump of bushes and the players in turn cast at it as a target. The use of the hair tufts serves as a guide to the count, thus if several darts fall almost equally near the target dart, the one whose hair tuft touched it is declared the winner.

Boys often amused themselves by placing embers from the fire on stone and striking them with another stone. When skilfully done, this gives off a report like a gun.

The Indian boy is an expert artist and music. Since coming under the instruction of white teachers, he has readily assimilated the games taught, and now ranks, in games and athletics, not only as an equal, but in some cases sets the lead.

SUNRISE IN ALBERTA

A sunrise fills the eastern sky;
Suffusing thus the entire sky;
It spreads, and soon the shades of night retreat before the King of light.
The morning star is in its prime,
Yields crown and sceptre at the dawn:
The morn's first blush is seen by me,
Fades from my sight at break of day.

And now to my enraptured view
My sky is filled with golden hue;
The sun hastened to proclaim
Sends herald forth its living flame.
O God! how lovely is the sight!
The clouds on fire in sea of gold;
The clouds on fire in sea of gold!
In fitting splendour then arise born!

The snow-crowned Rockies to the west
Receive the rising sun's first beam;
The rising sun's effulgent light
Tints every peak and every height;
A wave of glory sweeps each fold,
Then slowly turns to burnished gold;
Next, as the sun's first rays convey
Such baptism of the new-born day!

Ah! Nature hail thee with delight,
Glad of thy rising, God of light!
The prairie in her spring-time dress
Wakes to the gladness of the breeze.
The early bird, in search of food,
For faithful mate and well-scented bread,
For the young ones, whose first gleam
And sweetly tells his love-born theme.

Creator of such vast array,
That fills the soul at birth of day,
Uncreated works formed by Thy hand
Proclaim the greatness of the command.
What are a million years to Thee?
A thousand years? aye, nay!
Thy wisdom's boundless, who can explore?
I can but marvel and adore.

E. Gardner-Smith
Cardston, April 30th, 1926.

A Fascinating Indian Legend Relating to Waterton Lakes

By S.H.M.

In the long, long ago when the great country of North America was all prairie and inhabited only by Indians and wild animals, a party of Indians were camping by the banks of one of the rivers of what is now known as the Great North West. In this camp was a young Indian boy known as Sokumapi (the Boy). He was a strong hunter, a great athlete and an unsworn warrior, yet despite this he was very unsuspicious, and owing to his many evil deeds he had incurred the wrath of the Master of Evil.

After a long and serious conflict, Ausetutsoki, according to the agreement Sokumapi accompanied him to his abode to be his servant.

On arriving at their destination Sokumapi found to his dismay that the only other living thing there was a large number of snakes and a very emaciated looking ass, which on no account was he to feed. The Master of Evil left the place for a few days, fearing Sokumapi would disobey orders that he must not feed the animal. The Indian noticed the poor unfortunate creature getting thinner each day, and out of sheer compassion fed them.

Then a wonderful thing happened, for when Sokumapi went feeding the same number of snakes, and was most abusive about the treatment given by Ausetutsoki, and the ass then communicated to Sokumapi the secret of its unhappy state.

It appeared from the conversation that the ass had at one time been the unfortunate wife of an Indian chief, and that it was Ausetutsoki who had stolen her to his abode and changed her into an ass. She was now receiving punishment for her past misdeeds. The Boy and the ass then made some arrangements and contrived to effect their escape from that loathsome spot, and decided that during the next absence of Ausetutsoki they would make an attempt to find more habitable quarters. Immediately upon the return of Ausetutsoki he noticed the ass looking much better, and immediately Sokumapi not to give it any food, consequently just as soon as the Master of Evil went away on one of his periodical visits to his asscetero Sokumapi and others took him away, thus losing the part of a saddle horse.

Before taking their departure they made a thorough search of the whole place, but as they could not find anything of value, they tied these securely to the ass and started on their journey. Shortly after their departure Ausetutsoki returned, only to find that the ass and Sokumapi had gone away. The Master of Evil was very angry and immediately started to follow them.

He tracked them for a long time and just when he was getting tired of the chase he saw them in the distance and loudly called upon them to return. But they were so weak exhausted by the long journey he soon got up to them. Both the ass and Sokumapi were now desperate for their lives, scared and taken back to the abode of the lost. Just as Ausetutsoki was almost within striking distance of them, Sokumapi threw a stick at him, which struck him in the leg, a dense thicket of trees and shrubs, which to a certain extent impeded the progress of the Master of Evil. Such a quantity of the turnip-root was eaten by them that they desired and they started with renewed energy.

It was not long, however, before Ausetutsoki realized himself of his own strength in which he had been caught, and then started again to overtake the fugitives. They had not gone far before the Master of Evil was again in sight, but they were in this case therefore, Sokumapi depended upon the magic of the ass by throwing the stone at Ausetutsoki, with the intention that it might have been thrown up, so that while Ausetutsoki was climbing over the mountains the ass and The Boy made good their escape.

In due course Ausetutsoki came down over the nearby hills and demanded them to stop. He offered different bribes but all to no avail, and to show their contempt Sokumapi threw the bunch of moss at him in derision, which upon falling to the ground...
produced a tremendous swamp or marsh between the mountain and the province.

During this long and very exciting chase neither the ass nor The Boy had partaken of any food, but they struggled on and moved in order to rid themselves of their dreaded pursuers. At the same time the Master of Evil was experiencing great difficulty in crossing the swamp, but after a time he managed to arrive on solid land, and with a determined grit started after his fugitives.

It was now seen that the sun was rising and Ausetanu appeared in the distance both the ass and Sokumpi resting under the shade of "Dead Indian Mountain." Cautious, wending his way towards them, thinking that he could thus have them there, his catcher, Sokumpi suddenly turned, and much to his dismay saw the Master of Evil only a short distance from him. With tameless fury he pursued them, they had left, so in desperation he flung the root (which had peculiar medicinal properties) into the Indians' little ground whereupon it broke into many pieces. As they separated strong magic was again in evidence, for streams of water commenced to rise, which joined together and formed the lake (Pakmotokimin), which carried them along with it until its progress was arrested by the contact of other mountains; thus Ausetanu was safe upon the lake and the Master of Evil upon the other.

Seeing that he had defeated the Master of Evil and was to his abode, there to be near his love. The ass and The Boy were delighted to realize that at last they were safe from the enemy's clutches. Sokumpi then started to return to his old camping ground. When he arrived there after many moons riding on the back of the Indians, he was surprised that they had left him as a great enemy, especially as he had overcome the Evil One. His past misdeeds were forgiven and he was made the Head Chief of the Tribe.

For some time after this he was deeply interested in relating his adventures to the Indians that he had visited, forget the ass which had so befriended him, until one day he noticed it walking around the camp very forlorn and miserable. The ass approached him and said: "My life is a true one and I am not a tomahawk four times so that I may pass away to the Sandhills." Sokumpi objected to such an act and tried to remonstrate with him, still the beleagued animal at last, to stop the pitons well, he struck it on the head four times, and with the last blow it fell to the earth.

But the end was not yet, for there immediately arose from the fernbraes a beautiful Indian Maiden. All the camp heard the wonderful tidings. The Assume was so overcome with joy that he asked his newly found partner to become his wife.

Many children were born to this happy couple whose spirits have long since passed to the Happy Hunting Ground, but "Dead Indian Mountain," whose stoic profile hovers to the heavens above, stands witness as the memorial of this eventful chase. The spirits of their departed children still hover and watch over the silent glades and deep canyons of that enchanted and delightful spot, Pakmotokimin (Waterton Lakes.)

THE CANON'S LAMB

The Canon had a little lamb;
He fed it, so 'tis said,
From out a bottle filled with milk.
But now the lamb is dead.

No matter where the Canon went,
He used to carry it.
The lamb was sure to follow him
Crying "Ban ban."

It followed him to school one day,
The children were delighted,
But in the afternoon it did not stay,
For it became afflicted.

So now the Canon walks about
With mournful heart, yes very,
For he must take his walks without
The lamb, whose name was Jerry.

I. M. H.
SOLILOQUY OF A BLOOD INDIAN.

The tom-tom drum its silence keeps,
Nor signal smoke ascends from hill,
The brooding plain in stillness sleeps.
No more we leap to fight and kill.

Gone are the restless buffaloes,
Gone, too, the deer's lowing hooves.
The Crow, and Shoshone, and other foe
Stood not again o'er grassy slope;

We hurled them back each time they came,
We took their scalps in bloody fray;
They learned to dread our tribal name
And fear the fire that burned so gay.

But then were have had to cease,
The Mounties came and made it so;
And now we smoke the pipe of peace
And fight no more with ancient foe.

The tomahawk and scathing knife
Hang resting on the tepee wall,
We've turned away from wars and strife,
Nor longer start at war-whoop's call.

The Mother Queen across the sea
Signed her good name to treaty page,
These virgin lands, by her decree,
Ours shall remain from age to age.

And now we turn the soil,
We plough and harrow, reap and sow,
And golden crops reward our till.

We fear no more the winter's snow,
We place no faith in ancient sire,
In sun-dance, fetish, and shaman,
To banish sickness, death, and ill.

And superstitions can but harm.

Our children dwell in St. Paul's School
Where they are taught the White man's ways,
There, too, they learn the Golden Rule
And to great Spirit chant their praise.

In vision clear I see the day
In peace and plenty do we dwell;
The enemy holds not a place,
In arts of peace we shall excel. —E.G.S.

SUNRISE

The sun that rose in splendour
Displays new grandeur now:
The first, faint thirte, scintillate,
Have turned to brilliant glow.

The clouds have crimson lining
Inscribed in purple hue:
Beyond, the sun is shining,
And striving to break through.

Bright colours now assemble—
Behold, a wondrous sight!
Well may we mortals tremble
At such an splendid sight.

A canopy of glory
O'ercasts the darkening sky:
Revealed is Heaven's story
Before enraptured eye.

Our hearts are filled with gladness
And pride is stedfast there,
Who in His goodness sends us
Such message of His love.

I. M. H.
May 29th, 1926.

TORONTO 5: ONT. Feb. 16th, 1927.

Dear Mr. Scott:

The Rev. Canon Middleton, Principal of St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve, has forwarded to me the following resolutions, which were passed at the 14th Annual Reunion of St. Paul's Old Boys and Girls, held on the 16th and 17th of Jan. last. The Resolutions are two in number and written as follows:

1. That this Association request the Ind. Dept. to increase the per capita Grant towards St. Paul's School.

2. That all children attending St. Paul's School be allowed a vacation of one week during the Christmas Season, this to be in addition to the usual summer vacation.

With regard to the increase in the per capita Grant as your department has, as I am rightly informed, undertaken to make a substantial increase in the per capita Grant to our Indian Residential Schools, the need of St. Paul's would probably be met by this increase, when the same has been approved and authorized by parliament.

With regard to the vacation of one week during the Christmas Season, I trust that this request may receive your consideration.

Believe me,

Very truly yours,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to report that while at the Blood Agency during the first week of the present month I visited both schools. At the time of my visit there were 131 children in the R.C. School, and 128 in the C. of M. School. There are still a few children on the reserve who are not attending school, and I gave the Agent instructions to see that every child who was physically fit was placed in school. If all the children of school age were in, it would probably bring the attendance in the R.C. School up to about 130, and in the C. of M. School to about 135. Shortly after you left the Agency, I received a list from the two Principals, of children who had not returned to school after the holidays, also a list of children who were of school age and had not been enrolled in the schools. I found there were something like 75 children on the two lists, and I must say that I spent a great deal of time rounding these children up. I first saw most of the Indians and notified them that they would have to send their children back to school, and explained to them that all children of school age must attend. This brought in some of the children. There were, however, a number of Indians who seemed to have no intention of placing their children in school, and I finally had to have the Police notify them all in writing, as well as seeing them again myself. This brought all the children in who had previously attended, as well as a number of the children who were of school age and had not previously attended school. When I left the Agency, there were very few children of school age who had not been signed up in either of the schools. When examined, quite a number of the children were found to be not physically fit. These, of course, were not placed in school. The parents of a few children who were only 7½ years of age signed up for them while I was there and they are to be placed in the schools as soon as threshing is over. I think the attendance is now fairly satisfactory as there are only a few children at large who have not been enrolled.

There is, however, a lot of desertion going on at the schools, especially at the R.C. School. During the

During the last month some of the boys seemed to be continually getting away. In some cases, they are brought back by the parents, but we have to secure the services of the Police to bring others back. To give you an instance, I had a great deal of trouble in getting Joe Crow Spreads His Wings, a boy of 17, into the school. I visited his grandfather's place several times, where he stays, but the boy always avoided me. I finally got him in a week ago last Monday. At the same time the police scout brought in the son of Bob Steel, who had not returned to school; we had been after this boy several times. The same evening both boys ran away from the school. The Monday before that, I believe four boys got away in one evening, and a week did not pass but what some boy, sometimes three or four, would get away.

I do not know the reason for this truancy. The boys evidently feel they can get away easily and take advantage of it. The man in charge of the boys at the R.C. School certainly could do a lot more than he is doing to keep the boys from getting away. My own opinion is that he is lazy and would rather read a book than be around where the boys are playing. The school authorities seem to be under the impression that if the children run away, it is up to the police to bring them back. The Department can well understand that the police soon get fed up when they are called upon to bring the same boys back time after time.

While I was there, there was very little truancy at St. Paul's School, but about two weeks ago Mr. Middleton, the Principal, left for Eastern Canada.
and a few days after he left, Miss McGarry, the matron in charge, called Mr. Pugh up, saying that they were having trouble at the school with some of the boys. The Agent immediately went to the school and investigated the matter. He found that one of the boys had struck Miss Neville, the boys' matron, in the face. This boy was about 15 years old. Another boy, about 17, told him to hit her again, which I believe he did. If the matter had not been straightened up immediately by the Agent, who happened to be in the office at the time the school called up, there would have been more trouble as Mr. Smith, the Farming Instructor, is not capable and certainly cannot handle the boys when the Principal is away. I do not consider it just the right thing for a Principal to leave the school without a competent man in charge. Miss McGarry, the matron, is certainly capable, but where there are a lot of big boys, from 16 to 18 years of age, it takes a man to supervise them properly, and I am of the opinion that the Department should take strong exception to the Principal of any school being away without leaving a competent man in charge.

On my next visit to the Agency, I will again check up on the list of children who are of school age and not attending, and as I have done a lot of recruiting for these two schools, having spent a great deal of time on it when I was in charge in 1926, as well as this fall, I cannot suggest anything further in the manner of recruiting. The Principals have suggested appointing a scout for each school. I cannot see that this would be any improvement on what we have now as we have the services of the police at McLeod, Lethbridge.

Sixteenth Annual Reunion Held At Blood Reserve

More than Two Hundred at Gathering of ex-Pupils of St. Paul's School

BISHOP SHERMAN DELIVERS ADDRESS

Wonderful Progress Shown in Development of Activities On Reserve

The sixteenth annual reunion of ex-pupils of St. Paul's Anglican residential school on the Blood reserve was held on Monday, at the school.

The presence of Bishop Sherman, who knows the reserve as an adopted member of the Blood tribe, was partly responsible for the record attendance. Although the school buildings it appeared at first sight as though there could not be more expected, but on closer view, this turned out to be a line-up of Indians gathered around a cluster of good-looking sedans parked near the school. The sedans parked near the school were, at any rate, of the Blood tribe, which confirmed the gathering as such coming and going. Here was a statement of the Blood tribe in its most modern and civilized fashions, accompanied by Indians as most of the white sisters in any neighboring town would have been.

There were Indians, with pig-tails and moccasins, and Indians of all grades between the two mentioned. The most striking feature was that all these Indians spoke English very well, and very good English at that. Only the old-fashioned ones tried to turn into Blackfoot to express themselves. The business of the day after-school models of what such meetings should be, were brought forward and put to the vote in the most approved manner, and all ideas carried through without a hitch.

were inclined to look back at the old days with longing and regret, and at the present time with dissatisfaction. A reunion was a time when we arrived at the end of a period of experience. We looked back and saw the things we had missed, the memories of joy, happiness, fear, sorrow—but it is that road that we must travel, and meet with His opportunities and privileges.

We must not say that we have no road, no tracks to guide us, for none has been laid down for us. But the track of the future is a clarion call to the voice calls us to go forth and make a seed plot of Christian teaching and living. It is to the world is the only source of Christianity, and the only means of spreading and interesting Christian influence. We must use the knowledge we possess, the greater knowledge we possess, to make use of, and to share that knowledge with others. As the old king of France said, "I am not the one who had his coronation, but I am the one who had his Margaret."

These three supreme qualities are the only things that every man and woman needed to know.

It was an impassioned oration, full of feeling, and full of justice. One who has heard the bishop speak will realize it was the highest note that he had ever sounded. One heard him afterwards, both of Indian and white, that they were very moved, and this sixteenth reunion was a day destined to be remembered as the one at which the bishop spoke.
Two Hundred Present

In some ways, the main business of the day was the banquet at night in the large school hall. Such a thing would always be done at the business meetings, but the spirit of a great gathering, esprit-de-corps among the ex-pupils on the reunion committee, the hearty banquets and the ideals then held up to the young Indians, were worth any other cause. And if anyone doubts whether the old mission work has done good work, let him compare a typical present-day Indian with an old-time missionary, and he will be convinced. So it came about that the assembled company of 214 sat down to a dinner which was served by the ever-zealous members of the staff and their helpers.

The dinner, however, was really an excuse, for had not the Indians come there to have a good time? It was with keen interest that they listened to the reminiscences of these reunions, sketched by the Rev. Cyril Smith, who, during the early days of his work, he met various ex-pupils of St. Paul's, who were unable to talk very much English, and discovered that in most cases they had returned to the school since they had left. With time and opportunity now added in mind, the principal set about organizing the reunion, so that he might be able to hold for the school those who had graduated, and the result was seen Monday night. From a little over 50, the numbers had swelled to over 100.

Loyalty was the keynote of what St. Paul's taught, and of what she demanded.

The old boys of the school have shown themselves true friends during the days of the war, and the example shown them will be remembered by the present generation and those to come.

The principal, Mr. Percy Creighton, replied, assuring the gathering that they had given him much encouragement that cooperation is the root of all progress, and that they would continue to work together for the upbuilding of Canada and the world forever.

Indians of Blood Reserve Benefit By Civilization

Canon Middleton Claims They Are the Finest In the Dominion; Eagerly Seek Education

Far from being a vanishing race, Indians of the Blood Reserve are adjusting to modern life and their needs are increasing in number and importance. Canon Middleton, for 23 years the missionary at the Blood Reserve and principal of 69 pupils, addressed the board meeting of the W.A. at the school hall Monday afternoon.

The Blood Reserve is by far the most outstanding in the Dominion. Canon Middleton has been at the Blood Reserve, comprising 570 square miles, longer than any other reserve. It is larger, moreover, than the other three reserves—Pikangikum, Moosonee—Reserves combined, which with the Blood Reserve make up the Blood Confederacy. The four reserves have a total of 5000 Indians.

Age of Romance

Scoring the appalling ignorance of children attending the schools of the Indians and the work being done among them, Canon Middleton gave a description of the history of these people. He said that the Indians he termed that of about 1000 years ago. The Indians had formed part of the Blackfoot confederation, which included the Sioux, and had developed a certain degree of civilization and had developed a certain degree of civilization. The conception of the Ten Commandments had been a very important part of the five commandments. Theft was the first crime on the list of commandments, the second being to steal, to give back stolen goods by way of compensation, and the third punishment of being shot at sight. Addictions were also punished by the body by degrees for cowardice, the fourth commandment. Toil, work and wear women's clothing, which was considered a sin, was a life for a life.

Age of Transition

In the age of transition, that of giving up old ways and adopting new living to meet the changes brought with the white man's advance, the Indian fell to his lowest level. The government rations of meat, sugar, and other supplies, based on the means of livelihood the Indians had always known, did not meet the taking of such means by the white settlers. Canon Middleton pioneered the movement to help the Indians, and the government is now coming to realize its responsibility to these people.

The present age, that which the speaker terms the Age of Progress, is bringing education and cultural advantages to the Indians. These advantages to these people which the Blood Indians has been quick to recognize.

Dear General Stewart:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, with enclosures, with reference to a situation on the Blood Reserve, near Cardston, Alta. The church rivalry on this reserve is very keen. Thirty years ago, after both churches interested had been labouring in the field for many years, there were about 100 Church of England Indians and a like number of Roman Catholics, the rest - approximately 1000 - being classed as pagan. Today, there are about 550 Anglicans and a like number of Catholics and only 100 odd pagans. Of course, this competition between the churches leads to many problems, which are difficult of solution. This is particularly true when the principals of the two Indian residential schools are recruiting pupils, and I propose, first, to refer to those enclosures with your letter which deal with the school question.

Some of the Indians on this reserve do not take the white man's religion very seriously, and, when they have a pupil old enough for school, they have been known to play one principal against the other and to accept church rites from both. Then, there is the vexed question of Indian marriages. A mother will remove herself with her young children from her first husband and will take another who is perhaps a communicant of the other church. In a year or two, we find both schools claiming the children. Further, the adoption of children is common in Indian communities and, sometimes, it is very difficult to decide between the rights of the natural and foster parents. To

Dear Mr. Williams:

I have the honour to report on an inspection made at the St. Paul's School in the Blood Agency. In this instance the same applies as to the St. Mary's School; I did not inspect the class rooms as I intend to do that during the winter. I did, however, go over the school, their farm and garden, &c., and went into the general administration of the institution.

At the time of my visit there were 127 children in residence and I was quite interested to note that there were 7 in Grade VIII, 3 in Grade IX, 1 in Grade X, and 1 in Grade XI: This certainly speaks well for the school. At present one girl is training for a nurse in the General Hospital at Nelson, B.C., and is in her third year; another girl is to take up nursing in Grace Hospital in Winnipeg, and begins her training this fall.

The boy cadets at the school won fifth prize for the Dominion of Canada in the St. John's Ambulance Corps. The girls of the school won fourth prize for the Dominion. The girls are taught sewing and general house-work and cooking, but they do not do any of the milking. They do a certain amount of work in the gardens, &c.

The boys get a certain amount of training in farming and gardening,

The school has quite an extensive farm. This year they have sown 220 acres to wheat, 80 to oats, 20 to grass and about 65 acres are being summerfallowed. Ten acres are under potatoes and other garden stuff. In all, the school has about 400 acres under cultivation.

FROM "CALGARY HERALD"

February 2, 1933.

SCHOOL HOLDS REUNION

Old Students Meet

St. Paul's Residential School

ON, Feb. 1.—(Special)—The first annual reunion of the old St. Paul's Residential School has been held today.

The occasion began with a special service in the school church, when his lordship the Bishop of Calgary paid a visit to the school.

The services was conducted by Rev. Canon Morrison, and the speakers were Rev. Mr. Orton, M.A., of High River.

The reunion banquet was held in the general dining room, with about 200 adults and 50 special guests.

Rev. Canon Morrison, B.S.C., was host of the evening, assisted by his wife and Miss Mary Murray.

J. E. Pugh, M.C., Indian agent, proposed the toast to "The Guest," corresponding to which Mr. J. S. Stewart, M.P., who touched upon the work done at the school and the progress of St. Paul's in the last twenty-one years.

Rev. Mr. Orton, M.A., spoke of the warmth of friendship that had always greeted St. Paul's entrance and he traced back many memories here.

Chief Crosschild, influential and progressive chief of the reserve, brought a message on behalf of his people, thanking them for the good work being done at St. Paul's and on the reserve.

A toast to the "Old Boys and Girls" was proposed by the Rev. H. Parkinson, M.A., who expressed his delight to see so many old boys and girls.

Frank Goodstriker, graduate of the school, gave the response, folowed by a speech given by an older member—Mountain Horse. A musical interlude then rendered by W. Beete, B.S.A.

The toast to "St. Paul's School" was proposed by Rev. Mr. Orton, M.A., who stressed the responsi-
bility of school life and an appealing and impressive response followed by Mrs. F. G. Greer, of Calgary, who saw not only the outstanding progress of the Indians, but a greater day ahead, when by education and proper training, fore-
sight and new opportunities the Indians would attain full rights of citizenship in the Dominion.

H. P. Filliou then proposed a toast to "The Diocese of Calgary," commending the work of St. Paul's parish, its standard and position, and the advancement it had attained.

His lordship Right Rev. the Bishop of Calgary gave the final toast. He was glad, he said, to see such enthusiasm for the cause of Canadian life. Education was one of the leading forces, and the work of the school would have far-reaching effects.

Following the speeches, the annual ball was held in the school auditorium, which was crowded by a large number of graduates and friends. A delightful evening was spent.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of April 18th with regard to the school facilities on Indian Reserves, having special reference to the situation at Brocket. I note your remark that the arrangements made will enable them to conduct this school satisfactorily. I am in receipt, however, of a very strong letter from Thomas Graham, the Indian Agent at Brocket, setting out that this will not cover the situation and appealing to the Provincial Government to go still further and give them a special grant over and above what is given ordinarily to a rural school. This appeal I consider to be altogether unreasonable and it is beyond all possible argument that it should be directed to the Ottawa Government.

You may not be aware that, in this Province, it is necessary to pay $900 for teacher's salary alone. I think the provision made is inadequate. The small amount of money involved is not the matter of serious consideration, but you will readily understand that this Government cannot accept responsibility where it has no legal standing, and that what we are offering to do admits nothing excepting our anxiety to see that children are not deprived of education. Our assistance is purely a gift.

Yours truly,

(sgd.) Geo. P. Smith.

Sir,

There are seven or eight heads of families in Brocket who are anxious to get a school established here for their children. Mr. Dolan, School Inspector, on one of his trips through Brocket, met the people here and we discussed the matter with him. At his suggestion we bought a good building and had it moved to Brocket for a school house. The Department of Indian Affairs have agreed to furnish it with desks, blackboard, globe, etc., and have also promised a grant of $250.00 per year, while the provincial government, through their inspector Mr. Roberts of Macleod say they will only give us $1.00 per day grant. This small amount would entail a hardship on some of us who would have to pay from $50.00 to $100.00 per year, and as we are tax payers in other school districts we do not think it just. Mr. Dolan intimated that in some cases the provincial grant allowed was as high as $400.00, and if so, surely this is a worthy case. I would like to point out that the employees of the Department of Indian Affairs who will have children attending the school are three in number, while those who are not employees and have nothing to do with the Department of Indian Affairs number five heads of families, so you will see that this school is not being established purely and solely for the benefit of Department employees. There are 15 children of school age in Brocket and I feel sure that we will have your sympathy and consideration. We have written the local school inspector to come and discuss this matter and advise us as we are anxious to get the children to school, but so far he has not put in an appearance. As we have gone to a great deal of expense already in buying this building and having it moved we would like to get the school under way as soon as possible.

I am Sir,

Sir:

I beg to draw your attention to the position the employees at this Agency are in with regard to the education of their children.

The nearest school is five miles distant from the Agency. During the summer months the children are able to drive themselves, though the roads are almost impassable in wet weather, but in the winter it is practically impossible to get them to school as the road, which is used very little, becomes blocked with snow and the distance is too far for children to drive in cold weather. There are six children going to school from the Agency at present and there are two more of school age, varying in age from thirteen to sixteen years old. It is out of the question to expect the second semester to drive them there and bring them back, nor are there horses available, and we have no means of having the children nearer the school, so that it means that for the next five months our children will not be able to go to school.

I understand that in some cases under similar circumstances the Department or the Government has afforded assistance to its employees, for the purpose of getting their children to school, and with this in view I am putting forward a suggestion that the Department or Government will help us to engage a teacher who would reside at the Agency and teach the children there. I have no doubt that with board and lodging provided free we could get a teacher for $60.00 a month, which would mean $300.00 for the five months. Would it be possible to request the Department or Government to consider this plan and to grant the amount as stated above?

As it is a matter of great importance to us that our children be educated, may I request that you give this your attention, and bring it to the notice of the proper authorities.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) Geo. S. Dodd
Indian Agent

Sir,

I have the honour to report a perplexing situation which has arisen at this Agency, with respect to a Day School for the children of Department employees.

With the closing and removal of the Anglican Indian Residential School, and the closing and removal of the Roman Catholic School in the near future - the latter is already filled to its capacity, preparing to remove - there are left without a school for our children who have always attended one or the other of these institutions. The new schools are each situated about six miles from the Agency.

Belonging to the employees at the Agency are the following children of school age:

| Name                  | Boys | Girls |
|-----------------------|------|-------|
| Dr. Hill, Resident Medical Officer | 2    |       |
| P. Booth, Farming Instructor     |      | 1     |
| P. Dufresne, Interpreter        | 2    |       |
| Lang Turner, Indian Agent       |      | 2     |

and also two other children living at the Agency, the daughters of the telegraph operator, who is a Government employee although not of the Indian Department.

The Bishop of Saskatchewan, Dr. G. E. Lloyd, is considering the project of establishing a Day School in the building recently vacated by the Anglican Indian Residential School at Onion Lake; the principal obstacle to this is the devising of ways and means to meet the cost of maintenance. A School District cannot be formed here as there is no assessable land. The Saskatchewan Government, recognizing our difficulty, has promised us $300 annually towards the upkeep of a private school, such as the one projected; but, even so, the balance required, devolving upon so few parents would be considerable; and I have been asked to approach the Department with a request for a small annual grant towards the upkeep of this school for employees' children until such time as the railway is built through this district and relieves the situation.

Trusting that the Department will give sympathetic consideration to this request,

I have the honour to be

These schools are for the benefit of the employees of this Department and, as such, any grants allowed should be paid from the General Administration Vote. Consequently we have rents to pay, fuel and light, and as school districts in Alberta do not recognize Indian Reserves as part of school districts and residence rules apply, we are expected to pay school rates when demanded. I may say that where families are residing in Cardston, in good weather week ends and holidays, return to reserve is invariably done for those periods. This cannot, however, be done in bad weather. I would like it understood that very rarely do employees themselves stay in Cardston over night.

By the arrangements as at present, I may say in the Agent's case, no inconvenience is caused Officials visiting the Agency, and are at all times taken care off, a factor which one in an Agent's position has to consider, and the Department may rest assured that this feature will always be taken care of.

The problem of getting the children to school from the four places is difficult in that the distance is great, and to solve the problem of education of employees' children, without effecting the Department either financially or from a duty point of view is difficult. Schooling for the Indian children is of course provided for under Treaty conditions, but there seems to be no way of approach to the problem for employees' children where premises are widely scattered on a large reserve such as this, and not adjacent to town or village, with its advantages. A copy of this letter has been sent to Mr. Inspector Christianson.

I should be glad to discuss this matter further with the Department if they have any suggestion to make regarding the problem.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to inform you that at a meeting of the employees of the Department of Indian Affairs of Alberta held at Edmonton in June, last, a resolution was passed in connection with the education facilities for employees' children in the different agencies in the province. This should have been brought to your attention before this, but owing to my illness it has been held up until now.

The education of employees' children at the different agencies has always been a bone of contention; At least it has been ever since I came into the Department, and on various occasions employees have taken this question up with me. In a great many cases they live miles away from the nearest school and it has been necessary for them to either move their families to town, or find a boarding place for their children in the nearest town. Employees only getting a small salary are not able to do this. You will readily understand that a Farming Instructor, for example, who has several children, cannot send them to a boarding school. Neither can he afford to get boarding places for them in town, as the salary he receives will not allow him to do this.

I took this up several times with Mr. Graham, our Commissioner at that time, but nothing was ever done in the matter. At one time I was out in Alberta with Mr. Graham and Dr. Scott, then Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and I discussed this with them personally. Dr. Scott instructed Mr. Graham to go into the matter thoroughly and make a recommendation as to what should be done, as he was quite prepared to give it consideration, and to give assistance wherever it was necessary to send the children away from home to school. Mr. Graham, however, did nothing about it and the matter dropped there.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6371, file 764-2, part 1)
Doctor Scott gave some agencies an allowance of $250 per year. For instance, the Blood Agency and Peigan Agency received this amount, but it was never properly handled: On the Peigans the late Mr. Arthur, then Agent, had one child; Mr. Lancaster, then Clerk, had 6 children, and the late Mr. McLaughlin, who was then Farming Instructor, had one child; and the $250.00 was divided three ways. Other Agencies, however, that were in the same position received nothing. This gives you an outline of what has taken place.

I have always been of the opinion that parents are responsible for the clothing and feeding of their children, and would have to pay a certain amount of school tax no matter where they were. But, where we found that an employee had to send his children to town to board I have always thought that some assistance should be given by the Department, but only during the time they are attending public school. No grant should be given after the children have reached the age of 16 years, whether they are still attending public school or not. The amount thus expended would not be great as a few of the agencies are within fairly reasonable distance from school. Also, some of our Agents have families that are already grown up. I shall be forwarding you in a few days a list of the employees in the different agencies, the number of children in each family, and the school facilities in each case. I feel quite sure that you will give this your earnest consideration. It is one of the matters I had intended discussing with you last summer.

I have the honour to be,

Dr. McGill,

The Deputy Minister's authority for these payments apparently has become the accepted practice although I was recently informed by an official of the Auditor General's Office that he was contemplating writing the Department regarding the matter. I intimated that the Department had the matter under consideration, and was then informed that under the circumstances no official observation would be made for the present. It was suggested, however, that the whole question be investigated with a view of drafting suitable regulations regarding conditions under which such assistance would be granted and that proper authority be obtained for the expenditure.

As only three Agencies, Blood, Peigan, and Onion Lake, are affected at present, and the amount involved is only around $600.00, I would suggest that, pending consideration of the whole question, any payments which may be authorized be charged to the Education allotment as formerly.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department's letter No. 345560 of the 24th ultimo in connection with the education of employees' children in the various agencies in the Province of Alberta. In this connection I wish to point out that the grant would have to come under two or three different headings. For instance, in certain agencies the children have to be sent away to board or the mother has to move to town with the children. In other cases the parents are put to the expense of hiring a teacher; and in a few agencies the children are able to drive to public schools that are situated near the reservations.

I forwarded to the Department letters from all the Agents showing the number of children in the different agencies and giving the school facilities. I would recommend that where the children have to be sent away to school and the parents have to pay board at a cost of from $15.00 to $20.00 a month, the Department give a grant of $5.00 a month for each child for ten months, which would amount to $50.00 for the school year. Other cases could be dealt with accordingly.

I shall now take each agency separately and outline the situation, giving my recommendations in each case:

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
BLACKFOOT AGENCY:

There is no difficulty at this Agency in connection with getting schooling for the employees' children, as they are all able to drive to nearby towns. Most of them attend school at Gleichen, with the exception of Mr. Evans' children who attend at Cluny.

SADDLE LAKE AGENCY:

Mr. R. W. Secord, the Clerk, has one girl seven years old, and the nearest available school is at St. Paul. He pays $16.60 a month for board and tuition. Mr. J. H. Boorse, Farming Instructor, has one boy attending school and it costs him $5.00 a month for board. I would recommend that each of these two employees receive a grant of $5.00 per month towards the education of their children.

BLOOD RESERVE:

At this point we have a real problem: The children of employees number 16 at the present time. Mr. Pugh, the Agent, has two children attending school, and Mr. Betts, the Farming Instructor, has four. Mrs. Pugh and Mrs. Betts are living in town where both families have rented houses. I would refer you to the Agent's letter which I forwarded to the Department along with the other letters in this connection. At the present time there are seven children that would come under the grant, and you will note by the Agent's letter that inside of three years there will be 15 children attending school if the present employees are retained.

PEIGAN AGENCY:

There are only two children from this Agency attending School, as you will note by the list submitted by the Indian Agent. Mr. Webb, the Clerk, father of the two boys attending school, pays $10.00 per month to get them to school, which would mean $100. per year, as well as $16.00 per year for school fees. I note by the Department's letter that he is getting a grant of $50.00 per year, and I consider that this is quite satisfactory.
STONY AGENCY:

There are only two children of school age at this agency: two boys, 10 and 11 years of age, sons of Mr. George Reid, the Clerk. At the present time the old hospital building there is being used as a school, and Mr. Reid, Mr. Staley and Mr. Rogers, who runs the Morley Trading Company, have hired a teacher. Mr. Reid is paying $10.00 per month towards the teacher's salary at the present time. If Mr. Reid received the same consideration as the Peigan Agency Clerk, viz., $50.00 per year, I believe this would be quite fair.

HOBBEMA AGENCY:

The education of employees' children does not present any problem at this Agency: Mr. McLeod, the Farming Instructor has one girl twelve years old, and Mr. Moore, the Clerk, has two children. These three children are attending a day school about a mile and a half from the Agency.

LESSER SLAVE AGENCY:

At this point, Mr. L'Heureux, the Agent, has a real problem on his hands. At the present time the Agent has four children of school age and they have to be sent away to a boarding school at Donnelly, a distance of 70 miles from the Agency, as there is no day school within miles of the Agency. For each child he has to pay $15.00 a month, and $16.00 a year as a tuition charge. In other words, at the present time he is paying $60.00 a month for the education of his children, not counting the tuition, books, clothing, &c. As you will note in his letter, he states that the average cost is about $20.00 per month for each child. I think the Department will agree with me that $5.00 a month for each child would help him out greatly and at the same time, it would not be unreasonable to ask for that amount in this case.

EDMONTON:

There is no problem here: The children all attend day schools and drive to school every day.
SARCEE AGENCY: As the Department will note by Dr. Murray's letter, his children are attending school in Calgary, and Mr. Hetherington's go to day school at Midnapore.

This covers all the agencies in this province with the exception of Athabasca. From time to time various problems will arise and these of course can be adjusted. I would just like the Department to be sympathetic towards employees' requests. For instance, where a Farming Instructor is living on a reserve away from the Agency, where his children have to drive quite a distance to school and he is put to great expense in procuring driving equipment for them, I would ask that on recommendation from me the Department would consider furnishing a small grant towards the expenditure incurred in this connection.

Regarding the payment of the school grant, I would recommend that a cheque be made out to each individual employee who is getting the grant, and the cheque can be forwarded through the Agency office. I do not think I have anything more to add to this, except to say that for the present time the amount required to take care of my recommendations would not be large, but at the same time it would be of great help to the employees. Take a Farming Instructor, for instance, who has to keep two homes going, or has to send his children away to school and pay board; He has not very much left out of his salary each month. During the period that I have been with the Department as Inspector I have seen so many cases where the parents are really denying themselves everything to see that their children receive an education. I suppose this applies to outsiders as well as to employees of the Indian Department, but as I have said before, this is a matter that should have had attention years ago, but was never given any consideration. I trust the Department will give favourable consideration to my recommendations.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

RESOLUTION RE EDUCATION EMPLOYEES' CHILDREN

Passed by the Staff of the Department of Indian Affairs in Alberta:

---

Whereas large numbers of employees of the Department of Indian Affairs, resident on Indian Reserves throughout the Western Provinces are debarred from giving their children an adequate education, except at great expense to themselves, owing to the distance they reside from the nearest school District, and whereas these employees are compelled to expend large sums of money each year out of all proportion to their salary, to pay for board and rooms for their children while they attend school and this works a great hardship on the said employees,

Therefore, be it resolved and it is resolved that the Department of Indian Affairs should assist these employees up to the amount paid as grants for the education of an Indian child, upon the recommendation of the Inspector of Indian Agencies and the Agent of the Agency concerned such assistance to be proportional to the number of children being sent to school, i.e., the larger the number of children from one family the smaller the per capita grant. No child to receive assistance after reaching the age of EIGHTEEN years. In the case of an Indian Agent being affected the recommendation of the Inspector of Indian Agencies for the Province to be sufficient.

Dear Mr. Sutherland,

In August we made application to the Department for the annual school grant, $250.00, towards the education of the employees' children in the Onion Lake Agency, but we were turned down flat. We were told that the Auditor General has taken exception to the Department making the expenditure from the appropriation to which it was charged and that owing to certain regulations it could not be provided for by a special vote. All this is very disappointing to us and we have difficulty in reconciling it with the Department's letter (No. 16565) dated August 28th, 1927, a copy of which reads as follows: "If you can make satisfactory arrangements for a class room and its equipment and can secure sufficient funds for a satisfactory day school, the Department will allow a grant of $250.00 per year." On receipt of the letter from which the above is an extract, we procured suitable building and equipped it at some considerable expense, and made the necessary arrangements for financing. In view of the above the official reply came as a shock. It simply means that we will have no school for our children.

The cost of operating our school is $900.00 per annum, and the only assistance we now receive is the Saskatchewan school grant of $200.00, leaving a deficit of $700.00 to be made up by ourselves, and it is beyond our capacity to do so. At its inception in 1927 there were seven children of employees of school age - now there are ten attending. Even with the Department's grant of $250.00, $100.00 had to be put up privately to make ends meet, and without the grant the situation is hopeless. Our nearest Saskatchewan public school is nine miles distant.

I am addressing this personally to you as I have a feeling that in some way you may be able to help us. I trust you have fully recovered your health and that you will enjoy a Merry Christmas and a very Happy New Year.

Yours very truly,

Mr. J. D. Sutherland,

REPORT ON C. PANT. SCHMIDT'S VISIT TO BLOOD INDIAN AGENCY ON THE 12 to the 17 INSTANT.

Remarks re Staff:

Re: Mr. M. MacLeod, Agency Clerk:

As the Department know (Vide Dept. #140-103 dated October 1, 1942, and subsequent correspondence) Mr. MacLeod, the Senior Clerk, has moved his family to a rented house on the outskirts of the town of Cardston, so that his two boys may be able to walk to school. Mr. MacLeod still occupies the Clerk's house at the Agency, where he batches from Monday morning until Saturday noon. The Agency H.Q. is nine miles from town.

Re: Mr. T. Gregson, Farming Instructor on Farm 4

Area - North of the Agency H.Q.

I was surprised to find that Mr. Gregson had also moved his family to Cardston so that his four children could walk to school. I asked both Mr. Gregson and the Indian Agent whether the Department had been informed of this; the reply was in the negative. I then told the Agent that he should inform the Department at once.

The Home Farm where Mr. Gregson lives is 18 miles from Cardston and school. In the past he drove his children to and from school each day. Owing to gasoline and rubber restrictions he decided to move the family to town where he owns a house. As it is now, it may be said that his home is in Cardston, as he spends the greater number of his nights there.

I remarked that I appreciated the fact that his children have to be educated, but thought the Department might and should have been informed and consulted in the matter of his moving. I also stated that I was aware that he had to go to town quite frequently for repairs and other business, but that this was not an every-day occurrence or necessity. Mr. Gregson remarked that he figured it was cheaper for the Department (as he uses a departmental farm truck) for him to move to town, than to drive the children to and from town each day. Agent McMillan then mentioned a letter written by the Deputy Superintendent General some years ago re schooling for employees' children; this letter was not produced. I told him to mention this letter when writing to the Department to inform them that Mr. Gregson
had moved to Cardston, adding that I did not wish to argue on this matter, and that the Department would give their approval or vice versa.

The farming area on the Blood Reserve is divided in two by a section line running East and West at a point approximately nine miles North of the South Boundary of the Reserve. The South (or G.P.) Area is under the supervision of Farming Instructor W. Bette; his home is approximately 4½ miles from town. The North Area is under the supervision of Farming Instructor T. Gregson, whose home is not far from the Belly River, near the North-west corner of Section 24, Township 5, Range 26. It might be said that there is no farming done East of Range 25 and North of the centre of Township 5.

Owing to the storm and the roads being drifted, I was unable to make any other visits on the reserve. I left Saturday at 11.00 A.M. for Brocket to see Mr. J.T. Faunt, whom I had not visited since Autumn.

I was surprised to find that Mr. Gregson had also moved his family to Cardston so that his four children could walk to school. I asked both Mr. Gregson and the Indian Agent whether the Department had been informed of this; the reply was in the negative; I then told the Agent that he should inform the Department at once.

The farm where Mr. Gregson lives is 18 miles from Cardston and school. In the past he drove his children to and from school each day. Owing to gasoline and rubber restrictions he decided to move the family to town where he owns a house. As it is now, it may be said that his home is in Cardston, as he spends the greater number of his nights there.

I remarked that I appreciated the fact that his children have to be educated, but thought the Department might and should have been informed and consulted in the matter of his moving. I also stated that he was aware that he had to go to town quite frequently for repairs and other business, but that this was not an every-day occurrence or necessity. Mr. Gregson remarked that he figured it was cheaper for the Department (as he uses a departmental farm truck) for him to move to town, than to drive the children to and from town each day. Agent McMillan then mentioned a letter written by the Deputy Superintendent General some years ago re schooling for squatters' children; this letter was given to me and I told him to mention this letter when writing to the Department to inform that Mr. Gregson had moved to Cardston, adding that I did not wish to argue on this matter, and that the Department would give their approval or vice versa.

The farming area on the Blood Reserve is divided into two by a section line running East and West at a point approximately nine miles North of the South boundary of the Reserve. The South (or C.P.) Area is under the supervision of Farming Instructor W. Betts; his home is approximately 4½ miles from town. The North Area is under the supervision of Farming Instructor T. Gregson, whose home is not far from the Belly River, near the North-west corner of Section 24, Tp. 5, R. 26. It might be said that there is no farming done East of Range 25 and North of the centre of Township 5.
Calgary, February 16th, 1943.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Reference your No. 345560 of the 10th instant, re Indian Agent A. McMillan's letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to Farming Instructor T. Gregson, I beg to advise that this matter was mentioned in my report No. 402-9 dated January 27th, 1943, Page 4, abstract of which I attach hereto. As stated therein, I enquired whether the Department had been informed that Mr. Gregson had moved his family to town; the reply being in the negative, I asked that this be done.

I pointed out to Mr. McMillan and Mr. Gregson that the Department had residences on the reserves for their employees, where they expected them to live; and after having lived there for a number of years, that before moving to town for the academic year -- or a period of ten months -- I thought the Department should at least be informed of their intention to do so.

Mr. Gregson has, for several years, driven his children to school at Cardston, using the Department farm truck which is supplied him for his use as Farming Instructor. (I understand there were odd days when his private car was used). This was being done when I first went to the Blood Agency when Mr. Gregson brought his children from his home to the Agency U.S. -- a distance of approximately 10 miles -- in the Department truck, then Agent Pugh picked them up and drove them to Cardston -- a distance of 9 miles -- together with his own (Agent Pugh's) and, I believe, Agency Clerk M. MacLeod's children as well. During the last year or two that Agent Pugh was at the Agency, his two children lived (boarded) in town, coming home for week-ends only.

In discussing the matter with Mr. Gregson and Agent McMillan, Mr. Gregson mentioned that he had to go to town quite often (almost every day) on official business, for machinery repairs, oil, grease, gasoline, or to look after the sale of grain at the elevator, etc. It was then that I remarked that I did not think this was an every-day occurrence or necessity; nor did I think that it required two trips to town each day.

My reason for bringing this matter to the attention of the Department is, that I considered the Department should at least have been informed that Mr. Gregson was moving his family to town; and when I was told that he himself made it his home, by spending most of his nights there, I believed it to be my duty to instruct that the Department be advised. I did expect that Agent McMillan would give more information than he did in his letter.

For your information, please,

C. Pant. Schmidt,
S/B Inspector of Indian Agencies.

1. Fill in all the columns of the Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. My statements are corroborated by interested outsiders, when I say that the education, fundamentals and disciplined training which are imparted here rank second to none, for I always demand that my Staff must be duly qualified to fill the positions they occupy. Such being the case, a new School—semi-industrial, if possible—to accommodate 100 pupils built on the Reserve, on such a scale that experiments of a practical nature could be carried on, so that not only the pupils, but also the ex-pupils could obtain and derive great benefits therefrom, is the great need of the Blood Reserve.

The pupils I have in School respond nobly to the curriculum and system now in operation, but we are only touching the fringes of what we ought to be doing, for it ever resolves itself into the old adage—"be content to "Mark Time",—have no worry—for the Indians will never repay what has and is being expended on them!"

Such a hopeless fallacy is not consistent with progress and is contrary to the laws of intellectual development. Therefore, I do emphasise the need for a new School in order to replace our present Institution, and I thought that during the intervention of an "Agreement" being re-modelled this would be a good time to write you concerning the above.

Dear Mr. Scott,

As the five years "Agreement" between the Department and the School authorities has now lapsed until such time as another is drawn up, may I crave the indulgence by calling your attention to the total inadequacy of educational facilities on this Reserve. Medical Report for February, 1919.

The pupils of the boarding schools have been generally free from sickness. On this date, 7th inst., I made an inspection of the boarding school at St. Paul's Mission.

There is nothing modern about this building. The heating of it is very inadequate in cold weather, and there are no facilities for proper bathing. The bath rooms both for the boys and the girls are in my opinion insufficiently heated and only one small portable laundry tub is supplied for each bath room. All the garbage and refuse from the buildings have to be carted away. There is no furnace in the buildings and the heating of the various rooms is accomplished by 34 small heaters from which pipes run into three brick chimneys. With these small stoves it must be very difficult to make the rooms sufficiently warm for the health and comfort of the inmates during very cold weather.

The dormitories are heated only by the stove pipes from the stoves on the first floor. The privies consist of a small building over a hole sunk in the ground. There is only one for the girls and one for the boys. When this hole gets filled up, the little building is moved to another hole.

When it is considered that there is an average attendance at this school of 30 girls and 30 boys the equipment and crude conditions at this school preclude what would at this day be considered proper sanitation and bodily comfort. It seems to me that more heat ought to be supplied to the dormitories.

Ottawa, August 19, 1919.

Dear Canon Gould,

As you may be aware it is the policy of the Department to rebuild our industrial and boarding schools when necessary on more improved plans. Previous to 1914 we had an extensive plan outlined looking forward several years under which we were to replace in order of necessity, as far as possible, buildings considered no longer fit for the purpose which they were serving. The war, however, intervened and we were obliged from economical reasons to curtail very largely our building schemes.

On the list for rebuilding were the Victoria Home and the Roman Catholic school buildings on the Brûléan Reserve, and I had planned later to renew both the Roman Catholic and Church of England buildings on the Blood Reserve. However, owing to the necessity of strict retrenchment these matters have been reconsidered and it has been decided that four schools on these two reserves are not necessary, their erection and maintenance henceforth being cancelled for burden both on the Government and the church authorities. It has been decided that one school for each denomination situated at the most convenient points should provide sufficient accommodation for the education of the children of the reserves in Southern Alberta.

I have already informed His Lordship Bishop Monseigneur accordingly, and I am now writing to apprise you of the decision of the Department, arrived at, as said above, after due consideration.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Graham,

You will remember my letter of the 4th July, to which you replied on the 31st of the same month, in which we discussed the educational affairs on the Blood and Siksika Reserves, and you supported my view that it might be advisable to have two schools only on these reserves, one for the Anglicans and one for the Roman Catholics. Since then I have had an opportunity of discussing the matter with Rt. Rev. J.T. Macdonald, Roman Catholic Bishop of Calgary. He is very much opposed to that suggestion thinking that it would destroy the work of his mission in the south. He also discussed the matter with the minister who threw out the suggestion that we might perhaps amalgamate the reserves of the Blackfoot, Siksika and Blood Indians. Hon. Mr. Neighen was speaking with me on the subject this morning and mentioned this suggestion. I said I did not think it would be at all possible to move the Blackfoot Indians, but I was not certain that it was impossible to amalgamate the Bloods and Siksikas. The minister wished me to write to you and ask you to consider the matter also to discuss it with Bishop Macdonald.

Of course it would be an immense advantage to have the Siksikas and Bloods together on the Blood Reserve. If we could sell out the Siksika Reserve and add the revenue to the capital of the Bloods we would get rid of a place of expense which the Indians have always found it difficult to support themselves. Will you kindly give the matter your best consideration.
