Dear Mr. Hunt,

From information received during the recent visit of the Rev. T. H. Westgate, Field Secretary of the M. S. C., it is highly probable that the erection of a new school in lieu of the present associated buildings at the above noted Institution will not materialise this year.

I write therefore on the advice of the Field Secretary to ask if you will kindly endorse the enclosed request for assistance in making the necessary repairs to the present buildings in order to render them more habitable and suitable for the pupils.

The foundations are fast decaying under all the existing buildings. All the buildings need re-flooring, the stoves and furnaces are almost beyond repair, and the new lumber on the buildings is cracking for want of a coat of paint. I have attached a list herewith, giving in detail the repairs necessary which I trust you will carefully examine and recommend to the Department the adoption of same. It is hardly necessary for me to say that if any work is done it ought to be commenced at an early date.

Thanking you in anticipation,

Yours sincerely,

S. Middleton,
Principal.
Summary of repairs absolutely needed to keep present school buildings in habitable condition.

New floors are needed in the Girls' Home, School Room, Boys' Play Room, Kitchen and Common Room.

Twenty-five new windows and frames are needed to replace the present windows, which are fast falling to pieces due to old age.

Four new heaters are needed two in Girls' Home and two in Boys' Home — greater capacity than those worn out in order to heat the old buildings.

All chimneys need re-pointing.

Interior of furnace is almost burnt out.

The bare lumber on the buildings is cracking for lack of a coat of paint.

The side-walks which have been in use for ten years are daily falling to pieces.

Estimated cost to even begin to complete the required repairs of the above noted items. Approximately $1,000.00.
Sir,

I enclose, herewith, copy of a letter addressed to Mr. Hunt, Agent at the Blood Reserve, by the Principal of St. Paul's Church of England School, together with a list of the repairs which it is deemed should be made without delay at this Institute.

Mr. Hunt has been over the premises with Mr. Middleton, and is satisfied that conditions have not been exaggerated. I am also aware of the state of the building referred to, and agree that repairs ought to be undertaken if the building of a new school is not contemplated for a year or two. I, therefore, beg to suggest that I be authorised to provide for an expenditure of say $150.00 in order to make the buildings habitable. I think, however, that an inspection of the buildings should be made, and this I propose to make myself, or have made by an Inspector shortly.

I shall be glad to hear if the Department concurs in my recommendation.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. GRAHAM

I visited the St. Paul Anglican Boarding School last week and made an inspection of the building and I found it in very bad shape. Dear Sir,

In answer to your communication of the 24th ultimo, I beg to state that Mr. Faunt—Indian Agent—and I have made a careful survey of the question regarding the approximate amount of children available on the Blood Reserve, who may be regarded as potential recruits for being admitted as pupils to a new C. of E. school.

At the present time there are 239 children of Anglican and Pagan parentage. Out of these, 130 are under the age of seven years, and 109 range between the ages of 7-16 years.

From personal knowledge and observation, ten to fifteen percent of this number would not be able to pass the requisite medical examination for admittance, thus reducing the above to approximately 225 children.

There are sixty pupils now enrolled at this institution which leaves forty children on the Reserve, all of school age, who are receiving no education. Based on the figures on a conservative estimate about forty per cent of the 130 children under seven years, will attain school age during the next two years. It would therefore appear that a building to accommodate at least 150 pupils would be necessary to ensure an education for the non-resident Anglican and pagan children of the Reserve.

Trusting this brief summary will give you the desired information.

I beg to remain,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Dr. Scott,

This letter is entirely personal, and is in no way to be regarded as official. During a recent visit of the Rev. Dr. Westgate, of the M.S.C.C., we were discussing the contemplated new school for this reserve, and the ultimate development of the scheme.

In drawing up an outline of the proposed buildings, I naturally included a residence for the Principal. It has been my privilege, during the past twelve years to reside in a house entirely apart from the main school buildings, and I am writing this, in the hope that you may be able to grant this request, when considering the final plans for the proposed new school.

Rest assured that when undertaking the new scheme, a capable assistant will be engaged, who will reside in the main building itself, and will exercise the necessary supervision.

The matter of the new school for the Blood Reserve, is a question of no small importance, both to the Indians and the community at large, I am therefore most anxious to make it the best of its kind, and shall not spare any effort in order to bring about the desired culmination.

Thanking you for past favours. Closing with every kind wish.

Yours most sincerely

[Signature]

PRINCIPAL.

February 10, 1923.

Dear Mr. Middleton,

I have your letter of the 18th ult., with reference to the proposed new Blood residential school. I am sending you today under separate cover blue print copies of the sketch plan which has been prepared, showing a suggested layout for the new school building.

You will notice on the ground floor plan that provision has been made for living quarters for the Principal. These quarters, as provided, are a self-contained unit. I do not think it advisable to provide a residence for the Principal outside of the building, and much prefer that he resides in the institution.

The building as planned provides accommodation for one hundred pupils, and, as you will notice on the attic floor plan, there will be space available which can be used later and fitted up as dormitories to accommodate an additional forty or forty-five pupils.

It is proposed to heat the building with a vapour system of steam heating, and to light the building by installing an electric lighting plant in the space indicated on the basement floor plan.

I would particularly draw your attention to the toilet fixtures as shown on the plans. You will observe that all of the wash basins and baths are located in the basement and the only plumbing fixtures provided as far as the pupils are concerned, on the other floors, are night toilets for each of the dormitories.

Reverend S. Middleton,
Principal, St. Paul's School,
Blood reserve,
MacLeod - ALTA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6371, file 764-5, part 1)
Regarding the closets, you will notice that no doors are shown, and that a screen is provided in front of the toilets. These screens and the divisions between the toilets, including the divisions shown between the baths, will be built of steel twelve inches from the ground and approximately five feet high. This makes a very sanitary arrangement and easy to supervise.

I may say with reference to the basement, that this floor will be built almost entirely above ground; the basement floor will be approximately three feet below the level of the finished grade line.

The building as planned should face South.

I would ask you to please examine these sketches and, if there are any changes in the layout which you would like to have made, kindly indicate same in pencil or otherwise on the blue print which you are returning.

It would be advisable to discuss these plans with Indian Agent Faunt, before returning the copy to the Department with your criticism.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

I have just received the following telegram from the Rev. S. Middleton, Principal of St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve—

"Plans as received from Ottawa for new school are totally unsuitable - too small - many alterations needed . . . . ."

As I have not received a copy of the plans I am unable to pass any opinion upon them, but consider that Mr. Middleton's judgement is worthy of consideration.

If I may have a copy of the plans at your earliest convenience I shall be much obliged, and if our Society may have an opportunity of expressing an opinion in regard to these, and making suggestions which they consider would be to the advantage of the institution, the results will probably be more satisfactory to all parties concerned than if their wishes and opinions were not considered in any way.

ST. PAUL'S SCHOOL
Blood Reserve, Macleod, Alta.

Feb. 20, 1925.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq., D.C.L.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I have to acknowledge with many thanks the arrival of the 'sketch plans' of the proposed new school.

I have given considerable time to the examination of these plans and have carefully taken each floor as a unit and then considered them as a whole.

Let me say in brief, that the outline and contour of the building is splendid, and I hope the main points of architecture will be preserved in the actual building.

I heartily endorse the heating, and lighting systems, likewise the arrangements of the baths and toilets for the pupils; the screens and divisions between the toilets is a most commendable idea.

Bearing in mind the future development of the school and realizing it is advisable to make any suggestions for alterations now, I am reluctantly forced to the conclusion that the whole building is too small and cramped, to give adequate accommodation for the number of pupils indicated.

On each plan I have attached the suggested alterations and additions. May I give a few explanations for the suggested alterations.

"BASEMENT PLAN."

Would strongly advise that the front of building, i.e., 'Dining Room' be extended eight feet, thus giving more floor space; and the main wall to be continued throughout the whole building up to each storey.
Following out this plan it would give two open balconies on "First Floor Plan".

"GROUND FLOOR PLAN"

By extending the main front, more space would be given for additional rooms, or to enlarge the rooms as already indicated on the Plan.

On this floor no provision is made for a "Reading or Sitting Room" for the senior pupils. It is highly essential that such a room be provided on each side of the building; one for boys, and one for girls. A room to which the pupils can retire during the evening for reading or quiet study is an asset to such an Institution. I have therefore incorporated two rooms on the plan attached.

I much appreciate the Principal's quarters being set aside as a unit; but do you not think they are small and somewhat cramped? The only entrance apparently is through the main entrance of the School, no exit is even made for the kitchen. Moreover, the position of the toilets in the Dormitory above does not favour or the best arrangement, when considering the quarters through which the drainpipe passes. Further, if the Principal is to reside in the quarters as outlined in the Plans received, would it not be much more dignified to have his quarters at the front of the building, rather than at the back?

I have however, attached a plan showing the additions and alterations suggested for this floor, which, if favourably considered, will add to the efficiency and service of the whole building. The addition has been suggested with the main idea of providing more accommodation and better facilities for both staff and pupils.

Whatever rooms are suggested for one side the building, must needs be duplicated on the other side, for there will be an equal number of boys and girls. Moreover, the "Class-Rooms as shown," will not give the required space for the pupils in residence. Four "Class-Rooms" will at least be needed—two for boys, and two for girls. A "Sewing-Room" will also be needed on the boys' side, similar to the one provided on the girls' side of the building.

In the plan attached I have made provision for this by locating these two rooms in the Principal's quarters (as now shown).

I beg to suggest however, that a two-storey building, as indicated on the plan I have submitted, be erected for the Principal. I have also enclosed a print of my old school, showing the idea for the Principal's quarters. This was an ideal arrangement, both from the standpoint of position, efficiency, and utility, for although separated from the main building, our revered Principal, was still resident in the school itself, and had access by means of a corridor as outlined on the attached plan.
You will further notice that I have made provision on this floor for the two "Reading or Sitting Rooms" for the pupils, between the Chapel and Staff rooms.

I add one word about the Chapel. Would it be possible to introduce the Gothic stained glass windows, rather than the open square windows, which are so common?

**FIRST FLOOR PLAN.**

This is the best arranged floor in the whole Institution. It is an ideal plan, may I make one suggestion. No provision has been made for an Auditorium or Assembly Hall. For such an institution it is absolutely necessary to have one. By taking the "Roof" over the Chapel one storey higher, that would give the desired location. Such a room could be used for drill, games, meetings, concerts, reviews etc. Unless this is provided for, there is no room in the building where all the residents of the school can meet in common.

**ATTIC FLOOR PLAN.**

Provision is made on the 'First Floor Plan' for 80 pupils. The Attic floor gives room for 22, this note is located on the Girls side of the building. I would fain suggest, at the outset, that similar provision be made for the same amount of boys on the other side of the building. There are enough children on the Blood Reserve to occupy the space indicated.

I trust I have not wearied you with all these suggestions etc. All have been made from a personal knowledge of the actual requirements for such an institution, and am sure, that if same can be incorporated in the final plans, the future administration of the school will be simplified and greater proficiency will be obtained.

Again expressing thanks for giving me the opportunity of offering suggestions.

Yours sincerely

[Signature]

PRINCIPAL.

P.S. Would be pleased to receive a copy, after revision, of the final draft plans. S.H.M.

March 15, 1933.

Dear Mr. Middleton,

Replying to your letter of the 20th ult., with reference to the plans of the proposed new St. Paul's C. of E. Boarding School, I have sent you today under separate cover, two blue print copies showing some changes in the layout for this building. Please return one of them to me with your comments.

Practically all of the suggestions have been embodied in the sketches, with the exception of the assembly hall over the chapel, as it would be impossible to make provision for this; also, it is not thought advisable to provide boys' and girls' reading rooms as marked by you on the blue print.

You will observe that the building has been extended in the front a distance of four feet; this will provide more accommodation in the dining room and rooms above on the different floors.

With reference to the plans, Rev. Canon Gould called at the office today and has made a couple of suggestions after looking over same. He suggests that on the ground floor, the two staff bed-rooms and the bath rooms to the right of the main entrance be converted into a sewing room, and that the right wing on which is now shown two class rooms and a sewing room, be made into two class rooms with a folding partition between. By this arrangement the two rooms could be turned into one and used when required, as an assembly hall.

Reverend S. Middleton,
Principal, St. Paul's C. of E.
Boarding School,
MacLeod - Alta.
It is also suggested that the sewing room could be used by the girls as a reading room, and the room marked on the amended sketches, on the left wing, as a sewing room, be used as a boys' reading room.

I would ask you to please return the sketches to me as soon as possible, in order that the plans for the building may be prepared without too much delay.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have to acknowledge, with thanks, receipt of your communication of March 15th, which arrived here on 20th, ult. The plans did not arrive until April 5th; in the meantime the additional copies came to hand the day following.

In replying may I say that I am heartily in accord with the approved alterations. The one Staff Room and Bath Room, to the right of the main entrance on the ground floor, could well be used for the dual purpose indicated, likewise, the "Sewing Room" on the left wing.

Canon Gould's suggestion to convert the two Class-rooms into an Assembly Hall will make a splendid arrangement. May I ask however, if provision for a platform or stage could be made at the north end. This would in no way militate against the space required, and yet would meet the requirements of the usual school auditorium.

Proceeding to the Attic Floor, I note with satisfaction, that the left wing is to be fitted up in conjunction with the right wing. As it would not be advisable to have pupils separated entirely from the Staff, I would further beg to suggest that additional accommodation be provided for the necessary Staff, by fitting up a room at each side, as indicated on the plans returned.

Thanking you for the consideration shown.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

The notorious limitation in recent years of the number of plans available for estimating has reacted detrimentally to the purchaser of new construction in the result of restriction of competition. Our object in making this request is based on service to those of the trade interested in having plans and specifications for estimating, and to the Dominion Government in the advantage of full competition in the field of material supply.

It is not our intention to employ anyone other than the Inspector of the Work when the construction of the building is undertaken, so that it will not be possible to accede to their request.

Gardner Smith, of Calgary, received the highest rating and was placed at the head of the list. Mr. Smith has done considerable work of this nature for this Department, his services have been very satisfactory, and we intend to employ him to supervise the work when the school building on the Blood reserve is being erected. Dear Sir:

RE BLOOD RESERVE SCHOOL - CARDSTON, ALTA.

When we submitted our tender on this work, there were a number of special inducements for us to quote a very close figure and certain items of cost which were taken advantage of at that time.

It is now over two and a half months since our tender was compiled and during this time, most of the inducements and advantages which influenced us in bidding very closely on the work, have disappeared or are rapidly disappearing. We gave the Department the whole of the benefit from the situation as it stood at that time. The chief items in this consideration are as follows:

(1) The advantage of being on the ground at Edmonton gave to the prospective work at Cardston, which is almost an exact duplication of the Edmonton contract.

(2) The location of Cardston is about the only district in the West where work of this kind can be advantageously commenced to make it a between season's job, owing to the more open fall and spring as compared with the rest of the Prairie Provinces. Coupled with this, was our desire to find continuous work for the best men in our organization and so prevent in some measure, the continued exodus to the United States.

(3) The opportunity to take delivery during the balance of 1923, of all materials excepting plaster, maple flooring and some interior trim and thus avoid paying the heavier sales tax which became effective January 1, 1924.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6371, file 764-5, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
(4) The exceptionally low price for excavating and teaming which the Indians were very anxious to do between the end of their harvest time and the commencement of farming operations on the land in 1924. It was estimated that a lot of the heavier materials could be moved by sleigh in preference to wheeled vehicles, as this is a cheaper method of transportation.

(5) The lower prices generally quoted for lumber in the fall, which are not available on the approach of the spring demand.

(6) The lower cost of doing work at the end of the year and before operations become general in the season of the following year.

(7) The stability during the balance of 1923 and the early part of 1924, of wage scales. In this connection, kindly note that effective May 1st, bricklayers wages in Toronto will be increased from $1.00 to $1.25 per hour and it is quite expected a similar increase will take place on the same date in Western Canada, and which we believe, will spread to other trades.

(8) By commencing work in 1923, we could have finished by midsummer of 1924 and thus have available, our deposit cheque to use in securing further business for 1924.

You will see from the above that our cost basis and the general situation, is on a somewhat different footing from that prevailing in October 1923, and while we have no reason to think that the Department would not make proper allowance for items of this nature, it seemed to us that we ought to advise you of circumstances as they affect us at this time.

If the work had gone ahead as planned and as contracts almost invariably do, we would have escaped any increased cost and be practically through with this contract before the season of 1924 is well under way, and we trust we may expect to be reimbursed where the delay has increased our unit cost. With the exception of sales tax, it is not expected that everything we buy will cost more, but in some cases, the future is uncertain. To date there has only been one increase and that is in the wholesale base of lumber which has advanced $1.50 per thousand.
It is to be remembered that the American Railroads and the United States generally, have had a very prosperous year and the placing of heavy orders for railroad equipment, rails, etc., and the expansion which may result from the prosperity of 1923, may cause increase in prices of steel and iron goods and this in turn, would affect plumbing and heating supplies and the structural miscellaneous iron work on our contract at Cardston. We are keeping in close touch with the situation and this week have been told by our sub-contractors, The Vulcan Iron Works, that prices are unchanged. They hinted however, there may possibly be an increase in the next month or two. We have also accepted October prices on sheet metal and roofing, cut stone, bricks and cement, so that prospective changes in market price will only be applicable to such supplies as are subject to price at time of shipment.

If it is at all possible, we would like to give shipping dates on some goods and take advantage of winter teaming costs before the roads get muddy, and make such arrangements as are necessary to enable us to get the major portion of the work done before midsummer.

We have taken the Cardston contract on the basis of it being a between season's job and wish to retain as far as possible, the advantage of such a situation. We would therefore, be glad to know if the site has been decided on and we can make some more definite arrangements about the work. If you can give us further definite news by return mail or in the near future, it will be very much appreciated.

Dear Sir:

In consultation with Mr. Orr I have gone over the drawings and specifications of the proposed St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve, with a view to finding economies that may be effected in its erection, and I beg to submit the following reductions and revisions.

In general the building as originally specified and planned cannot be called extravagant, and is well below the average unit cost compared with schools built in Western Canada. The reductions proposed are as follows:

**GENERAL MASONRY.** In general masonry to reduce the thickness of some walls in concrete and brick; to lower some of the story heights by one foot; to substitute common for face brick on exterior walls and where specified inside the building; to reduce the centre portion of the building four feet; and to omit the cut stone trim using concrete in its place. -$6,115.

**CARPENTRY.** To omit storm sash, it being considered that Cardston being the extreme South-West corner of Alberta this is warranted by climatic conditions; to omit cupola on the roof; to omit the rough boarding on the underside of joists and to put sheet metal lining directly on the joists. $2,000.

**PAINTING.** To simplify the painting and glazing by about forty per cent. $1,900.

**LAUNDRY MACHINERY.** To reduce the laundry machinery by approximately twenty-five per cent. $1,100.

**STEEL AND MISCELLANEOUS IRON WORK.** To revise fire escapes and to substitute some steel beams by wooden beams. $300.

**ROOF COVERING.** To omit the asbestos shingles and to use in their place B. C. cedar. $1,418.

**TERRAZZO & MASTIC FLOORING.** To omit all this work and substitute therefor cement finish with patent hardener. $3,068.
Feb. 29, 1924.

PLUMBING & HEATING.
To simplify and revise by omission all separate fixtures using trough or general fixtures. $2,150.

RESIDENCE.
To simplify and cheapen residence in general. $1,100.

SUNDAY REVISIONS, of a minor nature. $900.

The total saving to be effected by using all of the above will be $21,050. If they are all put into effect the building will be cheapened to the very lowest possible extent, and in my opinion, beyond a scale hitherto attempted in a public building.

You will note from the above that the residence has not been omitted, but if it is decided not to build it at this time a further $7,000 can be deducted. Also please note that the design of the roof has not been changed. If a flat roof is put on and an attic formed in the centre portion only, a further saving of from $2,000 to $2,500 can be made.

Respectfully submitted,

Shingles

—Will Not Warp, Cup or Curl

The ordinary flat-grain shingle WILL warp, cup and curl. The reason for this is explained by the fact that when a cedar log absorbs moisture and then dries out, it shrinks more than twice as much in the direction of the circumference as it does in the direction of the diameter. Likewise, when a shingle cut with a flat grain becomes moist and dries, it, too, shrinks more than twice as much in one direction as in another. These unequal stresses and strains cause warping.

Edg-Grain Shingles Make Forty-year Roofs

To overcome this warping, which shortens the life of the roof, we are cutting a one hundred per cent. EDG-GRAIN SHINGLE, which bears the registered trade-mark, "EDG GRAIN." In all EDG-GRAIN SHINGLES, the grain of the wood is vertical and parallel. The result is that when an EDG-GRAIN SHINGLE becomes moist, then dries, all the stresses and strains are absolutely parallel, with the result that an EDG-GRAIN SHINGLE CANNOT WARP. A shingle that won't warp can't check, cup or curl, and will lie close and tight to the roof for forty years and more when laid with Zinclad Nails.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the last paragraph of Mr. Claydon's letter of the 29th ultimo regarding the contract for the proposed new Indian Residential School on the Blood Reserve, I beg to give you the following particulars.

When Mr. Claydon was in the office and we were endeavouring to reduce the cost of the building we took it for granted that the school would be erected on the site, chosen by Indian Agent Faunt, adjacent to the railway. This site appeared to have everything to recommend it, and would of course have eliminated all teaming of materials from the station at Cardston to the site. I carefully checked through Mr. Claydon's original figures for this work and found that he had included a sum of $2,900 for teaming. This amount, in view of the railway siding being installed on the site selected by Mr. Faunt was one of the items deducted from the original tender in reducing the cost of the building from $143,123 to $123,231.

As it has been decided to erect the building on the original site it will be necessary to cancel the credit of $2,900 allowed for in the reduced figures, and same will have to be added as an extra to the contract.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I wish to recommend the following changes in connection with the interior of the proposed school at the Blood Reserve:

First, that 52" burlap be placed along the corridors instead of 36", as the latter would be just high enough to expose the plaster to hand marks, and for this reason the 52" would be much better.

Second, the bathroom arrangements are not quite right. The private bathroom for the staff is opposite the Principal's office, and unless the door is closed, it is not pleasant for the staff to go in and out. Could this room not be put down at the end of the hallway?

Third, regarding the laundry equipment. I understand this is to be the same as that installed at the new Methodist school at Edmonton. The Principal there has not yet started up his machinery and he regrets that it is so elaborate. I believe it would be more satisfactory to have two ordinary electric machines which could be run from the school electric plant, and a couple or three hand power machines, and these could be installed for about $400.00. It is a bad plan to do all the washing in the laundry by machinery. At File Hills we have hand power machines and get good results.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum: Mr. Scott.

With reference to Mr. Graham's letter of the 2nd hereunder, regarding the proposed changes in the plans for the Blood School, I beg to give you the following information.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Mr. Middleton writes me that you authorized him to break 100 acres of land last year, but authority did not reach him until 12th September, which of course was beyond the season any breaking could be done. We do not break land in this country after August 1st.

As this Principal has asked for four horses and I have recommended that they be purchased, my advice is that the horses and harness be supplied, also a plow, and that he employ a man to do the breaking. I do not think we should be called on to break the land and supply the horses besides. We should either break the hundred acres of land by contract, or buy the team of horses, plow and wagon, and have a man break the land, and then hand the team over to them. The approximate cost of four horses, plow and harness would be about $500 to $600. If you would recommend this, let me know at the earliest possible date, so that I can get the matter under way.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am addressing this letter to you, although it is in reply to a letter sent to me signed by the Assistant Deputy Secretary, as I am anxious the matter should come to your notice. It is with regard to a request from St. Paul's School, Blood Reserve, for farming equipment and stock for that Institution. I would ask you to see the original list, as it was from your office I received it.

The first thing I did was to get a price on the articles asked for, and as near as I can make out it would cost approximately $2500, if all the goods asked for in this list were supplied, which of course is most unreasonable. I have gone carefully into the matter, and would point out that the following is a list of what we found on hand:

- 4 Work horses, fairly good,
- 3 Saddle Horses,
- 1 Yearling colt,
- 6 Milch cows, grades, and 2 Holsteins;
- 10 Pigs, 1 Sow,
- 2 sets of harness (work),
- 1 set driving harness,
- 1 Set single harness,
- 2 Saddles,
- 1 democrat, old and dilapidated,
- 1 buggy, old,
- 1 Set light bob sleighs,
- 1 waggon, old,
- 1 Section Harrows,
- 1 Sulky Plow, in good shape,
- 1 Hay mower, in fair shape,
- 60 chickens.

Going through the list I have struck off the following articles, and my recommendations would cost the Department about $2000.00:

Of course if the Department wish him to dispose of the six grade cows he has now, and apply the proceeds to the purchase of a better milking strain, with what assistance he would give us, we might buy twelve cows. Re- Well drilling, Blood Reserve.

Sir,-

In a recent letter I mentioned that a large flow of water had been secured in the well drilled on the approved site of St. Paul's School. A 2nd well was authorized to be drilled for supplying water for the outbuildings and stock. This 2nd well was drilled about 150 yards to one side of the first well. The physical conditions seemed exactly similar, but, strange to say, after drilling 200' without indication of water, and through a discouraging red shale, we had to conclude that the water was missed, and so the drilling stopped. The explanation is that often the water follows narrow veins through the rock below, and if the drill misses the vein the result is a dry hole, even though the water may be close by. The drilling rig has been moved away, and no further attempt has been made to get a second well.

I do not consider that there will be any serious detriment in the failure to get a 2nd well for St. Paul's School, for the reason that the capacity of the first well is so great that there will be ample water for all requirements, about 1000 gals. per hour. It will be very feasible to supply water for outside purposes by connecting up with the school supply, although this extra demand must be taken into consideration in designing the pumping plant and water storage. I am at present preparing data on this subject, and will go into the matter fully in a special letter.

As previously mentioned, the well at the new Agency had been diminishing in the quantity of water to a very serious extent. At first this well was reported to be giving lots of water; but during building operations it was pumped dry, and, on investigation, it was found that less than 75 gals. per hour was coming in. This diminished yield seemed to be caused by sand filtering in and choking the intake, which is a condition often difficult and sometimes impossible to overcome. The well was 180' deep, mostly through clay, and stopped at a rock bottom. As matters stood it looked possible that the well would entirely choke up. After a consultation with the drillers it was decided to drive the casing down and bed it on the rock bottom, thus shutting off the sand, and then drill with a smaller bit down into the rock on the hope of piercing a lower water vein. This has been done, and I am very glad to report that a splendid water vein has been tapped at a depth of 210'. I made a careful test of the capacity of the well, and after baling steadily for
one hour, during which time 600 gals. of water was discharged, we had not succeeded in lowering the water below a point 40' from the bottom of the well. This means that we can count on a capacity of at least 600 gals. per hour, drawn from the solid rock, and free from the former danger of being choked with sand.

I have ordered suitable well piping, sucker rods, working barrel, pump head and jack, and it is expected that the new water supply will be available next Thursday. There is a small gasoline engine on hand that will answer present requirements for pumping.

The well drillers are under instructions from the Commissioner to proceed to the site he selected for the proposed Roman Catholic school, and drill for water there. This site is about three quarters of a mile North of the New Agency, on the main highway to Macleod. I expect this drilling will start on May 2nd.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Re- St.Paul's School. Blood Reserve.

Sir,-

I am in daily expectation of receiving the Department's instructions regarding changes made -if any- in the plans and specifications of the above-mentioned school. It will be my pleasure to co-operate with the Department to the very utmost of my ability in the performance of the duties assigned to me to the end that the completed building may reflect creditably on all concerned.

The contractors have not yet arrived on the scene, nor have I received any recent word from them. At their request, I wired them promptly as soon as the water supply was assured—that was on the 8th inst.—and I have not since heard from them. Presumably they are engaged in ordering their materials, and making arrangements with sub-contractors, etc., after which negotiations the active work on the ground may be expected to commence energetically.

As the site for the School has been finally selected in a locality adjacent to a series of ridges, it has occurred to me that consideration might well be given to an alternative system of water supply other than the system of pneumatic pressure supply shown on the Plans. The two pressure tanks provided in the Plans have a total capacity of approximately 3300 gals. and a working capacity of about 2200 gals. This does not seem a very large supply for an Institution that expects to house 175 people. Then to this we must add the outside demand for live stock, lawns, fire protection, etc. It would mean a frequent pumping of water to keep up sufficient pressure, and, in case of a sudden large demand, such as a fire, the conditions would probably not be very favourable for meeting such an emergency.

Also, it is noted in the Specifications that the water closets throughout the building are to be equipped with "Sloan" valves, and although I have not yet looked up this make of valve, I assume it is of the "flushometer" type, probably similar to the ones in use at the new Edmonton Indian School. While this system is undoubtedly the most modern and satisfactory method of flushing the closets where a sufficient and uniform pressure can be maintained, do you not think we might find them troublesome at St.Paul's School if dependent on a very fluctuating water pressure?

As an alternative proposal to the pneumatic pressure tanks, I would respectfully suggest that consideration be given to the placing of a larger supply tank, say about 25,000 gals. capacity, placed at a sufficient elevation so as to give a uniform pressure throughout the school equal to all requirements, including fire protection. According to the Plans the height of the ridge of the roof above grade is 53', and in determining the desired water pressure it would seem desirable that it be sufficient to enable a stream of water to reach any part of the school and with such a pressure there is no question as to the satisfactory working of the flushometers.

Mr.Fairchild, the Department's surveyor, assisted in preparing the plans.

Supply tank might be placed. These elevations are situated to the South West of the School, and consist of parts of the series of ridges already referred to. The school will face due East.

Taking the grade at the well as our datum, the first elevation we took was a knoll a little apart from the larger ridges. The summit of this knoll is 23.21 ft. higher than the said grade at the school site, and the distance from the well is 1296 ft. This is the nearest and most convenient elevation, but not of sufficient altitude to give the required water pressure unless supplemented with a tower.

The second elevation we took was a point on the nearest ridge, at which the rise above the school grade is 57.60 ft. in a distance from the school well of 2300 ft.

The third elevation was a higher point on the same ridge at a distance of 2648 ft. from the school well. At this point we have a rise of exactly 100 ft. above grade at the school.

At either of the two last elevations given the supply tank could be placed directly on a concrete foundation, but at the first elevation it would be necessary to place the tank on a tower in order to gain the required altitude. This might yet prove the most economical site.

For offices and buildings where severe tests require floors of first quality, it is highly desirable and most satisfactory in service. It eliminates strain because of the soft, resilient walking surface it affords; it promotes comfort because of the treated treadling surface it ensures; permits of easy cleaning because of its smooth, creaseless surface when properly laid with water-proof backing. This makes it very suitable for the large auditorium, as well as for all places where much walking is done by worker or occupant.

The ground cork, suitably coloured, is pressed firmly on a base of strong canvas burlap, the pressure exerted being so great as to effectually key the two, making them practically inseparable. Dear Mr. Orr,

In my letter to you of the 15th last, I referred to the size of flue in the main chimney, and I mentioned that the heating sub-contractor was expected here shortly, and that I would write you further on the subject after talking the matter over with him.

This morning this sub-contractor Mr. Snyder (whom you will remember put in the heating plant at Old Suns School) was present at a discussion on this and other matters connected with the School. Mr. Ernest Clayton, and his partner Mr. Mitchell, were also present. Mr. Snyder is emphatic in stating that the flue area must not be less than $3' \times 3'$, and states that he will assume no responsibility for the efficient working of the heating plant if the flue area is any less than this. The contractor shares in this view. My own investigation, as I stated in my last letter, led me to the conclusion that $3' \times 3'$ was the minimum size possible for correct draft. Under these circumstances, I feel that we have no alternative but to comply with the sub-contractor's demand. I would, therefore, ask you to please give me instructions in the matter. Provision must be made for the larger chimney, if authorized, in putting in the footings.

In the Specifications (Clause 9, Page 15) it states that "If gravel is used in place of sand and broken stone, proportions shall be one part cement to four parts gravel". As no broken stone is available, the contractor has no alternative but to use the river gravel found in the river beds. We have located what appears to be very suitable gravel, with about the right proportion of sand mixed with it. In the event of satisfactory gravel being obtained, do you not think such a rich mixture as that specified would be wasting cement? My own opinion is that we might safely change the proportions to one of cement to six of gravel. The Contractor states that he used the latter proportions at Edmonton with excellent results.

If you sanction this change, I would respectfully suggest that the fuel room be changed from that shown on Plan to one similar to that built at Edmonton, and that a debit and credit account be kept as between the saving in cement as suggested, and the cost of the change in fuel room. I feel convinced that the larger fuel room would prove a tremendous advantage over the other, and this is a way it might be obtained without adding to the cost of the building, for the saving in cement should meet the cost of the larger fuel room. Please include your decision on this point in your wire about the

Dear Mr. Smith:

I have your letter of the 16th instant with reference to the work at the St. Paul's School, and I beg to confirm the telegram sent you today as follows:

"Approve enlarging chimney to thirty-three by thirty-three inches also concrete to be one part cement five parts gravel and enlarging coal room; all changes subject to the condition that money can be saved on other items so as not to increase the cost of building."

I approve of the changing of the chimney flue to 33 x 33 inches, providing there is some way of saving on other parts of the building to offset the additional cost.

With reference to the concrete I approved in the telegram of using one part cement to five parts gravel mixture. I would not care to use six parts as mentioned in your letter. As you know one part cement to four parts gravel is equal to a 1 - 2 - 4 mixture of cement, sand and stone. In the 1 - 2 - 4 mixture the sand is simply filling the voids in the stone, which makes it equal to a one by four mixture.

I also approved of enlarging the fuel room, providing money can be saved other places to offset the additional cost.

With reference to the brick work, it will be satisfactory to leave the mortar without colouring and unbraced.

With reference to the Sloan valves specified, I would like very much to install these valves, but I think that with the uneven water pressure we might have trouble with them. I may say that the Manager of the company was in the office the other day, and he stated that the Sloan valve is guaranteed to operate satisfactorily under varying pressure of from five to one hundred pounds. If this is the case they would work satisfactorily but if we installed them, I would suggest that the plumbing contractor withhold payment on these valves until they prove satisfactory, under the varying pressures. I will be glad if you will give this matter further consideration and investigation, before we decide to change to the low down tanks.

With reference to the doors in the opposite end of the laundry room, I would say that it was my intention that we leave the opening in the wall large enough to pass the machinery through, this opening to be closed with a removable wood partition, so that at any time it would not be a difficult matter to move the machines in or out of the laundry, the doors to remain as shown on plan. If I remember correctly this was what was done at Edmonton.

I will certainly keep you posted regarding any changes that are agreed upon between the Department and the Claydon Co.

Re- St. Paul's School, Blood Reserve.

Sir,-

The work on the above-mentioned building is being pushed ahead with great energy. The contractors have a large crew at work, and large deliveries of materials have taken place. About 20 white men, and about a dozen Indians, are employed on the works, in addition to which there are about 20 Indians camps established near by, from which the Indian teams are hauling gravel, sand, bricks, etc., etc.

Mr. Farnell, the Indian Agent, furnished a list of names of Indians who have no farming duties at present, and it is from this list that the teamsters are selected. The Contractors are finding no difficulty in getting sufficient labourers; in fact so many Indians apply for work, especially for teaming, that the Contractors say they would require several schools to build to give employment to the full number of Indians applying.

The quality of the materials delivered is satisfactory on the whole. My only complaint is in the extent to which the mills reduce the lumber by excessive planing. It does not hold up to the specified dimensions, especially in the dimension two by fours, and two by sixes. These all are finished only 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" thick, instead of 2", and are lacking in width. The joists are somewhat better in proportion. These are coming 1\(\frac{5}{8}\)" in thickness, and also lack \(\frac{1}{2}\)" in width. The Contractors state that these sizes are now standard in the trade. Presumably, it is in order to keep down freight charges that the lumber is so scandalously planed away. I think it would be well for the Architect to note this discrepancy in the sizes of lumber supplied in comparison with the figured dimensions, so that he will be able to secure the needed strength, by specifying larger sizes when he deems it necessary. The lumber is all well seasoned, and sound.

The concrete footings were completed a few days ago. The footings of the main walls were increased to 42" as authorized by you, and were increased to 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" in depth. This was necessary to insure against uneven settlement in consequence of soft places in the foundation soil. The pouring of the concrete walls is now being done, and is about half completed. We are putting in 12" concrete walls, increased to 16" at the wall piers, as shown on the amended plan. The concrete throughout is being proportioned 1 to 5, as authorized by you, and every batch is accurately proportioned. The wall piers will
carried up in solid brick, with cement mortar, instead of part brick and part tile. You probably intended this, for we have no margin of strength to play with in these walls since they were reduced.

The concrete footing of the main chimney, enlarged to suit the larger chimney decided on, has been carefully put in. This footing is 24" deep, in two steps, with the lower step doubly reinforced. All the concrete is setting up well.

Regarding the flushometers specified for the toilets, I passed on the subcontractor (Snyder & Co.) your suggestion that a guarantee be obtained from the makers that the valves will operate successfully under widely varying pressures. Mr. Snyder replies as follows:

"We have written to the factory asking if they are willing to furnish them with a guarantee to work under from 10 to 60 lbs variation in pressure; this guarantee to be that they will wait for payment until their goods have proved themselves satisfactory to the Department's Inspector. Knowing the construction of this valve we know that they cannot work with a difference in pressure of nearly as much, consequently we think we should await their reply before ordering, after which we will take the subject up with you again".

Mr. Snyder evidently means that he will await the reply from the factory regarding the guarantee, and will not order until told to do so. I will notify you of the stand taken by the factory in the matter of the guarantee.

Regarding the Milwaukee Air Pressure system of water supply, the makers report as follows:

"We have your letter of the 22nd ultimo enclosing specifications and drawings pertaining to a water system for a school job. We are very much afraid that the delivering capacity of our #5 pump, which is the largest pump that can be placed in a 5' 5/8" casing, would not be sufficient to take care of the large number of fixtures which you show.

With the number of fixtures specified there would doubtless be times when 3 to 10 of them may be open at the same time, and, with a delivering capacity of only about 15 gals. per minute, the lower openings would get the water and the higher ones be robbed.

While we like to sell water systems we are very careful not to recommend our equipment excepting in cases where we are absolutely sure that it will give satisfactory service."

From the foregoing it would appear that the Milwaukee system is more adapted for suburban and farm installations rather than for large institutions where the consumption of water is bound to be heavy. I am investigating other systems, and hope soon to be in a position to forward full data, with recommendation, on what may be the best system of water supply for the conditions obtaining.
Yesterday I had a call from the Reverend Principal, Mr. Middleton. He has been scrutinizing the plans and specifications very closely—which is always commendable—and, as would be expected, has a few suggestions that he thinks are worthy of consideration.

He very much desires an outside entrance to the Chapel, stating that it may be a considerable time before a Church is provided, and in the meantime the Chapel will have to serve the outside Indians as well as those living in the School. I remember the same request was made when we were building the Kuper Island Indian School in 1915 by Father Lemmons, which request was complied with, and we built a neat iron stairway giving outside access to their Chapel, to their great satisfaction. I enclose a photo showing the said stairway, (which kindly return as it's the only one I have.) It would not be an expensive matter to meet Mr. Middleton's request if it is done during construction, and, in order to keep down the cost, a neat wooden stair would suffice. A much less stairway than that shown in the photo would reach.

Mr. Middleton is also anxious to know what is the intention regarding locker accommodation in the dormitories and playrooms. Nothing is shown on the plans, and he states that these are indispensable.

Other matters he brought up are not of sufficient moment to mention, and consist of little details that can be worked out as the work proceeds. One of the minor points he touched on was the elimination of the steel partitions screening the toilets. In order to bring out his meaning, he instanced the washing of the smaller boys by their supervisor—possibly little more than a girl herself—when at the same time there might be an 18 year-old-old Indian boy performing at a toilet in full view! I replied that, in doing away with the steel partitions, the object was to cut down the cost of the building, and that probably the ordinary demands of decency will be met by substituting a cheaper wooden partition.

Regarding the changes that, in the interests of the building, we have been compelled to make, and which inevitably add to the cost, it has been suggested that we substitute No. 1 E.G. Fir flooring in place of the hard wood floors, in all the rooms where the firm fir wood floors are provided, with the exception of the class rooms, sewing room, first floor dormitories, and ground floor (excepting the kitchen) of the Principal's residence. This saving would approximately cover the cost of changes made, and would still give very good floors. Also, if wood lath were substituted for metal lath above the dadoes throughout the new building, another considerable saving would result. Kindly instruct me regarding your wishes concerning these suggestions. If some means could be found to restore the nailing surfaces for the metal ceilings it would be very advantageous.

It is expected that the brickwork will start next week; and all the indications point to the building being completed well within the time set in the contract.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant with reference to the work on the new St. Paul's School, and I am very pleased to hear that good progress is being made on this contract, also that employment is being given to as many Indians as possible.

The work of construction on the above building is continuing in a satisfactory manner. The contractors have a good organization, and the exceptionally good progress that has been maintained since the commencement of building operations is a tribute to the business methods practised by this firm.

The lumber delivered on the job is all well seasoned, and in all respects but one, is fully up to the specifications. As mentioned in a previous letter, the dimension lumber, particularly the two by fours and two by sixes, have been so excessively planed away that the strength of these members has been reduced by fully 25%. On my calling the contractors' attention to the serious discrepancy in this respect he explained that all the mills have adopted the same standard, presumably to save weight in shipping. The joist lumber is holding up better in size, being \( \frac{1}{2} \) instead of 2", and lacking \( \frac{1}{2} \) in width.

The bricks have been arriving in large quantities, and in great varieties of colour. The amended specifications, as you know, have dispensed with the #1 Redcliffe pressed brick for face work, and in their place we have #1 common bricks. Mr. Mitchell tells me that his firm made a special arrangement with the brick yard whereby, for a small additional sum, sufficient #3 pressed bricks are being sent to do all the face work on the building. Several cars of these #3 bricks have arrived, and I must say that they are a nice uniform even-coloured line of bricks, much better than I expected to get when I saw the change in the specifications. They are red in colour, just dark enough to be distinctive from the ordinary red common bricks, though not a dark red.

The brickwork is now finished to the top of the basement windows of the main building, so it is now possible to see how the brickwork is going to look, and I am well satisfied with its appearance. In fact I believe it will not suffer in comparison with the facework on the Edmonton school. The white joint looks well against the red background. We are making a \( \frac{3}{8} \) struck weather joint.

The common bricks rival Joseph's famous coat, and represent most, if not all, the colours of the rainbow. Some of them are almost white, which was going to be very striking underburnt, but on closer examination, I find that they were as hard as the others. The difference in colour can only be accounted for by the light coloured bricks being made from a different clay than the red ones. Among the common bricks are a good sprinkling of semi-vitrified ones, very dark in colour, and just what we needed to carry out the Architect's request that dark red bricks be used for lintels and trim, and which will introduce a nice bit of detail to the face brickwork. I have personally selected and approved each of these dark bricks, which have been set aside for the purpose intended when the brickwork reaches that stage. The recreation rooms in the basement have been lined with the common bricks, and the walls look passably well considering the material we had to use. It is a good strong job, well suited to the walls of a play-room.

Regarding the elimination of cement mortar, and the changing to lime mortar, in the amended specifications, I would say that in this respect we are not fully carrying out the change called for. I have felt that there is a point beyond which stability might be sacrificed, and it seemed to me advisable to retain some cement in the
mortar, especially in view of the reduction in the thickness of the main walls. I discussed this point with Mr. Mitchell, and he shared my opinion that some cement should be retained to give greater strength. We are, therefore, using half a shovelful of cement per wheelbarrow full of mortar in both the brick and tile work. This is not a rich mixture, and the added expense will not be very great. Mr. Mitchell knows I have no authority to add to the cost of the building, and he states that, even if his firm never get paid for the cement, he would not feel that the cement should be entirely omitted.

The contractors have several men at work making the cast-concrete in the place of the cut stone originally specified. They are fortunate in having two men in their employ who have had experience in this special work, and the results so far are fairly satisfactory. The workmen are performing this work in the open without any protection from sun or weather; which condition is not as favourable for good work as where a shed is provided and the maturing of the concrete retarded. However, until the last day or two the weather has been cool and showery, which was favourable to the work. I will watch this phase of the work closely, and, if necessary, will ask that the freshly-made pieces be covered with boards, and dampened to retard the hardening process. On the whole, the cast-stone is setting well, and will probably serve the purpose as well as the expensive cut stone. It seems somewhat presumptuous for me to assume to do in a few days what it took Mother Nature thousands of years to accomplish!

As stated in a previous letter, we have had a great deal of moisture, starting on the 3rd of June and continuing at intervals throughout the month. The contractors, realizing their crew camped on the site, did not lose a good deal of time, for often a heavy rain would end suddenly, and the men would resume their work. The heavy rains caused our foundations to be flooded a number of times, which caused me some uneasiness in consequence of the added danger of settlement. The contractors always put men to work to remove the water when requested to do so, but, in spite of the frequent removal of the water, some softening of the foundation soil could scarcely be avoided. I have since been watching my foundation walls very closely, and only in one instance have I detected any evidence of trouble. At one point, about 15 feet from the N.E. corner of the main building, a crack has developed vertically across the footing and foundation wall. I noticed it first a week ago, and have observed it closely since. It is a very narrow crack, less than an eighth of an inch in width, and has not opened any wider since I first noticed it. I do not think it will give us any trouble nor affect the building itself in any way. I think the cause of it is in the settling of the foundation soil in places, aggravated, no doubt, by the excessive rains. I am very glad that we were allowed to increase the size of the footings, for, had we not done so, it is possible that we would have had other and more serious cracks from unequal settlement.

There are eight bricklayers at work, and the quality of their work is about average. In the crucial matter of filling all their joints with mortar they are defective, and I am forced to the conclusion that filling all joints with mortar is fast becoming one of the lost arts. However, by dint of frequent reminders, they are doing fairly well in that respect, and I think our brickwork will be better than the average done throughout the country. In all other respects, apart from not completely filling all joints with mortar, the bricklayers seem good careful workmen. The same brick foreman that was employed on the Edmonton school is looking after the brickwork here.

The heating boilers, and the laundry boiler, also the hot water storage tank, have been delivered at the site, and are all in accordance with the specifications, excepting the brick lining of the heating boilers will be dispensed with, and a smoke extension placed at one end, so as to comply with the Provincial regulations in force here.

With regard to the important matter of water system, I regret that I am not yet in a position to make a recommendation for this service, but hope to be able to do so within the next few days.
It seems that our choice will have to be between a sturdy pumping plant with pneumatic tanks for storage and pressure (such as we have at Old Suns School); or with the same kind of pumping plant but with a tower and elevated tank. The latter system has obvious advantages from a pressure and fire protection standpoint, but cost is a prime consideration and may be compelled to adopt the cheaper system. However, I have discussed the matter with Mr. Mitchell (the partner in charge) and he has asked their Winnipeg office to forward to me an estimate and specification of a heavily framed wood tower 60' high, with a 20,000 gal. tank. This estimate is long overdue, but I am told that it should arrive in a day or two, the delay being explained by their having to send away for information concerning the office staff and arrangements with preparing tenders on other work. There is no need for special hurry as there is an abundance of time to install the outside services before they will be needed.

As soon as I have received the necessary data, I will go fully into the matters of water service, sewage disposal, and the mechanical plant for pumping and lighting.

The erection of the steel I-beams and columns has been completed in the basement. Two of the beams have come too long, probably the result of the steel people not having allowed for the rounding off the ends as called for in the amended specifications. The contractor has sent bridging from local men from Cardston who will cut pieces off the beams by the oxy-acetylene process. Probably the I-beams in the floors above will be similarly too long, and can be cut shorter at the same time. In all other respects the steel work seems very satisfactory.

About 30 men are being regularly employed, and I have questioned the time-keeper as to whether or not the schedule of rates mentioned in the specifications are being complied with. He states that the said schedule is being followed, excepting in the case of common labourers, who are being paid 40¢ per hour instead of the 45¢ mentioned in the schedules. Mr. Mitchell informed me that Mr. Orr agreed to this rate if it was the going rate in the locality for common labour. Only one labourer enjoys the distinction of being classified as a "building labourer", and, as he is in charge of the mortar mixing, he draws 55¢ per hour. I have had no complaints from any of the men regarding the rate or wages being paid, so I suppose they are all satisfied. All the men are working 10 hours per day, when weather permits, and it is the intention to work on Dominion Day too.

The Reverend Principal says that his wife is anxious for some pantry accommodation in the Principal's residence, and he wants to know if the space shown alongside of the stairs cannot be converted into a small pantry. I replied that I would bring his request to your attention, and, if you are agreeable to it, we might work in a small pantry in the space referred to, with an opening into same from the kitchen. Will you please give me your views on the subject.

After about a month of cool wet weather, we have suddenly jumped into clear skies and summer temperatures. To-day the thermometer is standing at 82 degrees, but a light breeze from the mountains tempers the heat.

The Indian labourers and teamsters have all deserted us to attend a celebration at Macleod, lasting most of this week. There is no shortage of help, and their places are readily filled.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Claydon, president of Claydon Company Limited, the contractors for the above building, absolutely refuses to submit any receipts, vouchers or evidence of any kind that materials for this job are being paid for. He claims that, under his contract, he is under no obligation to submit proof that his company are paying for materials, and that he should not be asked for it.

To date the sum of $37,782.00 have been paid to the contractors on this job, much the larger part being for materials, and I, as Inspector, cannot say that any of these deliveries are paid for, with the one exception of a receipted invoice for nails and tar-paper which Mr. Mitchell, the partner in charge showed me.

In private building construction, a contractor would be refused a certificate unless he satisfied the Architect, or Inspector, that all bills were paid, or payments arranged for; in which latter case the Owner would be protected by the supply houses executing waivers of claims, liens, or rights to liens against the buildings or lands.

It is possible that in Government work it may not be necessary to enforce such stringent conditions, although in my experience as Inspector for the Department, I have made it my business to see that there should be no aftermath of unpaid bills in connection with building contracts. As this is something in the nature of a test case, I would ask the Department to kindly give a ruling for my guidance in this and similar cases which may arise.

I have not the slightest ground for thinking that the contractors for this school building are not meeting their obligations; I simply lack evidence that they are doing so. As I have no wish to start a controversial correspondence with their Winnipeg office, I will await your reply and be guided accordingly.

Sir,

As mentioned to you when you called at the School building yesterday, a number of points have occurred to my mind as the work of construction proceeds, some of which, perhaps, are worthy of consideration. I will make a mention of some of the things that I referred to. My ideas are offered merely as suggestions, and, as such, I would respectfully submit them for your consideration and decision. I will briefly comment on the items on the accompanying list in the order in which they appear.

1. Fire protection. I would suggest that an additional standpipe be placed in boiler room, with about 30' of hose. I would also suggest that 50' of hose be added to one of the standpipes on the ground floor, in order that the chapel and chancel might be reached by water in the event of fire.

2. I believe that there would be excessively hot water delivered through the faucets, with detriment to same, unless the hot water storage tank be provided with an automatic temperature regulator, by means of which the temperature of the water would be prevented from exceeding a pre-determined point. This applies to the season of the year when the boilers are being fired and the tank heated direct from the steam mains. We have installed "Towson Automatics" in connection with the above named results. I am also advised that the Alberta provincial regulations require that a safety valve be provided for hot water storage tanks drawing steam from boilers.

3. It occurred to me that if it is the ultimate intention to make use of the 2nd floor (attic) dormitories, perhaps night toilets will be required there. If so, should the required rough-in for same be done during construction?

4. Would not a return circulating hot water line prove an economy

5. I have not yet had any definite instructions as to what is to go in the place of the basement lavatory basins that have been cut out of the plans.

6. Is it the intention to have only a concrete floor in the janitor's room in the basement? If this room is to be his living and sleeping quarters, should there not be a wood floor?

7. In the amended specifications the ship-lag boarding of the ceiling joists has been omitted. Unless restored, it will be difficult to secure the metal ceilings; we will be compelled to use long plain lengths of metal, and with no chance of selecting patterns or designs.

9. In the laundry we will have some exposed belts and pulleys, which should be protected with guards. In a city the factory inspector would compel us to install protection guards, for the safety of the operators.

10. The storm sash have been cut out of the specifications. If possible these should be provided before the winter; without them there is danger of frost damage from pipes freezing and bursting; the sash will be greatly increased fuel consumption, the resulting frost will disfigure the woodwork and plaster. Inside basement storm sash would be preferable to the ordinary storm sash placed on the outside of the windows. The inside casements could remain permanently in place, and thus save the trouble, confusion and breakage that invariably results where outside storm sash have to be taken down and replaced with screens in the spring, and the operation reversed again in the fall.

11. Owing to the difference in floor levels between the Principal's house, and the floor levels in the main school building, the pipes which carry the condensate back to the boilers by gravity flow will pass in front of a number of windows. I expect our heating sub-contractor here tomorrow, and I will discuss with him the question involved, and will write you fully on the subject.

12. The radiators specified in the Principal's living room, dining room and library will come slightly higher than the level of the window sills. These should be replaced with lower ones which, if equal radiation is provided, come somewhat more expensive.

13. There is doubt in my mind as to the draft to our bakery and kitchen chimney, when the wind is from the east, owing to the reduced chimney now being 17' below the level of the ridge of the main building. However, we might wait and see.

14. The contractors inform me that they are procuring a name stone.

15. The creosote shingle stain specified would probably be a waste of money. In this climate the creosote stains evaporate and are gone within a year or two. I would recommend a good oil stain of known merit.

16. The Reverend Principal deplores the cutting out of the plan, the burlap originally specified, and states that unless some such protection is provided it will be impossible to keep some of the plastered walls from becoming disfigured.

17. The Reverend Principal is desirous of having pantry facilities in his residence.

18. Should the space over the charcoal be allowed to extend up 24" to the roof, or should we have a plastered ceiling either horizontal or oval, at about the level of the longest member of the trunk and screening same. I think the latter would give the better acoustic properties.

19. In this windy district I think it will be necessary to carry the framing of the spire down to the attic floor joists in order to hold it solid. I believe this was done at the Edmonton school. This method would take about 9'x9' of the floor of the centre dormitory.

20. It is proposed to carry the waste from the laundry and kitchen also the roof water, separately from the general sewage, and discharge same into the main sewer beyond the septic tank. This method is in order to avoid detrimental consequences to the bacterial activity of the septic tank.

21. There is no flue provided for the laundry. This would appear essential, in order that use may be made of a laundry stove for heating the irons. The existing chimneys cannot be tapped from the laundry.
