Sir,

With further reference to the list of suggested accessories, or small additions, to the plans, that I handed to you, I am now able to give more detailed information on some of the items on said list.

With regard to an automatic temperature control for the hot water storage tank when heated by live stems from the mains, a "Power's Automatic Temperature Control Valve" in 12" would cost, installed complete, $220.00. A safety valve attached to same tank, as required by the Provincial regulations, would cost about $17.00.

Regarding the suggested roughing-in, for two night toilets in dormitories of attic, these would cost $137.50. If said roughing-in is done close to existing soil pipes. It is thought that this provision, if authorized, should be made in the winged bath set in the centre dormitory, for the reason that the centre dormitory is not being finished under the present contract, and will not be heated.

With reference to circulating the hot water main running to the various fixtures such as washbasins, baths and sinks, it would be necessary to run a 1" main with 2" and 3" branches, and the hot water main should be covered. This provision would effect a great saving in hot water. The cost would be $220.00.

Regarding the heating of the Principal's Residence, I would draw your attention to some of the special features, and if you turn to the basement heating plant in the main building, you will be able to follow my meaning more easily. You will see that the steam line follows around the walls, and in order to deliver heat to the radiators on the ground floor above, risers are taken from the main at points at or near the radiators. The condensate is also carried from the radiators through Dunham traps, and returns by gravity flow to the boilers, below the basement ceiling.

Owing to the ground floor of the Principal's residence being 30" lower than the adjoining floor of the main building, the pipe line carrying the condensate by gravity back to the boilers, and which line is suspended from the ceilings, will have to be lowered to suit this condition the entire length from the Principal's residence to the boiler room through several rooms of the basement. As there are casement windows to be passed, you will note that this pipe line will have to be 30" from the wall to clear the casement windows when open, and from 3' to 4'-10" below the basement ceilings. As such condition would be very slightly, as well as in the way, I think it would be advisable to overcome the objection referred to in the following way: the dry return carrying the condensate from the radiators of Principal's residence could be vented into the existing dry return of the adjoining main building. It would then be necessary to carry an extra wet return line along base of basement walls from Principal's residence back to the boiler room, and connect to the inlet side of the return trap at boilers. This method is recommended by our heating contractor as the cheapest way out of the difficulty, and would cost in labour and materials $110.00.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6371, file 764-5, part 2)
Would it not be adding greatly to the cost, the best way of efficiently and economically heating the residence would be by an entirely separate steam main from the boilers, with separate returns. This would involve valving the existing steam lines which leave the steam header, and installing a 6" by 3" Tee, and a 3" valve and continue the 3" pipe line to the residence, where it would be necessary to drip and vent this steam line, carrying the drip line under the basement floor back to the boiler. Also, the vent line would be taken into the existing dry return of main building.

The advantage of such a separate heating system for the residence would be that steam could be shut off temporarily from the main building and delivered direct to the residence. This would make it possible to get heat quickly into the home at times when little or no heat may be required in the main building, and would thus save the over-heating of the main building at times in order to get heat into the residence. As the plan shows, the residence, being the farthest from the boilers will be the last to get the heat under the present system. A separate method of heating the residence, such as I have described, with the steam line covered, would cost $600, which, presumably, is prohibitive under present financial limits.

The heating contractor desires the earliest possible decision regarding this point. He has been kept up in connection with the heating of the residence. He is almost ready to lay the pipe lines, but I have asked him to defer same until I get your decision as to what we had better do under the conditions I have described.

We have found a means of putting in lower radiators in the ground floor of Principal's residence, without adding to the cost.

The contractors state that it will be almost impossible to secure the spire unless the framing of the posts is carried down to the attic floor, for which they state the cost will be $45 extra. Please instruct me about this.

If a laundry chimney is built, the cost will be $15, including a concrete footing, and flue lining. This would seem essential if a stove for heating irons is desired. I should know about this soon.

I am awaiting some further cost data; after receiving same, I will make a special report, with recommendation, on a water system for the school. I hope to be able to submit this report within the next few days for your consideration.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.
The work of construction on the above building is continuing in a satisfactory manner. The contractors have a good organization, and the exceptionally good progress that has been maintained since the commencement of building operations is a tribute to the business methods practised by this firm.

The lumber delivered on the job is all well seasoned, and in all respects but one is full up to the specifications. As mentioned in a previous letter, the dimension lumber, particularly the two by four and two by sixes, have been so excessively planed away that the length of these members has been reduced by fully 25%. On my calling the contractors' attention to the serious discrepancy in this respect he explained that all the mills have adopted the same standard, presumably to save weight in shipping. The joist lumber is holding up better in size, being 1 5/8" instead of 2", and lacking 1/4" in width.

The bricks have been arriving in large quantities, and in great varieties of colour. The amended specifications, as you know, have dispensed with the #1 Redcliffe pressed brick for face work, and in their place we have #1 common brick. Mr. Mill tells me that his firm made an additional agreement with the brick yard whereby, for a small additional sum, sufficient #3 pressed bricks are being sent to do all the face work on the building. Several cars of these #3 bricks have arrived, and I must say that they are a nice uniform even-coloured line of bricks, much better than I expected to get when I saw the change in the specification. They are red in colour, just dark enough to be distinctive from the ordinary red common bricks, though not a dark red.

The brickwork is now finished to the top of the basement windows of the main building, so it is now possible to see how the brickwork is going to look, and I am well satisfied with its appearance, in fact I believe it will not suffer in comparison with the facework on the Edmonton school. The white joint looks well against the red background. We are making a 3/8" struck weather joint.

The common bricks rival Joseph's famous coat, and represent most, if not all, the colours of the rainbow. Some of them are almost white, which I was going to condemn as being underburnt, but on closer examination, I found that they were not half as bad as others. The difference in colour can only be accounted for by the light coloured bricks being made from different clay than the red ones. Among the common bricks are a good sprinkling of semi-vitrified ones, very dark in colour, and just what we needed to carry out the Architect's request that dark red bricks be used for lintels and trim, and which will introduce a nice bit of detail to the face brickwork. I have personally sorted out a great many of these dark bricks, which have been set aside for the purpose until the face brickwork reaches that stage. The recreation rooms in the basement have been lined with the common bricks, and the wall looks passably well considering the material we had to use. It is a good strong job, well suited to the walls of a play-room.

Regarding the elimination of cement mortar, and the changing to lime mortar, in the amended specifications, I would say that in this respect we are not fully carrying out the change called for. I have felt that there is a point beyond which stability might be sacrificed, and it seemed to me advisable to retain some cement in the
more, especially in view of the reduction in the thickness of the main walls. I discussed this point with Mr. Mitchell, and he shared my opinion that some cement should be retained to give greater strength. We are, therefore, using half a shovelful of cement per wheelbarrow full of mortar in both the brick and tile work. This is not much extra, and the added expense will not be very great. Mr. Mitchell knows I have no authority to add to the cost of the building, and he states that, even if his firm never get paid for the cement, he would not feel that the cement should be entirely omitted.

The contractors have several men at work making the cast-concrete in place of the cut stone originally specified. They are fortunate in having two men in their employ who have had experience in this special work, and the results so far are found satisfactory. The workmen are performing this work in the open without any protection from sun or weather, which condition is not as favourable for good work as where a shed is provided and the maturing of the concrete is retarded. However, until the last day or two the weather has been cool and showery, which was favourable to the work. I will watch this latter part of the work closely, and, if necessary, will ask that the freshly-made pieces be covered with boards, and dampened to retard the hardening process. On the whole, the cast-concrete is proving itself, and will probably serve the purpose as well as the expensive cut stone. It seems somewhat presumptuous for mere man to assume to do in a few days what it took Mother Nature thousands of years to accomplish!

As stated in a previous letter, we have had a great deal of moisture, starting on the 3rd of June and continuing at intervals throughout the month. The contractors, having their crew camped on the site, did not lose a great deal of time, for often a heavy rain would end suddenly, when the men would resume their work. The heavy rains caused our foundations to be flooded a number of times, which caused me some uneasiness in consequence of the added danger of settlement. The contractors allowed the men to work to remove the water when requested to do so, but, in spite of the frequent flooding of the water, some softening of the foundation soil could scarcely be avoided. I have since been watching my foundation walls very closely, and only in one instance have I detected any evidence of trouble. At one point, about 15' from the N.W. corner of the main building a crack has developed vertically across the footing and foundation wall. I noticed it first last fall, and have watched it very closely. It is a very narrow crack, less than an eighth of an inch in width, and has not opened any wider since I first noticed it. I do not think it will give me any trouble, nor affect the building adversely in any way. I think the cause of it is in the softness of the foundation soil in places, aggravated, no doubt, by the excessive rains. I am very glad that we were allowed to increase the size of the footings, for, had we not done so, it is possible that we would have had other and more serious cracks from unequal settlement.

There are eight bricklayers at work, and the quality of their work is about average. In the crucial matter of filling all their joints with mortar they are defective, and I am forced to the conclusion that filling all joints with mortar is fast becoming one of the lost arts. However, by dint of frequent reminders, they are doing fairly well in that respect, and I think our brickwork will be better than the average done throughout the country. In all other respects, apart from not completely filling all joints with mortar, the bricklayers seem good careful workmen. The same brick foreman that was employed on the Edmonton school is looking after the brickwork here.

The heating boilers, and the laundry boiler, also the hot water storage tank, have been delivered at the site, and are all in accordance with the specifications, excepting the brick lining of the heating boilers will be dispensed with, and a smoke extension placed at one end, so as to comply with the provincial regulations in force here.

With regard to the important matter of water system, I regret that I am not yet in a position to make a recommendation for this service, but hope to be able to do so within the next few days.

It seems that our choice will have to be between a sturdy pumping plant with pneumatic tanks for storage and pressure (such as we have at Old Suns School): or with the same kind of pumping plant but with a tower and elevated tank. The latter system has obvious advantages from a pressure and fire-protection standpoint, but as cost is a prime consideration, we may be compelled to adopt the cheaper system. However, I have discussed the matter with Mr. Mitchell (the partner in charge) and he has asked their Winnipeg office to forward to me an estimate specification of a heavily framed wood pumping plant with a 20,000 gal tank. This estimate is being held up, but I am told that it should arrive in a day or two, the delay being explained by their having to send away for quotations, besides which the office staff were preoccupied with preparing tenders on other work. There is no need for special hurry as there is an abundance of time to install the outside services before they will be needed.

As soon as I have received the necessary data, I will go fully into the matters of water service, sewage disposal, and the mechanical plant for pumping and lighting.

The erection of the steel I-beams and columns has been completed in the basement. Two of the beams have come too long, probably through lack of the steel people not having allowed for the rounding of the walls as called for in the amended specifications. The contractors intend bringing out a local man from Wardston, who will cut pieces off the beams by the oxy-acetylene process. Probably the I-beams in the floors above will be similarly too long, and can be cut shorter at the same time. In all other respects the steel work seems very satisfactory.

About 30 men are being regularly employed, and I have questioned the time-keeper as to whether or not the schedule of wages mentioned in the specifications are being complied with. He states that the said schedule is being followed, excepting in the case of common labourers, who are being paid 40s per hour instead of the 45s mentioned in the schedule. Mr. Mitchell informed me that Mr. Orr agreed to this rate as it was the going rate in the locality for common labour. Only one commoner enjoys the distinction of being classed as a "building labourer", and, as he is in charge of the mortar mixing, he draws 5s per hour. I have had no complaints from any of the men regarding the rate of wages being paid, so I suppose they are all satisfied. All the men are working 10 hours per day, when weather permits, and it is the intention to work on Dominion Day too.

The Reverend Principal says that his wife is anxious for some pantry accommodation in the Principal's residence, and he wants to know if the space shown alongside of the stairs cannot be converted into a small pantry. I replied that I would bring his wishes to your attention, and, if you are agreeable to it, we might work in a small pantry in the space referred to, with an opening into same from the kitchen. Will you please give me your views on the subject.

After about a month of cool wet weather, we have suddenly jumped into clear skies and summer temperatures. To-day the thermometer is standing at 82 degrees, but a light breeze from the mountains tempers the heat.

The Indian labourers and teamsters have all deserted us to attend a celebration at MacLeod, lasting most of this week. There is no shortage of help, and their places are readily filled.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

The credit for the flooring is an exceptionally good one owing to us having found a way to offset some of the extra freight. We can get carload price on Birch flooring from Winnipeg and then ship it with the wood trim, and while this is a higher rate than direct carload from the East to Cardston, it is less than L.C.L shipments. We have also figured on a saving in freight rates with respect to the Fir flooring. If you order ceiling boards as suggested, they can come forward with the Fir flooring from a British Columbian mill which will give us carload freight rate.

The omission of a coat of paint could be very well made and the job would then be equal to the average run of work done at the present time.

We believe the change to galvanized wire would be an advantage. We have found that the copper wire is very tender and the screens need to be very carefully handled, and as a rule, the wear and tear of handling this soft copper wire seems to offset very often its non-perishing qualities. On the other hand, a galvanized wire does not suffer in this regard and further, the galvanized appears to resist the decay of time. I have seen galvanized wire after twenty years wear apparently in as good state of preservation as the day it was put on.

My absence from the City has hindered gathering this data and the progress of the work now demands as quick a decision as possible. If you agree to these suggestions and I hope very much you will, will you please wire us to this effect and shipment of ceiling boards and Fir flooring will take place immediately.

Re water supply. We have gone very thoroughly into the question of suitable mechanical means of providing water supply and have come to the conclusion that a deep well pump driven from a special counter shaft will be the most economical way of solving the problem. This special counter shaft I suggest be placed in line with the Laundry counter shaft and connection made to Laundry counter shaft by clutch. The same engine can be used for the triple purpose of lighting, pumping and laundry machine drive. I have made these suggestions to Mr. Smith when quoting on water tank and tower.

In addition to any figures I have quoted Mr. Smith, we will be pleased to collect the various items under head of pumping, lighting and water supply, and cover the whole of the different items under one proposal should it be found desirable to do so.
To date, Mr. Smith has our quotations for different phases of the water supply and we enclose herewith copy of our letter to him. This correspondence, together with quotations given you re lighting sets covers I think, all phases of the situation, but if there is anything further we can do to assist in closing out the matter, would be glad to follow your suggestions.

We have not been able as yet to find a further saving which can be employed for the putting on of paint dado where burlap has been omitted.

I expect to visit Cardston sometime in August and will make a recapitulation of all that is being done and try if possible, to provide for this item so suggest it be left an open question until that time.

The specification covering blackboards call for ninety linear feet of blackboard to be installed, whereas the actual measurement on the plan calls for one hundred and two feet. We propose ordering ninety feet according to specification as this is the amount we figured on, and distribute this quantity in a way that will give the best possible results. Kindly advise if this is satisfactory.

In answer to your letter of July 2nd regarding laundry machinery, kindly note that we placed order with the Beaver Laundry Machinery in June and in so doing, stipulated that placing the order with them was subject to your approval and they undertook to satisfy you on this point. As far as we can judge, their machines are all equal with those of the Canadian Laundry Machinery Co. All these firms indulge in the usual shop talk regarding the superiority of their products, but as both are being sold and used by the market in general, we do not think there is any fundamental difference between them.

Could you tell anything as to what finally happened over the adjustment of the water service at Edmonton. You will remember when I wrote you after visiting Mr. Graham, he had sent a man to Edmonton who claimed he could easily make the system as it was, satisfactory with very little trouble. I was rather skeptical about this unless they were prepared to have a man spend practically half his time watching the water pressure.

I was in Regina last week and went to Mr. Graham's office hoping to see him and find out just what had happened, but he was away. I saw Mr. Christianson (I think it was) who told me that a change had been made by putting in flush tanks instead of the flushometer valves and that they had altered a wrong connection in the bottom of the tanks, it being claimed that the outlet from the tank was some distance from the bottom.
I did not think there was much to this argument for while it is true that the outlet is placed in the end of the tank, it is as near the bottom as it could be, so for all practical purposes it could be said to be at the bottom or at the side.

In view of the study we have given to getting proper mechanical features at Cardston, I would very much like to know if there was anything happened at Edmonton that has a bearing on what we are trying to do at Cardston.

The thought has occurred to me that owing to Mr. Graham's criticism with respect to the absence of drains on the basement floors as an aid to washing them down, would it not be as well to provide a small grating and drain connecting same to the weepers, and grade the floors to these openings.

Report to W.M. Graham Esq., Sheet No. 2.

The steel I-beams, and C.I. columns were erected as needed, and were fully satisfactory. Several of the beams were sent in too long lengths, owing, no doubt, to the steel people overlooking the change in the thickness of the walls. These were cut to correct length by the laborious process of using a small hack saw. The steel stairs, and the fire escapes are due to arrive within the next few days, and will be set up as soon as possible.

The cast stone that is taking the place of the cut stone originally specified is turning out very well. The contractors were fortunate in having in their employ a man who had specialized in this work, and we are getting the benefit of his experience and skill in the good quality of the artificial stone. It looks well in its place in the walls, and will probably be as lasting as the natural stone, at about half the cost.

The heating sub-contractor (Snyder & Co., of Calgary) is carrying his work forward expeditiously. The heating boilers are set up on their prepared foundations, and the steam mains have been carried through the basement. The same contractor is performing the plumbing and drainage, and the basement drains are now being laid, in accordance with the drainage plans.

The electrician is expected to arrive with his helpers tomorrow to do the electric wiring, as called for in the specifications. He will soon be followed by the lathers and plasterers.

The sheet metal sub-contractor is said to be on the way from Winnipeg. The flat roofs are now ready for him, also the gutters. This contractor will erect the metal ceilings. The contractors state that they have been advised of the restoring of the shiplap to the under side of the joists, (to receive the metal ceilings) in most of the important rooms. This will greatly facilitate the nailing or the metal to the ceilings, and will make it possible to have some detail in the designs, and we should have some variety of patterns for the different rooms to avoid a deadly monotony all through the building which would be the case if all the metal ceilings were alike.

The contractors also informed me that the hard wood floors have been dispensed with in a number of the less important rooms, and E.G. flooring substituted. Also, that the outside painting has been reduced to two-coat work. These economies are to be applied against the cost of the shiplap surfaces that receive the metal ceilings. I consider that the change in the flooring is a justifiable saving for the purpose intended.

On the whole, I can say that the job is proceeding in a satisfactory manner. The contractors complain, frequently, that I ask them to do more than is called for; and there is sometimes ground for honest differences of opinion, but I try to be fair at all times, although, as would be expected, we do not always entirely agree.

The weather during the month has been almost continuously fine, and there has not been more than three hours of lost time. On some days the temperature went over the 90 mark, but the men worked right through it. The health of the camp has been good.

A large force of men are at work, and the supply of labour seems abundant.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Sir,

Although it is only two and one half months since the first sod was turned on this job, the contractors are today completing the framing of the roof. I think a record is being made in the way of rapidity of construction for a country job.

The brickwork is almost completed, and a number of bricklayers, and helpers, have been let go. All the outside walls are completed, with the exception of covering the gable ends. The chimneys are not yet completed; and the brick partition walls in the recreation rooms are yet to be built.

The quality of the brickwork done is only fair. I have had many occasions to make objection to the workmanship of the bricklayers, and to ask for the taking down of work, and the rectifying of small mistakes. None of these things were serious in themselves, but it has only been by frequent and persistent reminders that we have been able to get even passably fair work done. If left alone to do their work in their own way, I am sure the workmanship would be very far from complying with the high quality called for in the specifications. I believe the bricklayers who have had superior training to the average, but it seems to be almost impossible for bricklayers to lay bricks as called for in a specification. However, the contractor states that we are getting an unusually good job of brickwork, much better than is usually performed, but my own opinion is that it is not so good but that it might have been much better! I do believe, though, that the brickwork is superior to what is usually done throughout the country. My principal trouble has been to get the bricklayers to fill all vertical joints with mortar, which practice, I have concluded, might be numbered among the lost arts! The wetting of the bricks, as called for in the specifications, is another feature that is bound to be neglected unless continually insisted on. The tendency of contractors, in their eagerness for speed, are apt to be less concerned with the quality of the workmanship, and this applies particularly to the brickwork. The brick mason of today is trained for speed first, and quality of work afterwards.

The carpentry thus far performed is fully satisfactory. The contractors have a very efficient carpenter-foreman in Mr. Jennings, who has a number of particularly good carpenters under him, and the result of this happy circumstance is evident all through the job. The joists have all been laid, the studs set up, and the rough floors laid diagonally, while the framing of the main roof, including the erection of the rafters, is now being completed. We are fortunate in getting unusually fine, long straight rafters, free from defects, and the roof framing might serve as a model in good material and high class construction. Pains have been taken to securely tie the roof and thoroughly brace it. Care has also been taken to secure the brick walls to the attic floor joists particularly, the outer walls of the dormitories, where we found it very necessary to take extra precautions in this vital respect. The joist timber is good well-seasoned stock. With the exception of the smaller dimension lumber being undersized, all the lumber is satisfactory.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the jacket heater specified for this job, for the heating of the water during the season when the steam boilers will not be in operation, I would say that there appears to be good grounds for believing that the said jacket heater will be found inadequate for the purpose intended.

I have questioned the heating sub-contractor on the subject, and he has reported as follows:

"With reference to your inquiry re- the efficiency of the jacket heater, we find that the heater specified has a capacity of 225 gals. per hour, rated on anthracite coal. We consider that in using the local coal, and with the corrosion that will result from the using of the water from the school well, in a short time the capacity of this heater will be less than 100 gals. per hour. This we consider entirely inadequate, and we would recommend one having a capacity of 600 gals. per hour (rated capacity) as being as small as is practical to use for this service. The larger heater, with a rated capacity of 600 gals. per hour would cost an additional sum of eighty two dollars and fifty cents ($82.50)."

The heating contractor states that his quotation of $82.50 is additional is subject to the order being given in time to enable him to include the heater in a car of radiation that is being shipped from Toronto. The car is due to leave Toronto on short notice, and if it is desired to change the jacket heater to one of more ample capacity, a very prompt decision is asked for.

Awaiting your valued instructions in the matter,

GENERAL.
The structure will consist of a steel water tank supported on a steel tower.
The accompanying plan gives the capacity of the tank, height of the tower and general dimensions.
These specifications contemplate the erection of the structure by the Horton Steel Works, Limited. In case the erection is taken care of by the purchaser, it is understood that such portions of these specifications as refer to the erection are not binding upon the Horton Steel Works, Limited.

STRENGTH AND STABILITY.
The structure will be proportioned to withstand safely the following loads and forces acting separately or in combination:
1. Weight of the structure.
2. Weight of the water in tank.
3. Wind stresses incurred by a hurricane blowing at a rate of one hundred miles per hour from any direction.

The thickness of plates and sizes of all the principal members are shown on the accompanying plan. The details will be capable of transmitting safely the stresses for which said members are proportioned. Complete strain sheets and such detail drawings as will clearly show the dimensions of all parts, methods of construction, connections, etc., will be submitted, if desired.

QUALITY OF MATERIAL.
Except as noted herein, all metal in the structure will be made in accordance with the specifications of the American Society for Testing Materials, serial number A7-16, and modifications as allowed in those specifications will be permitted.

BOTTOM PLATES—PRESSING STEEL QUALITY.
Bottom plates will be made of open-hearth steel to the following specifications:
Maximum Phosphorus, .04 percent.
Tensile strength, 45,000 to 55,000 pounds per square inch.
Yield point not less than one-half the tensile strength.
Elongation in eight inches, minimum percent 1,500,000 divided by the tensile strength.
Cold bend test, 180 degrees flat on itself, without fracture on outside of bent portion.

STRUCTURAL STEEL AND PLATES.
Structural steel and plates (except for the bottom and roof) will be made by the open hearth process, and will be of the grade known as "Structural Steel."
Maximum Phosphorus, .06 percent.
Tensile strength 55,000 to 65,000 pounds per square inch.
Yield point not less than one-half the tensile strength.
Elongation in eight inches, minimum percent 1,500,000 divided by the tensile strength.
Cold bend test, 180 degrees flat on itself without fracture on outside of bent portion for material under 3/4" thick and 180 degrees around two thicknesses without fracture for material 3/4" and over.

ROOF PLATES.
Roof plates may be made by any process, but must be of a grade that will pass surface inspection.

WORKMANSHIP.
JOINTS IN COMPRESSION MEMBERS.
Joints in compression members will be planed so that good contact will be secured between the abutting ends.

PUNCHING.
Punching will be accurately done. The necessary machinery will be in first-class condition.

RIVET SPACING.
In general for work requiring caulking, holes will be spaced not more than ten times the thickness of the thinnest part connected.

Tanks made of plates over one-eighth inch in thickness will be made water tight by caulking only. No foreign substance of any description will be put in the laps between such plates.

FORMING PLATES.

Tank plates, both sides and bottom, will be shaped cold. If necessary, small detail pieces may be bent hot without annealing.

DETAILS OF CONSTRUCTION.

COMPRESSION MEMBERS.

Compression members will be of the open type, to allow for inspection and painting. Splices in main columns will be located as near as practicable to the horizontal struts so as to secure the greatest rigidity.

COLUMN BASES.

Column bases will be designed so that they can be easily cleaned and painted and will not collect water or dirt. They will be of such size and so constructed as to properly distribute and lead the foundations.

CIRCULAR GIRDER AND BALCONY.

A circular girder will be provided at the connection of the posts to the tank to resist the horizontal shear and bending moments due to the horizontal components of the stresses in the inclined tower columns. This girder will serve as the floor of the balcony and will be provided with a substantial steel railing around its outer edge. When the tower columns are verified and the capacity of the tank is not in excess of 12,500 gallons, the balcony will be omitted unless otherwise shown on the plan.

POST CONNECTIONS.

Post connections to the tank, in order to avoid eccentric loading on the tower columns, will be so made that the center of gravity of the column section intersects the center of the connection between the bottom and side of the tank.

RODS.

Rods used in tower bracing will be square or round in cross section, with enlarged screw ends and provision for adjustment.

ROOF.

The roof will be conical in form, made of steel or iron sheets cold riveted and securely fastened to the tank. An ornamental finial will be secured to the apex of the roof. A suitable hatch will be provided near the ladder to permit ready access to the inside of the tank.

LADDER.

Unless otherwise stated in the proposal, a ladder will extend from the apex of the steel rod of the circular girder of the tank. This ladder can be revolved entirely around the tank so that the roof and outside of the tank are easily accessible for inspection and painting. When the posts are inclined a short vertical ladder will extend from the circular girder to a tower column; unless otherwise specified in the proposal, the lattice column itself will serve as a ladder from this point to the ground.

EXPANSION JOINT.

When the tank bottom is elevated thirty feet or more above the ground or building roof an expansion joint will be furnished connecting the riser pipe to the bottom of the tank. In order to prevent contact between two iron surfaces and the consequent trouble from corrosion, this joint will be made with a cast-iron shell having a brass gland and a brass wearing surface. A short piece of pipe machined to proper size will be furnished with the expansion joint. This piece of pipe will not be put in place nor the expansion joint packed by the Horton Steel Works, Limited unless its contract includes the erection of the riser pipe.

ANCHOR BOLTS.

Anchor bolts, if same are included in the proposal, will be furnished F. O. B. cars at delivery point via less carload freight and are to be set in the foundations by the foundation builder. The anchor bolts will be of sufficient size to resist the uplift due to the wind when the tank is empty. Anchor bolts will not be furnished for tanks that go on buildings unless so stated in the proposal.

PAINTING.

Before leaving the shop all steel work, except the contiguous surfaces of tank plates, will receive one coat of graphite or equally good paint. After erection the entire tower and tank, both outside and inside, will be given a coat of graphite or equally good paint.

If the erection is completed with the exception of the painting and at such time the weather conditions are unsuitable for painting, the structure is to be accepted by the purchaser as complete without such painting, but it is expressly understood that a reasonable sum shall be reserved by the purchaser out of the contract price to cover the cost of the painting.
ACCESSORY ITEMS.

(Not furnished unless so stated in the proposal.)

INDICATOR.

The indicator will consist of a target sliding vertically on a channel over a graduated scale. The target will be connected by a brass chain which passes over two pulleys at the top of the tank, to a suitable float inside the tank. The indicator will not be furnished unless so stated in the proposal.

INLET PIPE.

Standard cast-iron pipe will be used for the riser pipe, unless wrought pipe is specified. At proper intervals this pipe will be stayed to the main posts by horizontal rods. The inlet pipe will not be furnished unless so stated in the proposal.

FROST CASING.

Where the climate makes it necessary to protect the water in the riser from freezing a frost casing should be built around the riser pipe. This frost casing will generally be circular in form and built of one or more thicknesses of lumber as the climate demands. At the connection between the frost casing and the tank bottom a removable steel-covered section of the frost casing will be provided so constructed as to permit expansion of the frost casing and allow access to the tank riser expansion joint and other pipe connections. If the work furnished by others is not completed so that the Horton Steel Works, Limited can build the frost casing immediately upon completion of its own work, the purchaser shall compensate it for the expense of delays or of sending men back to construct the frost casing. To avoid danger of freezing in a cold climate, water in the riser pipe must be kept in circulation or some means of heating provided. This casing will not prevent freezing in the riser pipe, if the water is allowed to remain stationary for any length of time. The frost casing will not be furnished unless so stated in the proposal.

ERECTION CONDITIONS.

The purchaser is to provide a suitable unobstructed roadway to the tank site and a clear space immediately adjacent to the tank site for the storage of materials and tools. Prior to the starting of the erection of the tower, excavations for the pipe work or other construction between the foundations, or in the immediate vicinity thereof, shall be filled in and obstructions removed by the purchaser.

Any overhead obstructions to the erection, such as telephone and electric wires or other overhead lines, shall be removed by the purchaser at his own expense before the erection is started.

TANKS ON BUILDINGS.

The erection of a tank upon a building involves concentrated loads upon the walls, foundations and other parts thereof, which necessitates a most careful examination of the building structure, to make sure that the load of the contemplated tank can be safely carried in the manner proposed. If the structure covered by these specifications is erected on a building, the Horton Steel Works, Limited assumes no responsibility whatsoever for the stability of the building, or any part thereof.

CLEANING UP.

Upon completion of the erection the Horton Steel Works, Limited will remove or dispose of all rubbish and other unsightly material caused by its operations and will leave the premises in as good condition as it found them.

TEST.

Upon completion of the erection, the structure will be tested by filling the tank with water and any leakage or other defects which may appear will be repaired so as to leave the tank in absolutely first-class condition. The purchaser shall make connections, furnish and pump sufficient water for making all tests promptly. In case the purchaser is not prepared to test the tank upon completion of the erection he shall compensate the Horton Steel Works, Limited for expense of delays to the erection crew or for the expense of sending men back later to witness test and repair leaks if necessary.

EXTENSION OF TIME.

Any period of delay caused by the failure or default of the purchaser, or by the failure or default of any owner, sub-contractor, or third party, to furnish material, or to do work as agreed upon with the Horton Steel Works, Limited, or by the failure or default of any common carrier to transport material for said works, according to the prevailing schedule of transportation in effect at the time said work was commenced, by strikes or lockouts of workmen, or by accidents, or by the action of mobs or the public enemy, or by war, or by any other acts of lawlessness, interrupting the said work, or destroying or injuring the material therefor; or by the act of Providence, or by inclement weather, or by other unavoidable causes, shall be added to the time for the completion of the structure.
PAYMENT AND TITLE.

Upon default of the purchaser in making any payment when due, or in carrying out any of the conditions of the contract, the entire purchase price shall at once at the option of the Horton Steel Works, Limited become due and payable.

The title to all material furnished by the Horton Steel Works, Limited for this structure until fully paid for, shall be and remain in the Horton Steel Works, Limited and all such materials shall at all times be and remain, and shall be considered as personal property, notwithstanding the mode or manner in which such personal property shall be annexed or attached to the realty, and in the event of any default by the purchaser, the Horton Steel Works, Limited may at once and without process of law, take possession of any and all material used or intended for use in this structure, and remove same from the premises as and for its property.

INDEMNITY.

The Horton Steel Works, Limited agrees to indemnify the purchaser from all claims and demands for damages or compensation from injuries to persons or property caused by the negligence of the Horton Steel Works, Limited in the erection of this structure.

PERMITS.

The Horton Steel Works, Limited will furnish such stress sheets and plans of the water tower as may be necessary to secure building permits and licenses for the erection of the structure. Such building permits and licenses must be procured by the purchaser at his own expense, before erection is started.

FOUNDATIONS.

The purchaser shall furnish the foundations including the reinforcing steel, unless otherwise stated in the proposal. The foundations shall be built and the anchor bolts set as shown on plans which the Horton Steel Works, Limited will furnish. The cost of any delay in starting erection, which may be caused by the foundations being improperly constructed or the anchor bolts being incorrectly set, shall be borne by the purchaser.

In furnishing the foundation plans it must be clearly understood that the Horton Steel Works, Limited acts only in a purchasing capacity and assumes no responsibility whatsoever for the load the soil will safely sustain. Unless notified by the purchaser of unusual soil conditions, the foundations will be designed for a maximum pressure on the soil of two tons per square foot. They will also be of sufficient weight to resist, with a proper factor of safety, the uplift due to wind forces.

The excavation must be carried to such a depth that the foundation footings will be both below the frost line and on firm soil, deeper than shown on the plan if necessary to accomplish these results.

The footings will consist of concrete piers with the necessary anchor bolts. In the lower part of the foundations the concrete must be made of one part Portland cement, three parts sand and five parts broken stone or gravel. The cement must be of the best quality and free from any foreign material. The sand must be fine, sharp and clean, free from any clay or loam. The broken stone or gravel must not be larger than 2" in any dimension and must be entirely free from dirt or any foreign substances. The materials must be thoroughly mixed and immediately deposited in place. Any concrete which has been allowed to even partially set must not be put into the foundations. The concrete in the top 12" of the foundations must be enriched by doubling the amount of Portland cement specified above.

When the foundations are built by the Horton Steel Works, Limited and conditions are found such as to require extra excavation, wet excavation or more concrete, materials or labor than is called for on the foundation plans, the Horton Steel Works, Limited shall be compensated for the additional expenses involved.

Upon completion of the foundations the foundation builder shall backfill the excavation and shall grade level the area between the piers and the immediate vicinity thereof to approximately one foot below the tops of the piers.

GUARANTEE.

The Horton Steel Works, Limited guarantees for one year the structure it furnishes under these specifications to the extent that it will repair any defects due to faulty design, workmanship or material, which may appear in the structure during that period.
Report on Sewage Disposal for St. Paul's Residential School, Blood Reserve.

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith a blueprint showing a plan of sewage disposal designed for this institution. It is along the lines recommended by Mr. R. B. Owens, F.A., R.S., the Provincial Sanitary Engineer, who is a noted authority on the subject. It is similar in principle to the one that was installed at the Indian Hospital at Gleichen.

This method of sewage disposal is known as the "Aerobic Bed System" and the special feature about it is that the solids of the sewage are held in suspension on the perforated shelves during the interval between the siphonic emptying of the tank and the rising again of the liquid to the high water mark. In this way the solids are exposed directly to the action of the aerobic bacteria most of the time; and through this agency, the oxidation and liquefying of the solids take place more readily than would otherwise be the case. When the rising liquid reaches the high water mark the siphonic action again takes place, resulting in the complete emptying of the tank of all liquid, and leaving the solids again exposed to the destroying aerobic bacteria. The resulting effluent is said to be very much better than that from the deep anaerobic tank. As the liquid rises in the large chamber it simultaneously rises in the siphon chamber, being admitted through openings at the floor level of the main tank, and, as stated before, when the liquid reaches the high water level (about 15" from bottom of bell) the emptying of the tanks again takes place.

In the Plan, as you will observe, I show two chambers. The sewage enters in the centre, and falls on a baffle board controlled by floats. This feature I copied from the one in use at the Edmonton Indian School, but, since drawing the plan I have decided that it is not entirely reliable, and I would substitute it for an ordinary Y shaped tile, with one fork of the Y discharging into one chamber, and the other branch discharging into the opposite chamber. The Y could not get out of order, or fail to function; and in the event of it being necessary to shut...
off one tank for any purpose (such as for repairing siphon, or cleaning out, etc.) all that would be necessary to do to control the intake would be to block one end of the Y, and thus throw all the sewage into the other chamber.

The perforations in the shelves should not be directly over one another, but should be "staggered".

I propose to locate the tank within 100' of where the main sewer leaves the school building. The outlet will be in a depression, or small watercourse (dry most of the time), distant about 750' from the school. I have the exact survey figures for this sewer line, furnished by Mr. Fairchild, the Department's Surveyor. We have just barely sufficient fall in the line, but by exercising care, and laying the pipes with the help of an instrument, we can get by all right.

As the final effluent discharges at the outlet of the system, it will inevitably form a considerable pool there, owing to the slightness of the fall to the watercourse. For this reason, particularly, it is important to install a scheme of sewage disposal that will give the greatest purification to the sewage in order to avoid a most objectionable nuisance from bad odours. The aerobic bed system is said to be very superior in its action to the ordinary deep tanks, and there should be the minimum amount of smell from such a system.

With regard to cost, the Gladson Co. have quoted a price of $2100.00 for the entire sewer line and septic tank, built according to plan. This included 750' of trench, averaging about 5' in depth, laying of the 6" vitrified tile supplied by them, and installing the aerobic tank, complete in every respect. They also offer to do it on the basis of proven cost, plus 10%. My own opinion is that a saving would be effected in having it done on the cost plus basis. At Gleichen we saved about $300.00 by having the Hospital sewage plant put in this way, as compared with the contractors' tender.

As the season is advancing, I am sure you will see the desirability of an early decision regarding this essential service. Awaiting your valued instructions in the matter,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

E. Gardner Smith
Inspector of Construction.

Sir,

Since my last report, written on the 31st of July, steady progress has been maintained by the contractors, and it now seems practically assured that the contract will be completed well within the time-limit (December 15th).

The brickwork is now completed, and all the brick masons have gone. It is the intention to bring back a local bricklayer from Cardston to do some remaining beam filling between the wall plates and the under side of the roof of the Chapel; and also to do some pointing up where other trades have found it necessary to make passages through the masonry walls.

In my last report I mentioned the ever-present difficulty in getting bricklayers to perform their work in accordance with a strict specification. As a class, they are the most independent men that come on a job, and, as they are difficult to replace, it becomes necessary to deal with them tactfully. By precept, and moral suasion, and innumerable reminders, I think I may say that the workmanship of the bricklayers has turned out much better than the average work done, and with the minimum of friction as between them and myself. I had very little confidence in the brick foreman, and found it necessary in several instances to request that work be taken down and done over again. My requests were always complied with promptly, and as the brickwork was very closely checked by me, the mistakes were rectified before any had gone far.

The cast-stone work is completed and in place on the building. It seems to be very satisfactory, and looks almost as well as the expensive cut stone which it replaced in the specifications, although it remains to be seen whether it will withstand the test of time as well as stone.

The concrete floors are now being put down in the base-
ment, as specified. A foundation of coarse gravel and broken bricks was first laid over the clay soil.

The installing of the heating system is well advanced. The two heating boilers were set up some time ago, but are yet to receive their specified covering. The steam mains, and return lines, have been carried throughout the basement below the ceilings, and the risers and returns carried up to the various rooms on the floors above. We have made a number of slight changes where the design or construction made changes necessary, but none were of sufficient importance to report. Mention was made of the desirability of a separate wet return from the Principal's residence, and this was duly authorized at a cost of $110.00. The coal bin shown on the plan was changed to one 2½ times as large, built with its reinforced roof finishing at grade level. This large underground bin will be of tremendous advantage to the school during all the years that coal will have to be stored there. It has a capacity of two large car-loads. The additional cost of the larger coal storage was estimated at $550.00, and the Department authorized the outlay, provided a saving in something else could be made, and applied on the coal bin. This was accomplished by changing the concrete specification from 1 of cement & 4 of gravel, to a 1 to 5 mixture, to which the Department's Architect had consented. The saving in cement was credited to the coal bin.

The hot water storage tank has been referred to by me in a former letter. I drew attention to the need of an automatic temperature regulator, and I have not received any instructions regarding this very desirable attachment. The advantage of a temperature regulator was explained in my letter of July 17th, and its cost given in a letter dated July 21st.

The work of installing the rough plumbing is also well advanced, and I expect to subject the soil, waste and vent pipes to the water test within the next day or two. The concrete floors being now put down in the basement are not over drain pipes, and will not be until all joints are found to be tight. The roughing-in for night toilets in attic dormitories is being done, as instructed by you.

The sheet metal contractor is carrying his work forward in a satisfactory manner. The gutters have been lined with galvanized iron, and extending 30" on roof as specified. The galvanized work on spire, roof valleys, and porches has been done, and flashing is being put in place, as needed. This contractor seems very efficient in his line of work. The metal ceilings will
have their nailing boards restored in most of the important rooms. The contractor informs me that the ceiling material has been shipped and is without variety in design. That means that we will have long plain sheets for the rooms where there are no ceiling boards, and throughout the other rooms, where a range of patterns might have been given, we will have a monotonous design for all these rooms. As it was possible to give a variety of ceiling designs for the various important rooms, without adding appreciably to the cost, if at all, I think it is unfortunate that some variation in ceilings was not provided for. However, perhaps my complaint is sentimental rather than practical.

The electrical contractor has his conduit pipes laid throughout most of the building, and in accordance with the wiring plan that was sent to the Department's Architect for approval. In this work, too, there were a few instances where slight changes from the plans were made to meet the exigencies of construction, or to meet a special need. On completion, this work will be tested by the authorized inspector of the Western Canada Fire Underwriters, and a certificate of inspection procured. The electric generating plant is not included in the general contract, and I intend dealing with this requirement in a separate report on the needed auxiliary services.

The work of lathing and plastering is now under way. The metal lath has been put on the walls where specified, and the wood lath used in the Principal's residence and the ceilings of the attic dormitories. The plastering just started yesterday. Three plasterers are at work, with the necessary labourers.

The shingling of the roof is partly completed, and is being well done. The cedar shingles are of good quality, entirely free from knots. The felt and gravel roofs, and the chapel roof, have not yet been started.

The painting of the spire was done yesterday and today, in a French grey colour. It is the intention to stain the shingles in a dark green color, using an oil stain instead of creosote; and to paint the outside trim in a light stone shade, just slightly off a cream. The painter is the same contractor that did the painting work on the Edmonton Indian School.

The steel stairs have been set up, and are being used in the work of construction. As the mastic floors have been dispensed with, we will be unable to procure that material for the treads of the stairs, so will have to make treads of cement, and
make use of a cement hardener. The fire-escapes have not yet been erected, but the parts are all here, and will be put up soon.

The combined kitchen & bakery chimney has been built to the reduced height called for in the amendments. I will be very agreeably surprised if the draft is good, on account of it finishing below the ridge of the main building. The main chimney has been completed to the enlarged flue size insisted on by the heating contractor. A brick chimney has been built in the laundry to accommodate the stove needed to heat the irons.

The carpentry work throughout has been satisfactory, and I have found the carpenter-foreman, Mr. Jennings, a very efficient and painstaking builder. He has a staff of first class carpenters assisting him, selected by himself, and up to the present time I have had no cause for complaint in connection with that branch of construction.

The general contractors (Claydon Co., Ltd) are represented on the job by Mr. W. Mitchell, who is a partner in the business. This gentleman was in charge of the construction of the Edmonton Indian School built last year, and has been applying himself here with energy to the carrying of the work forward with all possible rapidity. Supplies have been purchased and delivered well in advance of requirements, and costly delays, so common in country construction, have been avoided.

Regarding the auxiliary services of pumping plant, water storage, electric generating plant, lighting fixtures throughout the building, sewage disposal, etc., it is my intention to make a special report to you on these essential requirements, either in person or by letter, as you may direct. As the season is advancing, it is important that consideration be given to these things as soon as conveniently possible.

During the plastering of the building there will be a slackening in the carpentry work, and it would be easily possible for me to be absent for a few days without detriment to the building, in case you wish me to report to you personally.

The weather has been very favourable throughout the month, only two half-days being lost from rain. The supply of labour continues abundant, although when harvesting starts, the surplus labour may be absorbed.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector.

Sir,

With regard to the auxiliary services that will be needed in connection with St. Paul's School, I beg to submit herewith proposals for installing same.

WATER STORAGE

I have given consideration to three methods of storing water, viz:
1st, by means of a steel tower and steel tank; 2nd, by means of a framed wooden tower and wood tank; and 3rd, by means of pneumatic pressure tanks. I will review each of the three methods in the order in which I have mentioned them.

Steel Tower & Tank. I enclose herewith a blue print of a 60' steel tower, and a 20,000 gallon steel tank, with specifications fully describing same, as submitted by Horton Steel Works, Ltd. of Bridgburg, Ontario. This is a modern and high class plant, and would provide an abundant reservoir, and give ample pressure for fire protection. The supply of water in the tank would be adequate for all the requirements of the institution, for fire protection, for lawns and gardens, and for outside purposes such as the watering of dairy cows, work horses and other live stock. Many industrial plants, and private institutions, even where city water pressure is present, are adopting this means of independent supply, largely as an extra precaution against fire losses. The Provincial Government of Alberta are using these steel towers and tanks in nearly all of their important institutions. The price quoted ($5190.00) plus say an additional $500.00 for foundations and frost protection, making a completed price of about $5700.00, is not excessively high for a plant of this kind erected at the school site here. Were it decided to adopt this method of water storage and pressure, competitive prices from two or three other firms might well be obtained.

Wooden Tower & Tank. I am also enclosing a blue print of what is known as a "railway type" of tower and tank, such as is largely
used in Western Canada, with satisfactory results. The Claydon Co. have submitted a quotation of $4051 for the tower, tank and housing, as shown on the blue print. If the housing is omitted, and the tank heated in winter by a steam line from the heating boilers of the school, the price would be reduced by $1102.00, but we would have to add the cost of the steam line and protection covering, amounting to $500.00, which would bring the total price up to $3459.00. This price would include the 60' framed tower, and 20,000 gal. wood tank, with open tower but housed tank, connected to the pumping plant, and heated through protected steam pipes rendered frost proof, and provided with an overflow. This plant would also be very satisfactory, not as durable as the steel plant first quoted, but at quite a saving in first cost. Should this proposal be considered, it would not be necessary to house the wooden tower; the price last mentioned, ($3459.00) would apply. The necessary foundations are included.

Pneumatic Pressure Tanks. When pressure tanks are considered, we at once abandon the idea of a large reservoir of water for fire protection, and a reserve against breakdowns of pumping plant. Two 4'x 18' standard steel pressure tanks, installed complete, with the usual water and pressure gauges, each tank having a capacity of 1500 gallons, and a working capacity of about 1000 gals., and guaranteed suitable for a pressure of 60 lbs would cost $996.00, as quoted by Claydon Co.Ltd. The total working capacity of this plant would be scarcely 2000 gals. on one pumping. The pressure would vary between almost nothing to 50 lbs. Frequent pumpings would be necessary to keep up a reasonably fair pressure, especially for the higher floors, and for fire protection. Should an outbreak of fire occur at a time when the pressure happened to be low, the facilities for fighting the fire would be far from good. There would be no reserve of water in case of breakdown of plant; nor would there be water to spare for outside stock or gardening. The supply of water in the school well is very abundant, and this well will furnish more water than can possibly be used. I witnessed a test of 1000 gals. per hour. The work of construction, which made heavy and frequent demands on the water, did not noticeably affect the supply. But if the water has to be delivered through the pressure tanks, very frequent pumping will have to be resorted to.

In addition to the price quoted for the pressure tanks ($996.00) it will be necessary to add another $476.00, as quoted by the contractors, for preparing a suitable chamber to receive the tanks. Such a chamber would require to be 12'x 21', with 7" wall, 3" con. floor, 5" re-inforced concrete roof. The best place to install the tanks would be in a separate chamber built at the West end of the boiler room on the outside of the building, with said chamber finishing on the level of the boiler floor, and with access to the tanks through a 4' opening in the boiler room wall. It will also be necessary to provide a 2½" air compressor in order to get anything approaching
the full efficiency out of the tanks, and will cost $100.00, including piping having check and relief valves, belting and the necessary pulleys to connect to the transmission line. The prepared chamber at $476.00, and the compressor at $100.00, added to the cost of the tanks in place, would bring the total cost of the two pressure tanks installed complete and connected up with the water system, to $1572.00. This would be a very good plant, as pressure tank systems go, but would have the drawbacks referred to. There is no available space anywhere in the basement for pressure tanks. If placed in the prepared chamber they would always be accessible for inspection or repair; the re-inforced roof would be sufficiently below grade to avoid frost trouble.

PUMPING PLANT.

In considering a pumping plant for St. Paul's school, we can rely on having an abundant supply of water to draw from. The well was drilled to a depth of 140', and the water rose in the casing to within 30' of the surface. I witnessed a thorough testing of this well, and found the capacity to be in excess of 1000 gals. per hour. In fact we were unable to lower the level of the water below a point 40' from the surface of the ground even when bailing at the rate of 1000 gals. per hour, which means that we still had 100' of water in the well. There is sufficient water in this well for all possible needs of the institution, including the barn and live stock.

Proposal No.1. Hoosier pattern working head #1601, having adjustable strokes 6-9-12" at 30 strokes per minute.

Cylinder to be 24" all brass working barrel 30" long connected with pump with 3" galv. plugged and reamed drop pipe and 1 5/8" ash rods with forged couplings. Cylinder to be placed 50' below pump head.

The discharge pipe to pressure tanks, or elevated tank, shall be 3" galv. piping, twinned to the two tanks with each tank having 2" gate valves. There would also be placed on this line one 1" relief valve, and one 2" horizontal swing check valve having leather seat.

The necessary pulleys, belting, etc., is included, to connect up with the transmission line in the machinery room for the lighting and laundry plants.

The last-described proposal consists of a heavy duty, large capacity pumping plant. It would perform its work without strain, and should last for many years without repairs. Should pressure tanks be adopted for water storage, this last-mentioned pumping plant would fill the tanks with the minimum of pumping, and a fair pressure could be more readily maintained than with the lighter plants of less capacity. This is an important point from the standpoint of fire protection.

In each of the 4 proposals the capacity mentioned is the maximum, and obtained on the longest strokes. The speeds are as determined best by hydraulic engineers. A high speed pump does not work satisfactorily in any case, and particularly when delivering water against pressure in a storage tank. The capacities mentioned are in American gallons, which is about 20% less than Imperial gallons.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

I beg to submit herewith the following details with reference to the installing of a water system, sewage disposal system and electric lighting plant, required for the new Indian Residential School now being built on the Blood Reserve in Alberta.

WATER SYSTEM.

With reference to the water system there are three methods to consider with regard to the storing of water, first, by means of steel tower and steel tank; second, by means of a framed wooden tower and wooden tank; third, by pneumatic pressure tanks.

The amount of water required per day for this building will be approximately 3,600 gallons. This is based on allowing 20 gallons per day for each of the 180 inmates of the building. This is the minimum. In addition water will be required for the stock.

STEEL WATER TOWER.

With reference to the steel tower and tank this system would include a sixty foot steel tower with a 20,000 gallons steel tank. This would give a modern highclass plant and provide an abundant supply of water with ample pressure for fire protection and outbuildings. This type of tower would cost complete, $5,700.

WOODEN TOWER AND TANK.

If this type of water storage was considered it would include a wooden tank with a capacity of 20,000 gallons, sixty feet high, supported on wooden frame construction. This tank is known as the railway type, and is largely used in Western Canada with satisfactory results. This plant would be satisfactory, is not as durable as the steel plant first quoted, but has a saving in first cost. The cost would be approximately $3,469.

PNEUMATIC PRESSURE TANKS.

When the pressure tanks are considered we at once abandon the idea of a large reservoir of water for fire protection and with a reserve against breakdown or pumping plant. Two 4 x 18 standard steel pressure tanks installed complete with the usual water and pressure meters would cost $1,572.

The total working capacity of these tanks would be approximately 2000 gallons, and the pressure would vary from almost nothing to 50 lbs. depending on the amount of water in the tanks. One of the main advantages of the elevated tanks before mentioned is that there would be a constant and even pressure at all times.

To all of the above prices it will be necessary to add the cost of installing a pumping plant complete. This will cost approximately $641, and will be practically the same for whatever style of water storage is used.
MEMORANDUM:

In connection with the sewerage system for the building it will be necessary to build a septic tank. Owing to the slight fall from the building for the installing of a septic tank it is important to provide a scheme of sewage disposal that will give the best purification to the sewage in order to avoid most objectionable nuisance from bad odours. It is therefore proposed to build a tank on the aerobic bed system. This tank is designed along the lines recommended by Mr. Owen, Provincial Sanitary Engineer for Alberta. The cost will be approximately $2,100.

ELECTRIC LIGHTING PLANT.

With reference to the lighting plant it will be necessary to install a plant consisting of a 5k. 240 volt generator, 10 H.P. gasoline engine with storage batteries, fuel tank, etc. This gasoline engine will also be utilized for the operating of the pumping plant, and the system installed will necessarily have to be a belt driven outfit. The cost of this plant complete will be approximately $2,400.

The various propositions contained in the above report may be summarized as follows:

WATER STORAGE:
Steel tower and tank, 30,000 gallon capacity, $6,700.00.
Frame wooden tower and tank capacity 20,000 gallons, $2,550.00.
Pneumatic pressure tanks working capacity 2000 gallons, $1,672.00.

To all of the above projects will have to be added the cost of the pumping plant, which will be approximately $841.00.

SEPTIC TANK: Septic tank complete, $2,100.00.

ELECTRIC LIGHTING SYSTEM: complete, $2,400.00.

With reference to the above mentioned works I beg to recommend that the Clayton Co. be authorized to proceed with the erection of a wooden tower and wooden tank, the installing of a pumping system and the building of a septic tank.

With reference to the electric lighting plant before this is authorized I would recommend that the Inspector of Construction be authorized to instruct the Clayton Co. to submit a price for the different types of lighting plants of the size required, and that they be instructed to install the plant which will give the best results at the least cost. A full report should be submitted to the Department by the Inspector before the work is authorized.

I may say, with reference to the above mentioned work that there is an item of $4,700 stipulated in the specifications to partly defray the cost of the water and sewerage systems.

ARCHITECT.

A few days ago we had a visit from Rev. Mr. Middleton (Principal) and Miss McGary (Matron) and, after a tour of inspection through the building, they requested me to draw to your attention two or three small matters that have not yet been dealt with, as follows:

I have discussed the matter with the contractors, and they quote a price of $137.50 to carry steam and return lines from the pipes that pass through the kitchen to the balcony, and provide 66' of radiation, with the necessary valves, traps, etc.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

I beg to submit herewith the following details with reference to the installing of a water system, sewage disposal system and electric lighting plant, required for the new Indian Residential School now being built on the Blood Reserve in Alberta.

WATER SYSTEM.

With reference to the water system there are three methods to consider with regard to the storing of water, first, by means of steel tower and steel tank, second, by means of a framed wooden tower and wooden tank, third, by pneumatic pressure tanks.

The amount of water required per day for this building will be approximately 3,600 gallons. This is based on allowing 20 gallons per day for each of the 180 inmates of the building. This is the minimum. In addition water will be required for the stock.

STEEL WATER TOWER.

With reference to the steel tower and tank this system would include a sixty foot steel tower with a 20,000 gallon steel tank. This would give a modern highclass plant and provide an abundant supply of water with ample pressure for fire protection and outbuildings. This type of tower would cost complete, $5,700.

WOODEN TOWER AND TANK.

If this type of water storage was considered it would include a wooden tank with a capacity of 20,000 gallons, sixty feet high, supported on wooden frame construction, known as the railway type, and is largely used in Western Canada with satisfactory results. This plant would be satisfactory, is not as durable as the steel plant first quoted, but has a saving in first cost. The cost would be approximately $3,459.

PNEUMATIC PRESSURE TANKS.

When the pressure tanks are considered we at once abandon the idea of a large reservoir of water for fire protection and with a reserve against breakdown of pumping plant. Two 4 x 18 standard steel pressure tanks installed complete with the usual water and pressure gauges would cost, $1,572.

The total working capacity of these tanks would be approximately 2000 gallons, and the pressure would vary from almost nothing to 50 lbs, depending on the amount of water in the tanks. One of the main advantages of the wooden tanks before mentioned is that water level can be constant and even pressure at all times.

To all of the above prices it will be necessary to add the cost of installing a pumping plant complete. This will cost approximately $841, and will be practically the same for whatever style of water storage is used.
MEMORANDUM: MR. SCOTT.

SEPTIC TANK.

In connection with the sewerage system for the building it will be necessary to build a septic tank. Owing to the slight fall from the building for the installing of a septic tank it is important to provide a scheme of sewage disposal that will give the greatest purification to the sewage in order to avoid a most objectionable condition from bad drainage. It is therefore proposed to build a tank on the aerobic bed system. This tank is designed along the lines recommended by Mr. Owens, Provincial Sanitary Engineer for Alberta. The cost will be approximately $2,100.

ELECTRIC LIGHTING PLANT.

With reference to the lighting plant it will be necessary to install a plant consisting of a six K.W., 110 volt generator, 10 H.P. gasoline engine with storage batteries, fuel tank, etc. This gasoline engine will also be utilized for the operating of the pumping plant, and the system installed will necessarily have to be a belt driven outfit. The cost of this plant complete will be approximately $2,400.

The various propositions contained in the above report may be summarized as follows:

WATER STORAGE:
Steel tower and tank, 20,000 gallon capacity, $5,700.00.
Frame wooden tower and tank capacity 20,000 gallons, $2,468.00.
Pneumatic pressure tanks working capacity 2000 gallons, $1,572.00.

To all of the above projects will have to be added the cost of the pumping plant, which will be approximately $841.00.

SEPTIC TANK: Septic tank complete, $2,100.00.

ELECTRIC LIGHTING SYSTEM, complete, $2,400.00.

With reference to the above mentioned works I beg to recommend that the Claydon Co. be authorized to proceed with the erection of a wooden tower and wooden tank, the installing of a pumping system and the building of a septic tank.

With reference to the electric lighting plant before this is authorized I would recommend that the Inspector of Construction be authorized to instruct the Claydon Co. to submit a price for the different types of lighting plants of the size required, and that they be instructed to install the plant which will give the best results at the least cost. A full report should be submitted to the Department by the Inspector before the work is authorized.

I may say with reference to the above mentioned work that there is an item of $4,700, stipulated in the specifications to partly defray the cost of the water and sewerage systems.
