Dear Mr.Orr,-

I have heard from the contractors that the 60' framed tower, and the 20,000 gallon wooden tank, have been authorized for the water system for this school. No doubt this will soon be confirmed in a letter of instructions to me.

The contractors have figured their tender on the basis of the tank being located close to the rear portion of the school, but I have been wondering if you would like to have it placed there. The tank, when full, will weigh about 100 tons, and I wondered if you might consider such a weight, placed on a 60' tower, as constituting a menace to the safety of the building. If in the course of time the foundations should settle unevenly, or the structure itself become unsound, there is just the suggestion of danger, is there not? Were the tower and tank placed say 20' from the building the hypothetical threat to the building would be removed. This district is subject to terrific winds, and this factor, also, must not be ignored.

Please do not misinterpret my remarks to mean that we are going to duplicate the Leaning Tower of Pisa, or neglect our foundations. I merely have a feeling that I would like your approval to this structure being placed so close to the school before I allow the contractors to put it there.

Should you decide that the tower and tank are to be erected not nearer than 90' from the building, the contractors would expect to be paid for the additional cost of carrying the water and steam lines, with protected covering, the added distance, which would amount to about $125 extra.

Will you kindly wire me your instructions in the matter?

Re: St. Paul's School, Blood Reserve.

Dear Mr. Orr,

During the work of the electric wiring of this building, the Reverend Principal earnestly requested that some additional outlets be provided. While admitting that his requests were eminently reasonable, and would add to the efficiency of the institution, I told him I was short of all discretionary power regarding additional expenditure, and that I was unable to give a single order that would add a dollar to the cost of the building.

Mr. Graham (to whom I had been instructed to refer all such matters) was then absent from Regina on a tour, and as immediate action was necessary before the rough wiring was covered by the metal lath, Mr. Middleton undertook to be personally responsible for the payment of these electrical extras. This means that if the Department does not pay the electrical contractor, Mr. Middleton will do so out of his own pocket. On this clearly understood basis the additional wiring has been done.

I am enclosing herewith full details of each item of lighting extras, and I will briefly explain them in the order in which I have numbered them:

1. Extra circuits were run to the unfinished central attic dormitory, so that when the time comes that this room will be needed, provision will have been made for providing the light outlets and switches. This is a wise provision, and an ultimate economy.

2. This charge is for a wall plug in baseboard so that a desk lamp may be used.

3. This charge is for placing switches in the staff rooms adjoining the attic dormitories, instead of in the dormitories themselves, as was called for on the floor below.

4. This charge is for providing facilities so that a moving picture machine may be used for purposes of education and entertainment in the assembly class room where the folding doors are.

Sir,

For some time past I have been expecting a visit from the Indian Commissioner (Mr. Graham) and a number of items on which I want official decisions have been deferred in expectation of his arrival. The sheet metal contractor has practically completed his work, and intends returning to Winnipeg almost at once. In his department are two instances in which I would like decisions before he leaves.

I would have referred these matters to Mr. Graham, as instructed to do, but, according to the papers, he is at present absent from Regina, and is reported as being at Edmonton in connection with the formal opening of the new Indian School there. I have, therefore, deemed it advisable to send you a night letter dealing with the two items of sheet metal work, so as to have an official decision prior to the metal contractor leaving, and I have wired you as follows:

LOUVRE IN SPIRE ADMITS RAIN & SNOW IN DRIVING STORMS.
CONTRACTORS RECOMMEND LINING INSIDE LOUVRE WITH GALVANIZED IRON WITH BOTTOM TURNED OUT TO DISCHARGE ON ROOF COSTING FIFTY TWO DOLLARS. STOP. SHOULD BASEMENT LAVATORY VENTS BE EXTENDED TO VENT TOILET AREAS INSTEAD OF BATHS COSTING FORTY SEVEN DOLLARS.

I think the items mentioned in the telegram are self explanatory. Regarding the louvres, although there is a splendid slope to the shutters, yet the driving storms get through, causing a heavy dripping of water. At the Edmonton school the contractors boarded the louvre up solid, yet the driving rain, following the boarding down, came through on the ceilings, and something more will have to be done there. By using sheet metal all the way down the louvre, and with the lower edge turned out on the slope of the bottom shutter, like on a window sill, leakage should be effectually prevented. In addition to lining the louvres with sheet metal, as described, it is intended to carry down angle strips of gal. iron on the exterior angles.
between the louvres, so as to make an absolutely watertight job where otherwise a slight shrinkage of the posts might leave slight vertical openings.

Regarding the vents in basement toilets, the plan shows these leading to the bathrooms. Would it not be better to extend them to the rooms containing the toilets?

As stated in the telegram the estimated cost of the louvre protection is $52.00; and the extension to the basement vents is quoted at $47.00, both of which estimates include the contractors' 10%.

The work of the general contract is well advanced, and it is expected that steam heat will be available within ten days. The sewage disposal plant is now being installed.

Are the bakery oven and kitchen range likely to arrive soon? I would like to get them set up, and see that they are in proper working order.

The weather continues fine and mild, following the rain and snowstorm of three weeks ago.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Dear Mr. Orr,

On the ground and first floors of the school are seven bedrooms, a parlour staff room, the matron's office, the boy's study, and the store room off the 1st floor passage (on the way to the rear balcony) which have doors with the top part glass. The glass measures 23"x 33". The glass for these doors have not yet been put in. The purpose of the glass is to admit borrowed light to the corridors. I wonder if it was your intention to have these doors glazed with muranese glass in order to prevent any visibility into these rooms from the corridors? I have asked the contractor to defer glazing these doors until I learn your wish in the matter.

The contractor states that it would cost $15 extra to put in figured glass as compared with the cost of plain glass.

The steel partitions provided for the lavatories and basement bathrooms have been erected, in accordance with the amended specifications. The large steel screen shown on the plan, and passing in front of the toilets, was cut out in the changes. In earlier correspondence you indicated that it was your intention to provide wooden screens to take their place. These could be made either in solid V.Joint 6' high, or in lattice work such as is often used in toilet room doors. My understanding was that this very necessary adjunct to the toilets would be provided at the time the lockers, tables, etc., are constructed, and, as I have already written to you regarding the auxiliary interior work required, I would ask that you kindly instruct me regarding the toilet screens too.

In the boiler room space was provided for ashes in a 4'x 4' concrete space located alongside the main chimney, as shown on the plan. No outside cover has yet been authorized for this ash chute. Should there not be sloping double doors provided?

No provision has yet been made for an ash hoist for elevating the ashes. During the heating season there will be a
large quantity of ashes to remove, and, I presume, it is the Department's intention to provide a mechanical ash lift. The one installed at the Edmonton school cost, if I remember aright, about $400.00, and seemed very satisfactory. Remembering the Department's wish to keep down cost on this building, I have been looking about to see what I could find that would meet the needs without too much outlay, and I succeeded in locating a very suitable rig that was installed at the Municipal Hospital at Cardston a few years ago, and it has never been used. The Hospital is a small building, heated with a hot air furnace, and as the quantity of ashes is small, and only a few steps to carry them outside, the janitor has never felt the need of the ash hoist provided by the architect for the building.

I examined the ash hoist in question; it is called the "G & G Telescopic Hoist", made by Gillis & Geoghegan, of Sherbrooke, Quebec, and has a guaranteed capacity of 500#. It is exactly what is needed at the school here. The Hospital Board, in response to my inquiry, stated that they would sell it for $75.00, including two very heavy iron ash buckets. Its cost was $278.00, plus transportation and installing. If so instructed, I will procure this very suitable hoist and iron ash buckets, and have it installed by the contractors. Mr. Snyder, the heating subcontractor, states that there is nothing better on the market for our purpose, and that the price asked is about 25% of its value.

About a week ago Mr. Inspector Christianson, of the Regina office, and Mr. George, a carpenter sent by Commissioner Graham, arrived at Cardston to start barn building. I understand they propose building a horse and cattle barn here (two separate buildings) and a horse barn on the R.C. school site near the new Agency. Apparently they are acting under instructions from Regina rather than from Ottawa. I have not been shown the plans, or consulted in any way, so I assume that it is not the Department's wish that I should exercise any supervision over the construction, or concern myself with this work in any way. The weather is now very unfavourable, with snow and below zero temperatures, and it will be difficult to perform the work as satisfactorily, or as economically, as though it had been started two months ago.

The contractors are endeavouring to keep frost out of the building by burning wood cuttings until a car of coal arrives which, it is hoped, will be tomorrow.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have this day visited the new St. Paul's School building which is being erected at the South end of this Reserve for our Society, and have much pleasure in informing you that the general plan of the building itself, and the care which has been maintained in the carrying out of that plan, stands in my opinion, much to the credit of those who have been associated with this work in these respects. The work of the contractors at the time of my visit was rapidly nearing completion and, so far as I could ascertain, after a careful examination of the whole building, they will have the satisfaction of feeling that their work was well done. A similar statement may also be made with regard to the duties discharged by your Inspector of Construction.

Although the main school building was rapidly nearing completion, and presented an appearance which I felt must be both pleasing and creditable to those responsible for its erection, there were a few matters of importance on which I solicited information from those on the spot at the time of my visit and as this was not forthcoming, I have conceived it to be my duty to bring the same to your attention. These are as follows:

1. Storm Windows. As no storm windows had been provided, and apparently no arrangement made for their provision, I fear that they may have been overlooked. Nor do I consider that any lengthy explanation is required on my part to convince you of their necessity.

2. Night Toilets for the Attic Dormitories. As no night toilets were provided for the dormitories in the attic, even though such are certain to be required as soon as the School is opened, I was puzzled to know why they had not been installed as in the other

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 637L, file 764-5, part 2)
D. Van C. Scott, Esq., C.M.G.,

dormitories, and especially so, when the "roughing in" had been done.

3. Lockers in Dormitories and Recreation Rooms. As lockers are unquestionably a necessity in each of the six dormitories and in each of the two recreation rooms, and no arrangement had apparently been made for their provision, I was apprehensive that this necessity might have been overlooked also. As these will take some time to make, and their non-provision delay the opening of the School, immediate action in this respect is important.

4. Ash Hoist. An ash hoist has not been provided and requires no comment to explain the great convenience it would be. I learned during my visit that a new telescopic ash hoist purchased for the Cardston Municipal Hospital at a cost of $400, but never used as it was too large for the shaft, might be purchased for much less—possibly half of the original cost—and as it would suit the School's purpose, would recommend that it be secured and installed.

5. Porch over rear Entrance of Principal's Residence. As the prevailing winds are from the West, and at the time of my visit had piled a deep quantity of snow over the steps and against the rear entrance of the Principal's residence on the West side the erection of a porch, with steps leading from the platform down by the side of the wall instead of at right angles to it, would add greatly to the comfort of this part of the building.

6. Porch over the outside Entrance to the Chapel. A porch over the outside entrance to the chapel would also add comfort to this part of the building.

7. Soft Water Tank. As the water in School wells contains a considerable amount of soda, and soft water will be required from time to time for filling the boilers, washing etc., the conservation of soft water is necessary for these and other purposes, and a soft water tank should be provided.

8. Poultry House. As no poultry house has been provided and one will be required as soon as the School is opened, I learned from the contractor that he would sell fifty feet of his cook house for $100, and as this could be used for a poultry house until Spring, I beg to recommend that that length of this building be purchased for this purpose.

9. Stock Barn. During my visit to the new School building I met a contractor from Regina named Mr. George, who informed me that he had been awarded the contract for building two stables, namely, one for horses and one for cows. Upon request he kindly showed me the plans which had been given him for these buildings, and I feel it my duty to inform you that they furnished me with a rather uncomfortable surprise. The plans themselves were not the usual blue prints I had expected to see but pencil drawings, without scale, showing in rough outline the ground plan of each building and the
cross section of an end. As one large stock barn with a silo attached, similar to the one built at the Old Sun School, would have met the needs of the new St. Paul's School better than the two smaller buildings about to be erected, I cannot but express to you my very keen regret that some reference was not made to me, or to some other representative of our Society, before the plans were finally adopted and the contract awarded. The almost invariable method of procedure adopted by your Department in the past, whereby copies of plans and specifications of important buildings about to be erected for our Society were submitted to one or more of its representatives for suggestions before the work of construction was actually begun, possessed so many decided advantages that I am quite at a loss to understand the reason why, in this particular instance, it has not been followed, and I can only hope in the highest and best interests of the cooperative system of administration which our Society and your Department have so successfully pursued during the past few years that the usual method of procedure may be fully restored and maintained.

As the contract for the erection of the stables has already been awarded to the above-mentioned contractor, and the materials already ordered by him, it is now, I fear, too late to ask for a reconsideration of this important matter, but I am strongly of the opinion that the stables for the cows should have a silo, owing to the large quantity of milk which will be required to meet the needs of the School, and that the stable for the horses should be enlarged so as to provide what is termed a "maternity ward" for a brood mare, and an additional double or box stall.

If you will kindly give the above matters your early and sympathetic consideration, and issue instructions accordingly, you will do much to relieve our Society of the anxiety which is now felt in connexion therewith, and help to bring the whole plant up to that state of efficiency and completion which is necessary before it can be considered ready for occupation.

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary M.S.O.C.

PROGRESS REPORT; ST. PAUL'S SCHOOL, CARDSTON.

Sir,

In my last monthly report I indicated that the general contract was likely to be completed during the month of November, but there still remains some interior work yet to be done before the building is completed. The contractors have been largely occupied in the work of the outside services which were additional to the main contract, and, for that reason, the completion of the inside work has been delayed.

The weather during November has been generally broken. There have been two snow storms, and a number of very windy days. The snow drifted badly, and, for several days, the roads were almost impassable. We also experienced very low temperatures for so early in the winter, reaching a minimum temperature of 17 degrees below zero on the 11th inst. During the latter half of the month the weather has been mild again, but frequent high winds have been a source of annoyance and delay to the contractors, especially as they have been engaged in erecting the 60' framed water tower and 20,000 gal. tank, with housing. It so happened that the last two Sundays were free from wind, and the contractors and their crew have worked on Sundays too.

The sewage disposal system has been satisfactorily completed, with the exception of putting more earth covering over the sewer line where it crosses a depression, and protecting the outlet.

All the cement floors in the basement have been laid, with the exception of that for the machinery room, and it will be done within the next few days. The concrete hardener has been used, as specified, and the surface of the floors so treated is quite satisfactory, and should wear well, and be practically dust-proof.

The flat roof drainage, and the waste from the laundry and kitchen sink, have been conducted through a separate drain, and joins the main sewer beyond the septic tank. I would like to have carried the laundry and chapel roof water to a soft water tank in the laundry, so that there would have been a supply of soda-free water not only for laundry purposes but for the cooling system of the power plant, but this was not authorized.

The heating plant is now in operation. The two #12 Firebox Tubular Boilers seem very satisfactory in operation and efficiency and, excepting during penetrating winds, are easily able to heat the entire building. The boiler covering has been done, as specified, and the boiler breechings have been covered in accordance with the Architect's directions. I am expecting a visit from Dunham's engineer, who will check up the system to see that the Dunham specialties are all correctly installed. The Provincial Boiler Inspector will also make an inspection soon, and I will procure from that official the usual certificate of inspection, as required.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6371, file 764-5, part 2)
The laundry boiler, jacket heater and hot water storage tank have also been installed in the boiler room.

The plumbing fixtures throughout the building are now set up in place, with the exception of the galvanized iron sinks (which are being made to order) and bath and kitchen sink for residence which arrived damaged, and are being replaced. I have not yet been able to test the water lines against leakage for the reason that we have not yet got our water in the building, but I will do so later.

The laundry machinery arrived from Toronto recently, and have been set up in the laundry room. These will be driven from a countershaft which passes through the brick wall from the machinery room. The countershaft will be driven by direct belt drive from a pulley attached to the main shaft of the engine. The laundry machines consist of a large washer with inside partition, an extractor and a drying tumbler, and they all seem good serviceable machines. We will test out the running of these machines as soon as the power is available. We are also installing a suction fan with discharge through a vent in the laundry roof.

We received the Lister engine, generator, batteries, etc., from the Crowfoot School, Cluny, and this plant is now being set up. It arrived in good condition, and will fit nicely in the enlarged machinery room. I expect that by the end of this week electric light will be available. The electrical sub-contractor is carrying out this work. The large powerful pumping plant authorized by the Department has arrived, and will probably be set up within the next few days. We will make a thorough test of all these services before turning them over to the local help.

The lighting fixtures are now being hung. We are following the list authorized by the Department, and are aiming at keeping within the prices mentioned in the list.

There still remains a little carpentry work to do inside the building, which will be quickly completed as soon as carpenters finish the outside work. I have not received any instructions regarding such work as building in the lockers, making the tables and benches for the dining rooms, and such work. The contractors have frequently asked if they are to do these things, and, if authorized, could be done at times when the weather interferes with outside work.

The painting work is not yet completed, and will occupy another week or ten days. Some of the exterior painting of trim was damaged by a dust storm, and is being scraped and re-painted, much to the disgust of the painting sub-contractor, who complains that I am making him responsible for "an act of God".

The erection of the water tower and 20,000-gallon tank has been been the absorbing work during the past fortnight. This work has been interfered with a good deal by adverse weather conditions,- first by snow storms, then by drifting snow which buried the materials under several feet of snow, and latterly by high winds. Fortunately this critical work has been carried by accident, and is now nearing completion. The tower is completed, and the tank house should be finished within the next few days, after which the tank, which came "knocked down" from Calgary, will be put together. The water main and wet steam line have been laid in a trench 6' deep, and carried 90' to the tower, and the back-filling of this trench has just been done. The steam line will be an aerial one, carried on poles from the heating plant, and will be suitably covered. This line will be about 10' above grade. The risers to the elevated tank will be suitably covered, and boxed in. This work will all be done in a manner to insure immunity from frost trouble in the winter months.
There has been some disfigurement of plaster in a number of rooms caused by leakage from the gutters previous to the soldering of the joints, as mentioned in my last report. The contractors will be required to restore this damage before the building is accepted.

On the night of the 15th inst. we experienced a wind of almost cyclonic intensity, and it was found next morning that the brick gable over the Principal's entrance suffered the loosening of the brickwork. This gable seemed to receive the force of the wind deflected by the main building. The construction of this gable was fairly good, but not very strong, and is only a small gable. We have rebuilt this gable in solid brick and have put in a number of iron rods carried back and secured to the rafters, in addition to the ordinary brick ties, so it should be proof against a recurrence of such trouble. I am very glad it happened while the contractors were still here. The main gables suffered no damage from the gale, nor has there been any other damage of any kind.

I am hoping that the kitchen range and bakery oven will arrive while the contractors are here, for openings will have to be made in the bakery chimney. We have a few glazed tile left, which we will use in making good where the range smoke pipe will enter the chimney.

The erection of the horse barn and dairy barn is now being carried out by the foreman sent from Regina, and local men he has picked up. Through the courtesy of the Claydon Company, he has been able to use Claydon's facilities. As I received no instructions in the matter I assumed that it was not the Department's intention that I exercise any supervision over the barn work, or concern myself with it in any way.

From present indications I think the contractors will be through by about the middle of December. The Reverend Principal has engaged an engineer, who is coming to the school tomorrow, and will have the advantage of becoming acquainted with the mechanical plant under the supervision of the contractors. The engineer appears to be experienced and intelligent. The contractors will have a chance to satisfy themselves as to his competency before turning the plant over to his charge.

Will you please instruct me regarding accepting the building from the contractors on completion. I am holding the fire insurance policies, aggregating $90,000.00, and no doubt the Claydon Co. will be desirous for having the building accepted promptly on the satisfactory completion of their contract and subsidiary work, so that they may receive a refund of the unexpired insurance.

Awaiting your further valued instructions,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

E. Gardner-Smith

Dear Mr. Orr,

To-day we had a visit from the Reverend Principal and Mrs. Middleton. They are anxious to have the intended cupboard built in the Principal's kitchen previous to their moving in. I told him that I had not yet received any definite authority to have this work done.

Canon Middleton stated that the Indian Commissioner was leaving Regina for Ottawa to-day. As the contractors will soon be completing their authorized work, and leaving the job, it was thought advisable to write to the Department direct, to ask if it is the intention to have the cupboard asked for built by the contractors before they leave. If such is the intention I would ask that you kindly wire me to that effect, in order to save time.

You will remember that, in order to provide for the folding doors in the boys' class rooms, we had to move the door leading into the Principal's residence a little to one side. This change made a jog in the wall of the kitchen, leaving a recess of 5'-6"x 22", between where the jog came and the kitchen chimney, and it is in this space that the cupboard would go.

The type of cupboard most suitable would consist of a two-door cupboard and tilting bin below, table top with drawers under, and shelves above, with glass doors. This would cost, complete, in the neighbourhood of $65.00.

I promised to convey the Principal's request to the Department, and would await instructions before doing anything in the matter.

Your obedient servant

Sir,

Re- St. Paul's School: Blood Reserve.

In earlier reports I mentioned that I was afraid there would not be a good draught from the kitchen and bakery chimney. These flues are about 8"x 8" each in area. In the amendments to the specifications the height of this chimney was reduced by 17' in height. It is now much below the height of the main building adjacent to it.

Recently a stove was set up in the Bakery for temporary purposes, and it was found that the draught was so bad that at times the smoke came the other way,- that is instead of going up the chimney, it blew back into the room, and drove the occupants out. This condition is not a freak occurrence, but will be the case very frequently. The same conditions apply to the kitchen flue. It will be extremely difficult- if not impossible- to bake bread, or perform the cooking with the kitchen range.

I would respectfully suggest that an iron pipe extension be built on this chimney, about 16" in diameter, and about 20' in height. This could be anchored to the chapel roof, main building roof and to a post to be set in the ground to one side of the coal bin. This arrangement would brace the metal chimney safely.

I am leaving for Calgary tomorrow to spend Christmas with my family, and will return here for a few days afterwards, and I would ask the Department to please wire me regarding the extension to the chimney. I have not yet been able to get out an estimate of the cost of this work, but, if entrusted to me, I will have it done as economically as possible by the local sheet metal contractor, under my direction, at cost plus 10%.

I do not think the new range and bakery oven will arrive before the end of the year, and, if so instructed, I would endeavour to have this chimney ready by the time these fixtures are set up. Please wire me at Cardston by the 27th, if possible, and I will be guided by your instructions.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

With reference to the final certificate (No. 12) which I issued today to Claydon Company, Limited, the general contractors for the above-mentioned work, in full payment of their contract, including extras, and excess over the lump sum allowance for outside services, it will be noticed that I mentioned on the face of the certificate that details of extras allowed would be found on a separate sheet. I now enclose said sheet, showing that extras of $5,964.76, and excess over the allowance of $5,000.00 amounting to $3957.05, have been added to the certificate, bringing the complete total of contract and extras to $133,153.00. These figures will be better understood by reference to the statement enclosed.

Before issuing the final certificate I received from the contractors the signed guarantee of all materials and workmanship against defects for a period of 12 months, as called for in the specifications.

I have today accepted the building from Claydon Co., and have returned to them their fire insurance policies. I wired the Department today of the completion and acceptance of the building; and I have also notified the Indian Agent, Mr. Faunt, and the Rev. Principal, Canon Middleton. The building is now in the charge of a competent caretaker and engineer, who had the advantage of being thoroughly instructed by the contractors in the care of the heating plant and mechanical services, and I believe everything of that kind will be well looked after. The contractors, and all their men, have left for their respective homes.

Canon Middleton informed me that it will be impossible for the staff and pupils to move into the new building until the various furnishings and equipment arrive. Some articles are now at the Cardston station, but the bulk of the equipment and supplies have not yet arrived. The Principal hopes the moving in may be accomplished during the month of January.

The weather during December could scarcely have been worse, and gave considerable trouble to the contractors in connection with the work of building the tower and elevated water tank. Intense cold (45 below) with piercing winds, caused the freezing and bursting of pipes, and a lot of tearing down, and subsequent making good after, a considerable cost. By keeping the heating boilers going full blast day and night, it was possible to keep the building comfortably warm in most of the rooms, but in those rooms exposed to the wind there was some freezing trouble, owing principally—if not entirely—to the absence of storm windows.

I will write a separate report reviewing the recent work accomplished, but I will now devote myself to explanations of the various items which are additional to the contract, of which I am segregating under Schedules A & B. The items coming under A are those sundry items classed as ordinary extras; while the remaining items, classed under B, are those included under a lump sum allowance made in the contract, of $5000.00, and it is the excess over this sum that is being credited to the contractors. The explanations follow on separate sheets.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Construction.

OTTAWA.

Final Report on Construction; St. Paul's School.

Sir,

On December 22nd I notified the Department by telegram that the contractors were then turning over to me, as the representative of the Department, the new school building. Since that date the building has been under the charge of the Reverend Principal, Canon Middleton, or more particularly, under the care of his newly appointed engineer Mr. Rhines. This engineer has shown himself to be unusually competent, and the school is to be commended in having procured such a reliable and experienced man, along mechanical lines.

On New Year's Day Canon Middleton and family, and the matron (Nurse Megarry) accompanied by three or four of the older pupils, moved into their new quarters. They are now busy in checking material deliveries and putting things in order. So far but very few of the shipments have arrived, but it is expected that heavy shipments will arrive very soon.

On December 11th and 12th the Provincial Boiler Inspector, Mr. Marshall visited the school, and made a thorough test of the heating and laundry boilers. He issued the certificates of inspection, and left orders of two or three slight alterations considered by him to be desirable, and which have been attended to by the heating contractor.

On the 19th ultimo the electrical inspector of the Western Canada Fire Underwriters made an official visit and tested out the lighting apparatus. He found everything satisfactory, and the only change he ordered was to change the ground wiring from entering the soil below the switchboard in the engine room, and instead, to ground it to the water in the cooling tank, which has been done. While here he also inspected the electric wiring of the partly-built barns, which had been performed by the same electrical contractor, and which was found satisfactory.

The Dunham Heating Co.'s Inspector made a start to come here and check up the Dunham installations, but was caught by snow storms and could not get through. He intends coming when weather permits. This inspection is entirely gratuitous, but is a feature of the Dunham service.

When the contractors left (on Dec. 22nd) the water tower and tank was just completed, and there was not then time to give it a real test before Christmas. Since then we have been pumping at intervals, and have gradually reached about 12,000 gals. in the tank. It still leaks more freely than I care to see, but I am hoping that the cracks will soon disappear as the wood swells. The tank is made of fir, which is not nearly so good as redwood. The tank is now almost full of water, but leaks at the rate of 1000 gals. per hour as we try to raise the water higher. However, as the tank is a very large one, a reasonable time must be allowed for the leaking to stop, but in the meantime I would respectfully suggest that an adequate sum be retained from the contractors as a contingency measure against a possible expense that may yet arise.

The heating service carried to the tank is functioning very satisfactorily, and there has been no trouble in keeping the
fruit out since the heating boilers were supplied with river water. As previously mentioned the well water, though very good for all ordinary purposes and apparently inexhaustible in quantity, contains some substance in the nature of soda, which renders it unfit for the heating boilers, or laundry boiler. It was when trying to use the well water, at 45 below zero, that the water foamed and the boilers filling the steam lines, consequently making the sealing of these lines and the freezing of same where exposed. However, as previously reported, we were obliged to haul river water from Cardston, and refill the boilers after which there was no more trouble from the foaming previously experienced.

There still remains a little touching in the way of outside painting,—mostly where dust damage was caused on window sills and trim,—and it was impossible to get this done satisfactorily while the contractors were here owing to the cold weather and the presence of snow and ice on the sills. This work is not extensive, and the painter has left sufficient paint to complete the work, which will be done by the school staff in the spring, as arranged with the Principal.

I duly received the Department's instructions regarding the extension to the kitchen and bakery chimney. At the same time it would be well to extend the laundry chimney high enough to clear the chapel roof alongside in order to get proper draught; and I am assuming the Department's consent to this and will have it done at the same time. The kitchen range and bakery oven have not yet arrived at Cardston, and we will endeavour to have the chimneys in readiness for these services.

The Claydon Company informed me that the department had adopted their recommendation that the water tower be braced by anchor rope as a precaution against the extreme winds for which this district is famous. The wire rope which they sent for the guys was, in my opinion, too light, so I wired them to send heavier rope. As the contractors are absent, I have instructed their local workman on how this work should be done to get the results intended, and it is being done under my direction.

Yesterday I received a message from Indian Agent Faunt, asking me to measure up all the window openings on the west side of the school, and to let him have the list, with specifications, and he has authority to procure store sash for these windows. I am preparing the list, as requested, and will hand him the list tomorrow. This protection for the west windows will prove very helpful in those rooms exposed to the prevailing winds, and will undoubtedly effect a noticeable saving in fuel.

As mentioned previously, we are having trouble from water leaking through from the eavestroughs and disfiguring the interior plaster. This seems to be caused by the eavestroughs filling up solid with ice, the expansion of which appears to break open the soldered joints. When other permits all the gutters should be gone over, and the joints re-soldered where necessary.

As my work here is now practically finished I expect to return to Calgary on the 10th inst., and may return for a day or two later in the month to look things over again and accept the work that was recently authorized, but not yet performed.

In conclusion, I will take this opportunity of thanking the department for the courteous treatment and loyal support I have received throughout in the work here, to which I have devoted all my time and have given the best that is in me.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction

DETAILS & EXPLANATIONS OF WORK ADDITIONAL TO CONTRACT, SCHEDULE "A".
Item No. 1. "Increased size of concrete footings, $624.00."

This was authorized by the Architect owing to the unreliability of foundation soil. The cost of the enlarged footing was $624.00, of which $576.00 was for concrete and $48.00 for excavating for the footings. The contractors overlooked charging for the added excavating before, but in checking up their figures, the omission was detected, and is now included in their invoice.

Item No. 2. "Increased size of main chimney, $184.00."

This change was duly authorized by the Architect conditional on our finding some deduction to offset it. We have been unable to find means of offsetting this cost. As the heating contractor insisted on the larger flue area, we had no alternative in the matter.

Item No. 3. "Cement supplied to strengthen mortar," $71.50.

I felt that owing to the reduction in the thickness of our walls and the elimination of the cement in the mortar, we were not going to have sufficient strength in our basement walls and piers. The contractor was of the same opinion. We used one shovelful of cement to each wheelbarrow of lime carried up to the ground floor. In the brick piers we used cement mortar. I told the contractor that I could not promise that this extra cost would be paid for, but that I would refer it to the Department. This matter was referred to in my Report of June 20th.

Item No. 4. "Putting wooden floor in janitor's room, $27.50."

This was duly authorized, and the cost is rendered in detail. Credit is shown for the cement finish thus eliminated.

Item No. 5. "Additional outside entrance to chapel, with trim, $117.08."

This addition was the result of the Rev. Principal's request for an outside entrance, so that the older Indians might be able to attend church services without tramping through the School. This was accomplished by the Department. The windows which this entrance displaced were put in the boiler room so as to give more light in front of the boilers.

Item No. 6. "Door between Machinery Room & Laundry, $82.13."

In the plan a solid brick wall was shown separating the laundry from the machinery. It was suggested by the Architect that a movable partition be placed there so that the large machines might be passed through into the laundry when necessary. It was deemed important to put a door over the movable partition, so that the resident in charge might pass quickly between the rooms when carrying the machines instead of having to go a long way round by way of the basement passage and boiler room. In the event of an accident this change might prove very advantageous. The contractors were unable to give credit for the bricks displaced on account of the reinforced concrete lintel over the opening costing more than the bricks left out.

Item No. 7. "Work on hanging bell, $51.55."

This is the school bell shipped from Regina. The contractors quoted $15 for the setting of it on brackets on the roof, which has been done. The additional cost for bell ropes and pulleys, as per voucher from the Cardston Implement Co.

Item No. 8. "Building Rail in chapel, $13.78."

On the plan only a step was shown. The Rev. Principal said a communion rail was indispensable. This has been
been installed, made from stair railing, with hinged drop-leaf in centre, and with balustrades between posts. It has been stained and varnished.

Item No. 9. "Door between fuel room and boiler room, $12.21".

Without a door it was impossible to prevent a layer of black dust from spreading through that part of the building. When the fine steam coal was being unloaded a cloud of black dust spread over everything nearby, even reaching other basement rooms when the doors were opened.

Item No. 10. "Bal. due for boards under metal ceilings, $112.00".

This balance was still due the contractors after commissions were placed as an offset against the cost of the ceiling boards which have been restored. It was hoped that other economies might be effected to absorb the $12.00, but the previous pruning had been too severe, the details of the exchanges are in the records of the Department.

Item No. 10½. "Balance on account of larger hot water storage tank, less credit of difference in smaller high pressure laundry boiler, $35.00.

Item No. 11. "Decorating living room in principal's residence, $13.80.

The reverend principal and Mrs. Middleton were very desirous of having their living room slightly different to the rest of the Institution, and the walls and ceilings have been tinted by the painter. I stated that this work was not authorized, and since Middleton wanted it done anyhow, and if it is to be charged a proper charge against the Department, he has offered to pay for it himself. If this item is out of order, please delete it from the amount of the final certificate, and the Rev. Principal will pay for it direct.

Item No. 12. "Additional cost of white Muranese Glass," $35.75.

This glass was used to provide obscurity in the staff room doors bordering on the corridors. In addition, it was found necessary to put heavy wired glass in the double doors at the main entries, and in the outside door to boiler room. It was found that ordinary glass would not stand the high winds which frequently blew the doors shut violently in spite of the door checks provided. Several sheets of the ordinary glass had been thus smashed before it was decided to procure the wired glass. Authority has received from Ottawa for the muranese glass.

Item No. 13. "Extending ventilation pipes to Levatories," $7.52.

This was duly authorized at the price quoted.

Item No. 14. Sheeting inside of tower with gal. iron, $62.00.

This was necessary to prevent snow and rain from being blown through the louvres. The work was duly authorized at the price shown. It has accomplished the object intended.

Item No. 10½. The details of this transaction were arranged between the Winnipeg office of the Grand Trunk Co., and the Superintendent, Thompson, to whom we have correspondence on the subject, to satisfy them as to the correctness of our statement. I have therefore included this item, subject to the confirmation of the Architect. The hot water storage tank measures 3' by 10'.
Item No. 15. "Additional hangers on line shaft, $46.13."

It was found necessary to place three more hangers on the line shaft that was shown on plan. One of these was placed opposite the wall where the belt from the engine drives the pulley that turns the line shaft to laundry. The other additional hangers were placed in the laundry, one alongside the pulley that drives the extractor, and the other in a gap where there was too much vibration to the shaft when the machines were in operation. Everything in that connection is now working satisfactorily.

Item No. 16. "Sundry items of additional electrical work, $148.09"

This work was performed at the request of the Rev. Principal for additional outlets and call bells, and was duly sanctioned by the Department in their letter of Oct. 15th. The cost of the work to the contractors was $132.62, to which they have added 10% commission.

Item No. 17. "Net return from principal's residence, $110.00."

This was regularly authorized at the price shown.

Item No. 18. "Roughing-in for W.C.'s in Attic dormitories, $127.50."

Item No. 19. "Hot Water circulating pipe, $116.87."

This item was authorized by Commissioner Graham, and cost at the rate of $5.50 per foot. The effect of this will be a greatly improved hot water system, and a conservation of hot water. The hot water line is also covered under this item.

Item No. 20. "Larger sized jacket heater, $82.50."

It was decided that the change to a heater of larger capacity was advisable, and was duly authorized at the price shown.

Item No. 21. "Covering of boiler breechings, $272.25."

This was duly authorized and was performed by the heating sub-contractor at a cost of $247.50, to which the Clayton Co. have added their usual 10% commission.

Item No. 22 & 23. "Additional fire hose in boiler room, $49.50 and on ground floor, $38.50."

This was authorized by Commissioner Graham at $45. and $35. which, with the contractor's 10% worked out as shown.

Item No. 24. "Surplus coal taken over, $108.60."

The contractors brought in a large ear of coal for temporary heat during the last stage of construction. On completion the coal left over was measured and charged at cost price.

Item No. 25. "Hauling water from Cardston for heating boilers, $80.00."

In earlier reports it was mentioned that the local well water contained soda. This was found to be unsuitable for the boilers, and during the cold weather when the boilers were most needed, the water foamed and left the boilers. Five tanks of water have been hauled, and the boilers are now giving no trouble in this respect, and should carry through the remainder of the heating season. Next year the school teams can haul the

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6371, file 764-5, part 2)
necessary river water for filling the boilers, and this expense avoided.

Item No. 26. "Installing burlap as originally called for, $500.00."

In the amendments the burlap was struck out, and the contractors state that $500.00 allowance was made in their revised contract price in consequence. They claim that the burlap which they have wettered should be paid for at the rate that was allowed by the Department, and was omitted under the revision. As the Department will no doubt keep a record of the original and revised figures, including the burlap, I have added the amount claimed by the contractors in this regard, subject to the Department's confirmation. The restoration of the burlap was authorized in a telegram from Commissioner Graham.

Item No. 27. "Supplying belt lacer for machinery belting, $5.00."

This was left by the contractors for the use of the engineer, and was charged for at cost price, with lacing thrown in. This is a metallic system of lacing hooks, for which the lacer is indispensable, and as the belts are sure to stretch, and require shortening, the machine could not be dispensed with.

Item No. 28. "Teeming account, as per deduction from original costs, $2,900.00."

This one item makes up approximately one half of the total costs shown under Schedule "A." This sum was deducted from Claydon Co.'s final tender when it was expected that the school was to be built close to the railway yard siding provided. When finally it was decided to build the school on its present site the contractors claimed that this large deduction be written back into their contract price, which has been done under authority received from Ottawa.
DETAILS AND EXPLANATIONS OF PRIME COST ITEMS FOR WHICH A LUMP SUM OF FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS WAS INCLUDED IN THE CONTRACT PRICE. SCHEDULE "B".

Item No. 1. "Septic tank & Sewer system, as quoted, $2,100.00."

The work under this heading was duly authorized, and performed according to an approved plan, at the price quoted.

Item No. 2. "Additional length of main sewer, $65.00."

The plan showed the sewer leaving the building at the rear of the boiler room, but it was afterwards changed to another point of departure from building, which lengthened the sewer by 100'. This extension, including trench, cost $135.00. In order to lessen the cost as much as possible, the size of the sewer pipe between the septic tank and the outlet was reduced from 6" to 4", and a saving of $70.00 was effected and applied in reducing the cost under this heading, to $65.00.

Item No. 3. "Rainwater disposal pipe, $175.25."

In the specifications it stated that the laundry and flat roof water were to be taken to the outside of the building and the Department would continue it. This was carried in a separate 6" drain for 165' where it was joined to the main sewer just beyond the septic tank. This work cost $95.00 and $80.00 for iron pipe supplied by Snyder & Co.

Item No. 4. "Water tower, as quoted, including allowance for steam heating, $3459.00."

This system of water storage and pressure was decided on by the Department at the price quoted, and has been installed in accordance with the approved plan.

Item No. 5. "Revision as per wire to Mr. Orr for additional bracing at top of tower, $150.00."

I have not received any direct authority to include this item, but Claydon Co. state that this addition was arranged for by direct negotiation from the Winnipeg office. I am, therefore, including it, subject to ratification by the Department.

Item No. 6. "Cross bracing installed at base of centre posts, $20.90."

This was decided to be necessary as otherwise the outward thrust of the centre posts might have a tendency to break the vertical concrete piers supporting them, under great weight.

Item No. 7. "Supplying and installing water main, $322.30."

It was originally intended to install the water tower and tank alongside of the school building, but it was subsequently decided to place them 90' distant, and it is for this 90' that the added cost applies, and for an additional 85' of riser pipe in 3" size, from the bottom of the trench to the point of delivery into the tank. This figure $322.30, also includes the covering of the riser pipe with asbestos cell covering, followed by a covering of heavy hairfelt. Item No. 7 deals with the water main only. The contractors did not include the water riser in their quotation on the tower and tank.
Item No. 8. "Increase in cost of heating services for extra 90 feet, $489.17."

This charge is for the cost of carrying the steam main from the heating boilers to the base of the tower, a distance of 115', and for protection covering over the steam main and wet return. This item includes the cost of a six foot trench, 100 feet in length; and a pole line to carry the steam line. When authority was given for placing the tower and tank 90 feet from the school, it was then estimated that the cost of carrying and protecting the steam lines would be between $450. and $500. The heating of the tank itself, and the risers and returns from the grade to the tank, are not charged for in this item, being part of the contract price, under Item No. 4.

Item No. 9. "Supply and erect pump, as per quotation, $841.00."

This was regularly authorized, and installed satisfactorily.

Item No. 10. "Additional drop line to well, $24.20."

On account of having the large capacity pump authorized (1420 gals per hour) it was deemed advisable to draw water from a somewhat lower level in the casing than was included in the contract for the pump. We therefore added 20 feet to the intake pipe, at the cost shown. We are now drawing water from a point below grade, and there is still 30' of water in the casing below the pump cylinder. The well has thus far withstood the heavy strain on its capacity by the large pump, and I do not expect any trouble in that respect, which is a remarkable showing in the way of an abundance of water.

Item No. 11. "Supply and installing ash hoist and cars, $197.34."

This outfit was obtained from the Cardston Hospital board, as mentioned by me in a letter to the Department. The Hospital board seem to be somewhat confused in the matter, and it became necessary for us to pay $100.00 for it, and $97.34 extra for the heavy iron ash buckets. The Board discovered that the buckets were being used for garbage purposes, and they are having to get other buckets made in the place of the heavy iron ones we got with the hoist. However, we are getting a bargain as it is, as we got the one for the Edmonton school, and is costing the Department just half. It is now installed and working satisfactorily.

Item No. 12. "Install electric lighting plant supplied by Dept., $447.03."

This item includes the freight on the List plant shipped from the Crowfoot school, Cluny; the handling to site; cost of making base and shelves; and the electrician's time setting up and testing and the purchase of sundries for same; and a charge of $20.00 for inspection made by the official inspector of the Western Canada Fire Underwriters Assoc.

Item No. 13. "Supplying and installing electric light fixtures, $520.56."

This item is scarcely correctly worded. The installing of the lighting fixtures was provided for in the general electric specifications, and no charge is made by the contractor's for this work. The fixtures were purchased according to the list, and at the prices authorized by the Department. The contractors have added -----

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
have added their usual 10% to the purchase price. You will observe that there have been included a number of spare lamps, of various strength of lights, which the school will be able to make use of for replacement as other lights become broken or burnt out. These have been supplied by the electrical sub-contractor at a special price.

Item No. 14. Wash tables in boys' and girls' lavatories, $142.80.*

These wash tables were made to the detail supplied by the Architect and have been installed in the place of the washbasins originally specified. The tables are covered with zinc; each side slopes to the centre, and the centre of the table contains a depression, or trough, which slopes to an outlet connected with the drain through a sealed trap. Hot and cold water pipe available at either end of the tables delivered through faucets. A slop sink is fitted at one end of each table. A slatted shelf below each table provides for wash basins when not in use. Under proper supervision the scheme should work out very well.

NOTE: Under item 11, it will be observed that the hospital board at Cardston sold the Ash hoist direct to Mr. Snyder, so that the Department are purchasing the outfit from him, and not from the Board. I did not deem it necessary to ask for a copy of the invoice from the Board to Snyder. We have obtained the hoist at half its market value, although the cost has come a little higher than I was given to expect.

Under item 12, I have no voucher for the teaming of the lighting plant from the Cardston station to the site, as it was part of the general teaming arrangement, but I consider the charge of $300 reasonable, as it included batteries and cooling & oil tanks as well as the engine and generator. I am also looking for voucher for the freight of the furnishing to Cardston of $72.94. I asked the contractors for this voucher, but they stated that the receipt had been sent to their Winnipeg office, and there was not a duplicate. However, they showed me the corresponding entry in the stub of their cheque book, which satisfied me that the amount of freight charged the Department had been paid by them.

In the Brotherston Co's s/o under this heading, is included an item of $20. for the Underwriters' Inspection fee. I have also asked for a voucher for this charge, but I know the electrical inspectors would cut the generator, and accessories, when making his general inspection throughout the building. I have asked for a separate voucher for this charge of $20, and it will be obtained in a few days.

I think all other items appearing under Schedule "B" are sufficiently vouchered.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th inst.

With respect to the $1000 still retained, we appreciate having some reason given us for it and, although we do not object to $1000 being held for a while, we cannot agree that the condition of the tank in the water tower warrants it. This tank, like all other wooden tanks, will leak for quite a while. When the water was first pumped into it, as was expected, it leaked very much, but this to anyone with the least experience with wooden tank work is not regarded as a fault.

I have had similar experiences around railway tanks and have not yet seen one which has absolutely no leakage and it cannot be guaranteed that a 2000 gallon wooden tank will be absolutely without leakage.

In confirmation of the above, I would suggest you or Mr. Orr, at your convenience, examine a few of the railway water tanks around Ottawa, and then discuss the matter with any of the railway engineers who have charge of them.

I think by this time the tank at Cardston, or at any rate the lower portion of it, is about swelled to normal. Before leaving Cardston, our Mr. Mitchell explained to the caretaker there that he would have to swell the tank by degrees and, that as the swelling arose along the staves of the tank, so it could be filled, with a minimum of leakage, and then being thoroughly swelled it could be kept full without undue leakage.

I offer the above explanation, not as a protest against the retention of $1000, but to affirm that the condition of the tank is quite satisfactory and would be deemed so by any authority experienced in the use of wooden tanks.

I thank you for your telegram yesterday advising of bonds being returned to us and again express appreciation.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have received a letter from Mr. Middleton, complaining of the delay in not having the lockers and cupboards installed at the St. Paul's school, and giving this as a reason for not being able to occupy the school. This is really a trifling matter, as Mr. Middleton could very well have moved in and arranged to have the extra clothing and supplies stored in one of the spare rooms and on temporary boxes or shelves until such time as he could get the lockers and cupboards installed.

Dr. Westgate informs me that Mr. Middleton also complains that the barns are not completed. I may say that the horse barn is fully completed, and I understand that this barn is sufficiently large to accommodate all the stock which the school owns at the present time, but in addition to this the cow barn is all finished with the exception of one row of stalls, i.e., Mr. Middleton has not sufficient stock to fill all the space which is now ready. I cannot understand why he complains about the barns. If this is an obstacle in carrying on the Indian work then I fear we may expect many complaints. Mr. Scott is here today and tells me that everything is in good shape, and there is no good reason why they could not have moved in and opened the school.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Sect. General of Indian Affairs,

The Honourable Charles Stewart,

Dear Mr. Stewart:

(1) That Mr. Commissioner Graham will receive immediate instructions to complete, without further delay, the construction of the barns and the installation of the needed cupboards, lockers, etc., at the new school on the Blood Reserve; thus securing, at a very early date, occupation of the building by the Missionary Society.

(2) That, since the authorities of the Missionary Society must, of necessity, draw up their annual estimates of receipts and expenditures several months in advance of the dates when such estimates come into operation, it is absolutely necessary that the authorities of the Society should be able to work to, and from, certain fixed dates which have been agreed upon in advance between them and the authorities of the Indian Department. A case in point is the new school on the Blood Reserve, in which instance the date given the Society for the completion of the buildings by the contractor was Dec. 1st, 1933, and in connection with which the Society is still prevented from entering into occupation through the exhausting and needless delays of Mr. Commissioner Graham in completing the barns and installing lockers, etc. The Society's estimates for this school were drawn up last May and were based on the legitimate assumption that the buildings would be completed and available for occupation on a date not later than Jan. 1st, 1934. The delays noted have resulted in a serious loss to the Society in its estimated receipts under the heading of per capita grants. The Society's existing overdraft at its Bankers on its Indian Residential School accounts as on Dec. 31st, 1933, in the neighbourhood of $40,000.00 (forty thousand dollars), a failure to earn the full amount of the per capita grants estimated for the current year is, therefore, a matter of very grave concern to us. This fact illustrates, forcibly, the vital necessity that, for the future, we should be able to proceed with confidence upon the essential business principle of working up to, or from, agreed and known fixed dates.

Yours very faithfully,

General Secretary.
Commissioner's Office,
Regina, Sask. March 11th, 1925

Dear Mr. Stewart -

You will remember speaking to me on the train of Canon Gould's complaint to you that the Principal of the school was unable to move into the new building owing to the fact that the stables were not completed and that certain clothes closets were not finished.

You understand that the building of the stables was carried on by day labor and that the clothes closets referred to were not included in the original contract. I told you that I did not think the report that you had received was well founded, but that I would be going to the Blood Reserve in a few days and I would report to you exactly how matters stood.

The stables I may say were fit for occupancy fully a month prior to the time Canon Gould complained to you. The clothes closets were about completed when I got there, and as I said to you at the time there was no reason why the moving could not be done before these clothes closets were finished, as there was all kinds of vacant space in the rooms that were not occupied next to the dormitories that could be used for storing the clothes on temporary shelves.

In pointing this out to Mr. Middleton the Principal he told me positively that he did not complain to Canon Westgate as it was not a good reason; he said he did tell him something about beds that had not arrived, and on enquiring into this I found that it was only a few beds that were required for the staff, and that there were dozens of perfectly good iron beds, white enamel, such as are used in hospitals or any other institution which could have been used temporarily, but this did not do.

I am...........

Hon. Chas. Stewart,
Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I am taking the trouble of writing you in full regarding this matter as I do not think it is fair for Canon Gould to make statements of this kind when they are not well founded.

Yours very truly,

(sgd) W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Re: St. Paul's School: Blood Reserve.

Dear Mr. Orr,

I enclose herewith a letter from Messrs Brotherston Electric Company Limited, with an account for $22.35, for repairing the bell system which he installed at St. Paul's School.

Some time previous to moving the children to the new school, the Rev. Principal advised me that the bell system throughout the new building was not working, and that he felt some hesitancy about bringing the children until the bells were working again, having specially the fire alarm system in mind.

I at once called on the electrical contractors, and saw Mr. Brotherston. He said that he could not imagine the cause of the trouble, as he had left everything in perfect order, and it had also been checked up by the Underwriters' Inspector. I suggested that he first write a letter to the local engineer, mentioning possible causes of the trouble, and wait until he heard further before going to the expense of the trip. He did this, and after a time further word came that the system was still out of order. As Canon Middleton seemed nervous about bringing in the children with the fire gong not working, I told Brotherston that he had better go down and remedy whatever was causing the trouble; and that if the trouble was not the result of any defects for which he was responsible, I thought it likely that he would be reimbursed for the cost of his trip.

He found that the cause of the trouble was simply a burnt out fuse, which he remedied by replacement in half a minute. The bell system was in perfect order, and as the fault was not his, he has submitted a bill for his expenses, making no charge for the three days he lost. I have certified the bills as being correct in the matter of the charges shown, and I am writing this covering letter that the circumstances will be understood.

Yours very truly,

Afterwards the tank was reduced in width and made longer, with the result that our final proposition provided for a 5" top. We have no information here as to how deep tank is placed below the surface. We understood, however, it was difficult to secure sufficient fall. This would mean that perhaps tank is not far below the surface, and until we find out more about it cannot judge as to the wisdom of putting only a wood top on it.

Suppose for instance tank is buried under 8 ft. of earth which at 100 lbs. to the foot would give 800 lbs. weight on each square foot of the roof. This, of course, would be more than even a 5" slab would be expected to carry. We think it would be best to report to you depth tank is below surface as soon as we find this out.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Since writing you on the 9th instant regarding septic tank at Cardston, we have been advised that the tank is 4'6" below ground level. At the time we wrote you our Mr. Mitchell, who was in charge of the work at Cardston, was in Fort William, and we had no opportunity to discuss matters with him. He was in Winnipeg for the last weekend, however, and we got some additional light on the matter from him.

We find the tank is 16 ft. wide by 25 ft. long, having a longitudinal divisional wall, making the tank into two sections 6x25 ft. This divisional wall, however, does not extend up to carry roof, so that ceiling slab, which is 5" thick, carries right across the full width of 16 feet.

Our estimate for this work was made up from a pencilled drawing sent to us by Mr. Smith. The first estimate, as previously mentioned to you, showed a ceiling slab 6" thick, but that was when tank was 20 ft. wide. When the tank was reduced to 16 ft. wide the thickness of the slab was reduced to five inches. We did not question Mr. Smith's design - the slab thickness of 5" to what we thought a span of 6 ft. appeared a good proportion, as we generally figure that if a slab thickness equals 1/2" for every foot of span, it is correct. We took it as a matter of course that divisional wall was carried up the same height as the sides. This seemed so obvious that we did not even tell Mr. Smith, or even Mr. Mitchell, the way it had been figured. It appears, however, that Mr. Smith's interpretation of the drawing to Mr. Mitchell was that he had no intention of building divisional wall the same height at the sides.

Mr. Mitchell informs us that when building the tank it occurred to him the slab was too thin and he suggested to Mr. Smith that some means should be taken to strengthen it, and although he could receive no order for so doing he put in two piers from the centre wall to support the slab and put in extra steel across these piers. As this work was done without an order, we could get no payment for it. It is evident now that what Mr. Mitchell voluntarily did, and a good deal more,
was necessary.

Mr. Mitchell states that he did not do any figuring as to the load imposed on the slab, but from his general experience in handling concrete work he thought a 5" slab was too thin for such a span, and as it was not his responsibility, and not being trained for the design of slab, he was not called on or in a position to pass on the sufficiency of the design.

Now that the failure of the slab has proved its weakness, we suggest that in addition to the piers put up by Mr. Mitchell that a longitudinal beam be put over them to support slab, or instead of this continue the centre wall to the under side of slab, making one or more openings in it, so that tank can be entered from the side that manhole is in.

Figuring that the earth cover will weigh 100 lbs. to cubic feet, a depth of 4'6" from the surface will give a load of 450 lbs. to square ft. over the tank. Suppose we figure a load of 600 lbs. to the square foot on the slab to include weight of slab; this, we suggest, would require a 7" slab and about one percent of steel for a span of 6 ft.

If there is to be no centre support, and the slab run from side to side of the tank, I suggest it will require for the 16 ft. span to carry load of 600 lbs. to the ft. a 12" slab and proportionate amount of steel.

Inasmuch as Mr. McLean's letter proposes 2" plank top, we feel these facts should be placed before you, and we would therefore like to have your instructions now that you know tank is below surface.

In the meantime we are preparing the tank for a new top of some kind and as soon as we hear from you will proceed with finishing it off.

As we are billing the Department with some other work as set forth in previous correspondence, we will leave the question of responsibility for payment for consideration with other items we have to bring up.

Yours very truly,

CLAYTON COMPANY LIMITED.

R.G.

CARDSTON, Alta.

Re- St.Paul's School; Blood Reserve.

Dear Mr.Faunt:

I duly received your letter of the 23rd inst. with a raft of bills enclosed regarding some of which you ask for information.

I have numbered the bills referred to me, and will take them up briefly in the order in which I have numbered them.

(1) Roof Flanges for Bell Rope. This was not in Claydon's contract and the charge seems all right.

(2) Connecting Range Boiler to Stove in Principal's Residence. I did not assume this expense on behalf of the Dept'. I conveyed a message to Mr.Flett from the Principal, giving Flett the name of the range and the measurement of the fire-box. I am not in a position to say whether this bill should be paid by the Dept' or by Canon Middleton himself; it would seem to depend on what the Dept's policy is in such cases. It seems reasonable that the Dept' would finish the job when providing hot and cold water to the Principal's residence.

(3) Smoke Pipe for School Kitchen Range. This work was imperative as the range was obviously useless until provided with connections to the chimney.

(4) The Metal Extensions to Brick Chimneys. This was authorized in telegram to me of Jan.2nd, signed by J.D.McLean.

(5) Setting up Bake Oven & Smoke Pipe for Same. This work was necessary, and the charge does not seem excessive.

(6) Metal Extension to Laundry Chimney. See answer to No.4.

(7) This work was done after I left. The Dept' paid for setting up a range boiler in the Principal's residence, but as he was using a stove in the basement instead of the kitchen range, he was without hot water most of the time; hence he asked for connection to be made with the school hot water supply, and this charge of $16.35 was thus incurred. He now has two sources of hot water supply, which will be a great advantage to him when the heating boilers are not in use.

(8) Threading N.P.Pipe, 25¢. I don't know what this item is.
